THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Henry Green, Appellant,
        v.
        Tracy Godfrey Morris, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
  Â George M. McFaddin, Jr., Family Court
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-276
  Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed June 6,
  2007

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
        James H. Babb, of Sumter, for Appellant.
        Warren Stephen Curtis, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Henry
  Green (Father) appeals the family courtâ€™s determination that it lacked
  jurisdiction to modify a South Carolina custody order.Â  Father further appeals
  the family courtâ€™s decision that even if it had jurisdiction, it would decline
  to exercise it.Â  We affirm as modified. 
FACTS
On September 15, 1998, Tracy Morris
  (Mother) and Father had a son, Mark Austin Green, as a result of their
  nonmarital union.Â  In 1999, the parties separated.Â  On August 7, 2000, the Sumter County family court issued the original custody, support, and visitation order.Â  The
  parties received joint custody with Mother as the primary custodial parent.Â  In 2002, the child moved with Mother to Georgia.Â  Mother and Father
  appeared before the family court several times on matters regarding the child.Â  In 2004, Mother married an active member of the United States Marine Corps who
  was stationed in Arizona, and the family court entered a consent order
  allowing Mother to take the child with her to Arizona.
On June 5, 2005, the child arrived in South Carolina for his summer visitation with Father.Â  The child was scheduled to
  return to Arizona on August 6, 2005.Â  Upon arriving in South Carolina
  for summer visitation with Father, the child began relaying incidents of
  violence including corporal punishment perpetrated by Motherâ€™s husband.Â  Based
  on those allegations, on July 29, 2005, Father filed an action in the family
  court seeking modification of the custody order.Â  On August 3, 2005,
  Mother called to speak to the child, and Father informed her he would not be
  returning the child on August 6 as scheduled.Â  On August 11, 2005, Mother
  filed a response to Fatherâ€™s complaint asserting in part that the South Carolina family court lacked jurisdiction over the matter. Â 
On March 16, 2006, the family court issued
  an order dismissing Fatherâ€™s action finding it did not have jurisdiction
  because Arizona was now the childâ€™s home state, and the Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act (PKPA), 28 U.S.C. Â§
  1738A (2000), mandates that a
  court can decide child custody matters only if it is the childâ€™s home state or
  has been the childâ€™s home state in the last six months.Â  Further, the
  family court determined even if it did have jurisdiction, it would decline to
  exercise it because South Carolina is an inconvenient forum to make a custody
  decision in the case.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On
  appeal from a family court order, this Court has authority to correct errors of
  law and find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814 (1992).Â  However, this broad scope of review does
  not require this Court to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings. Â Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d
  620, 623 (2003). Â â€œThe family court in its discretion may enter
  an order declining to exercise jurisdiction based on a finding that it is an inconvenient
  forum, which this Court will uphold absent an abuse of that discretion.â€ Â Charest
    v. Charest, 329 S.C. 511, 516,
  495 S.E.2d 784, 786 (Ct. App. 1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Father argues the
  family court erred in finding it lacked jurisdiction to modify the custody
  order.Â  We agree.
The
  PKPA and the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act (UCCJA), sections 20-7-782 to -830 of the South Carolina Code
  (1976), â€œgovern the subject matter jurisdiction of state courts to rule
  in interstate custody disputes. Â Because the PKPA is federal legislation, its
  provisions will govern any conflict between it and the UCCJA . . . .â€Â  Widdicombe v. Tucker-Cales, 366 S.C. 75, 86, 620 S.E.2d 333, 339 (Ct.
  App. 2005) (petition for cert. filed) (citations omitted).Â  One of
  the UCCJAâ€™s purposes is to avoid conflicting custody decrees between states.Â  Id. at 87, 620 S.E.2d at 339; see
    also S.C. Code Ann.
    Â§ 20-7-784 (1976) (Other purposes of the UCCJA include avoiding
  relitigation of custody decisions of other states if feasible and facilitating
  the enforcement of custody decrees of other states.).
The
  family court found it did not have jurisdiction because the PKPA provides that a child
  custody or visitation determination is consistent with the PKPA only if the court has jurisdiction under the law of the state
  and one of the provided conditions is met.Â  The condition the family court
  relied on was:

  such State (i) is the home State of the child on the
    date of the commencement of the proceeding, or (ii) had been the childâ€™s home
    State within six months before the date of the commencement of the proceeding
    and the child is absent from such State because of his removal or retention by
    a contestant or for other reasons, and a contestant continues to live in such
    State . . . .

28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(c)(2)(A)
  (1988).Â  However, the family court interpreted the statute as providing
  that only the home state has jurisdiction.Â  This is contrary to a reading of
  the plain language of the statute, which provides that a state being the
  childâ€™s home state is only one of the reasons a court can exercise
  jurisdiction.Â  Another reason a state may maintain jurisdiction under the PKPA is if â€œthe
  court has continuing jurisdiction pursuant to subsection (d) of this section.â€ 28
  U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(c)(2)(E) (1988). Â Subsection (d) provides,

  The jurisdiction of
    a court of a State which has made a child custody or visitation determination
    consistently with the provisions of this section continues as long as the
    requirement of subsection (c)(1) of this section continues to be met and such
    State remains the residence of the child or of any contestant.

28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(d) (1988).Â  Accordingly, if South Carolina issues the original custody decree in
  accordance with the PKPA and one parent still resides in South Carolina, then South Carolina has jurisdiction if it retains it under the UCCJA. Â 
The PKPA mandates three criteria for a court to retain continuing
  jurisdiction: (1) that the
  original custody determination was entered consistently with the provisions of
  the PKPA; (2) that the court maintain jurisdiction under its own state law, in South Carolina, the UCCJA; and (3) that the state remains the residence of the child or of
  any contestant.Â  Widdicombe, 366 S.C. at 86, 620 S.E.2d at 339.Â  At the time of the original custody decree, Mother, Father, and
  the child were all residents of South Carolina, where the court issued the original
  decree.Â  Accordingly, South Carolina meets the first requirement for retaining
  jurisdiction because the original decree was entered consistently with the
  provisions of the PKPA.
The
  second requirement under the PKPA is that South Carolina retain jurisdiction
  under its laws.Â  We give great deference to the jurisdiction of the state that
  originally ruled on a
  custody matter.Â  Widdicombe, 366 S.C. at 87, 620 S.E.2d at
  339-40.Â 
  â€œCourts which render a custody decree normally retain continuing jurisdiction to modify the decree under local law.â€Â  Knoth v. Knoth,
  297 S.C. 460, 463, 377 S.E.2d 340, 342 (1989).Â  

  Although
    more than one state may meet the jurisdictional requirements under the UCCJA,
    once a custody decree has been entered, the continuing jurisdiction of the
    decree state is exclusive.Â  This jurisdiction continues if one parent continues
    to reside in the decree state and substantial evidence remains there, even
    though another state has become the childâ€™s home state.Â  

Charest
  v. Charest, 329 S.C. 511, 518, 495 S.E.2d 784, 788 (Ct. App. 1997)
  (citations omitted).Â  This jurisdiction is
  not necessarily affected by a childâ€™s residence in another state.Â  Knoth,
  297 S.C. at 464, 377 S.E.2d at 342-43.Â  If the prior state still has sufficient
  contact with the case to satisfy the jurisdictional requirements, all petitions
  for modification must be addressed to that state.Â  Id. at 463, 377
  S.E.2d at 342.Â  The courtâ€™s previous consideration of the case is one factor in
  favor of its continued jurisdiction.Â  Id.Â  When a state attempts to
  exercise continuing jurisdiction over a custody decree on which it has
  previously ruled, we broadly interpret the jurisdictional requirements in the
  UCCJA.Â  Widdicombe, 366 S.C. at 87, 620 S.E.2d at
  340. 
In Knoth, an Illinois family court modified custody in a matter a South Carolina family court had previously decided on numerous occasions.Â  297 S.C. at 461, 377 S.E.2d at 341.Â  The South Carolina
  Supreme Court found because the mother remained in South Carolina and the child
  still had considerable contacts with the state, South Carolina continued to
  have exclusive jurisdiction over the matter, and the Illinois family court
  improperly assumed jurisdiction.Â  Id. at 464, 377 S.E.2d at 342.Â  
In Charest, a case analogous to the
  instant case, this Court found â€œ[a]s the decree state, South
  Carolina clearly had continuing jurisdiction . . . based on the fact that at
  least one parent, the father, continued to reside here and the children visited
  him and remained in contact with him in South Carolina.â€Â  329 S.C. at 518-19, 495
  S.E.2d at 788.Â  In the present case, because
  Father still resided in South Carolina and the child visited Father in South Carolina, South Carolina meets the second requirement of the PKPA because it continued
  to have jurisdiction under this stateâ€™s laws.Â  
The
  third prong of the PKPA analysis provides that one party must continue to
  reside in the state.Â  Because Father continued to reside in South Carolina, the
  third criterion of the PKPA is satisfied. Accordingly, South Carolina meets all three requirements mandated by the PKPA for it to have continuing
  jurisdiction over the matter, and the family court erred in finding it lacked
  jurisdiction.
Father
  contends the family court erred in declining to exercise jurisdiction.Â  We
  disagree.
The family court may decline to exercise jurisdiction
  if South Carolina is an inconvenient forum to make a custody determination
  under the circumstances of the case and a court of another state is a more
  appropriate forum.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-796(a) (1976).Â  When determining if South Carolina is an inconvenient forum, the family court should consider if another stateâ€™s
  assumption of jurisdiction is in the childâ€™s interest.Â  Â§ 20-7-796(c).Â  The family court should take
  into account the following factors in making its decision:

  (1) if
    another state is or recently was the childâ€™s home state;
  (2) if another state has a closer connection with the
    child and his family or with the child and one or more of the contestants;
  (3) if substantial evidence concerning the childâ€™s
    present or future care, protection, training and personal relationships are
    more readily available in another state;
  (4) if the parties have agreed on another forum which
    is no less appropriate;
  (5) if the exercise of jurisdiction by a court of this
    State would contravene any of the purposes stated in Â§ 20-7-784.

Id.Â  The family court may also
  consider other factors it deems relevant.Â  Id.
In McGee v. McGee, 287
  S.C. 644, 647, 340 S.E.2d 571, 573 (Ct. App. 1986), we found the family court
  did not abuse its discretion in determining Georgia, rather than South
  Carolina, was the more appropriate forum for a custody action. Â Although the
  parents were divorced in South Carolina and the
  father continued to live here, the mother and the coupleâ€™s child had lived in Georgia for five years. Â Id. at 646, 340 S.E.2d at 573.Â  The child had attended
  school in Georgia for three years, all of his recent medical records were in Georgia, and all of his extracurricular activities were centered in Georgia. Â Id. at 647, 340
  S.E.2d at 573.Â  Therefore, those people most familiar with the childâ€™s current
  condition, such as teachers, friends, and neighbors, were in Georgia.Â  Id.
Similarly, in Charest, we found the family
  court did not abuse its discretion in declining to exercise its jurisdiction in
  order for a change of custody action to be instituted in New York. Â 329 S.C. at 520, 495
  S.E.2d at 789.Â  Although the father still resided in South Carolina, the children had
  resided in New York with their mother for five years before the action was
  instituted.Â  Id.Â  Accordingly,
  New York had the most significant connection to the children, and the witnesses
  who could testify about the childrenâ€™s daily activities and current condition
  were located there. Â Id.Â  The children were enrolled in school, attended
  church, and spent most of their time in New York.Â  Id.Â  Further, any
  evidence of the childrenâ€™s alleged mistreatment would necessarily come from New York.Â  Id.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In the present
  case, the child had lived in Arizona for over a year before Father filed this
  action.Â  Father alleges abuse at the hands of Motherâ€™s husband who lived in Arizona with the child.Â  Accordingly, any witnesses to testify about the interaction
  between the child and Motherâ€™s husband would be in Arizona.Â  Because the child
  has resided in Arizona for over a year, it is his home state, it has more
  substantial evidence concerning the childâ€™s care, and it has a closer
  connection to the child than South Carolina as the child has not lived here since
  2002.Â  Therefore, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in
  declining to exercise jurisdiction over the matter.[1]
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  because South Carolina meets the three criteria for retaining jurisdiction under
  the PKPA, the family court erred in finding it did not have jurisdiction to
  modify the custody decree.Â  However, the family court did not abuse its
  discretion in finding that even if it had jurisdiction, it would decline to
  exercise it because South Carolina was an inconvenient forum.Â  Therefore, the
  family courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED AS
  MODIFIED.[2]
HUFF, BEATTY,
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
  

[1] Additionally, Father maintains the family court
  deprived him of his procedural and substantive due process rights by executing
  an order granting the â€œde facto permanent reliefâ€ of a dismissal for lack of
  jurisdiction.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court has established a firm policy of declining to rule on constitutional issues
  unless such a ruling is required. Â Fairway
    Ford, Inc. v. County of Greenville, 324 S.C. 84, 86, 476 S.E.2d 490, 491
  (1996).Â  Fatherâ€™s due process claims seemingly center around the
  fact that the family court erred in finding it lacked jurisdiction.Â  Because we
  determine the family court erred in finding it lacked jurisdiction, we find it
  unnecessary to address whether Father was deprived of his due process rights.Â  
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Lee Edward Ellerbe appeals his conviction

  guarantees criminal defendants a right to counsel.â€Â  State v. Gill, 355
  S.C. 234, 243, 584 S.E.2d 432, 437 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  This right, however, can

  prior to trial.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThe trial judge has the responsibility to ensure

  self-representation, and makes a knowing and intelligent waiver of the right to
  counsel.â€Â  Id.Â  
On

  one, but two judges clearly informed Ellerbe of the dangers and disadvantages
  of self-representation.Â  On September 2, 2003, Judge Macaulay expressly told
  Ellerbe that he was entitled to an attorney and that it would be dangerous for
  Ellerbe to proceed without one; on October 6, 2003, Judge Williams expressly
  told Ellerbe that he was entitled to an attorney and that it would be dangerous
  for Ellerbe to proceed without one.Â  Nevertheless, Ellerbe proceeded pro se.Â 
  He did so knowingly and voluntarily.Â  Accordingly, after a thorough review of

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Mark and Beth-Ann Altstaetter, Appellants,
        v.
        Liberty Insurance Corporation and Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Curtis L. Coltrane, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-299
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 8, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Terry Wayne Yarbrough, of Beaufort, for Appellants.Â  
        Pope D. Johnson, III, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Mark Altstaetter
  and Beth-Ann Altstaetter appeal the grant of summary judgment in favor of
  Liberty Insurance Corporation and its subsidiary, Liberty Mutual Insurance
  Company (collectively Liberty).Â  We
  affirm.[1]
FACTS
Mark Altstaetter sustained an injury while working for Balfour
  Beatty, Inc. (Employer). Â Liberty provided workersâ€™ compensation
  coverage for Employer.Â  Altstaetter filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim against
  Employer and Liberty. Â Liberty appointed Sandy Mayhew, an employee of Liberty, as the nurse case manager for the claim.Â  As a nurse case manager, Mayhew takes
  an active role in managing the treatment of a claimant, utilizing her nursing
  skills.Â  Altstaetter concluded Mayhew neglected to inform him of his true
  diagnosis, exacerbating his condition. Â The Altstaetters filed this action
  against Liberty alleging, inter alia, negligence, breach of fiduciary
  duty, and breach of good faith and fair dealing.Â  Liberty moved for dismissal
  alleging the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act provided the Altstaettersâ€™ exclusive
  remedy.Â  
After
  reviewing affidavits and considering the partiesâ€™ arguments, the court treated
  the matter as a motion for summary judgment and granted Liberty relief.Â  The
  court denied the Altstaettersâ€™ motion for reconsideration and motion to correct
  a scrivenerâ€™s error.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary
  judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact, and
  the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v.
    Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493-94, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  In determining
  whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences,
  which can reasonably be drawn therefrom, must be viewed in the light most
  favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Faile v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Juvenile Justice,
  350 S.C. 315, 324, 566 S.E.2d 536, 540 (2002).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.
The Altstaetters argue the circuit court
  erred in finding as an â€œundisputed factâ€ that Liberty was functioning in its
  capacity as the workersâ€™ compensation carrier and entitled to an employerâ€™s
  immunity under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  We disagree.
Employers are immune from tort actions by employees for
  work-related accidents or injuries because the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act
  provides the exclusive remedy for an employee.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-540
  (1985); Fuller v. Blanchard, 358 S.C. 536, 541, 595 S.E.2d 831, 834 (Ct.
  App. 2004).Â  In Ancrum v. U.S.
    Fidelity & Guaranty Co., our
  supreme court addressed the certified question of whether the immunity provided
  to an employer extended to workersâ€™ compensation insurance carriers.Â  301 S.C.
  32, 32, 389 S.E.2d 645, 645 (1989).Â  The court concluded a carrier enjoys an
  employerâ€™s immunity under the act except when the carrier stands in the
  position of a third party unrelated to its function as a compensation carrier.Â  Id. at 34, 389 S.E.2d at 646.Â  
In Ancrum,
  the carrier provided safety inspections for its insured employers.Â  Id. at 32, 389 S.E.2d at 645.Â  The court provided a guideline to determine whether a
  carrier functioning in such a capacity acted as a carrier or as an unrelated
  third party:

  Carriers
    may perform safety inspections to assess risk and reduce on-the-job injuries in
    order to minimize benefit payments and premium increases.Â  In such a case,
    safety inspections would be integral to the function of a workerâ€™s compensation
    carrier.Â  On the other hand, a carrier may contract with an employer as an
    independent provider of safety inspections undertaking the employerâ€™s legal
    duty to provide a reasonably safe work place.Â  In this situation, the carrier
    would be performing as a third party and would not be immune from liability.Â 
    Evidence of such an agreement could include specific contractual language or
    payment of additional fees for these services.

Id. at 34, 389 S.E.2d at 646. Â By contrast, this court in Fuller, refused to extend the employerâ€™s statutory immunity to a
  physician.Â  358 S.C. at 543, 595 S.E.2d at 834-35.Â  In Fuller, the
  allegedly negligent physician was an employee of Doctorâ€™s Care, providing
  services to employees of Westinghouse pursuant to an agreement between Doctorâ€™s
  Care and Westinghouse.Â  Id. at 539, 595 S.E.2d at 833.Â  Based on
  Westinghouseâ€™s lack of the right to control the physician, this court concluded
  the physician was an independent contractor of Westinghouse.Â  Id. at
  543, 595 S.E.2d at 835. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-560 (1985) (providing
  remedies from third parties).
In
  this case, we agree with the circuit court that, even in the light most
  favorable to the Altstaetters, Mayhew was an employee of Liberty, acting in the
  scope of employment, in furtherance of Libertyâ€™s function as an insurance
  carrier rather than as an unrelated third party.[2]Â 
  Liberty provided nurse case managers as an ongoing part of its insurance
  carrier service to its employer clients. Â The nurses were Liberty employees and
  worked exclusively on workersâ€™ compensation cases.Â  Thus, we apply Ancrum and conclude Liberty is entitled to the immunity provided employers in the
  act.Â  
II.
The
  Altstaetters also contend the circuit court erred in:Â  (1) interpreting Ancrum to mean there is a grant of immunity for any conduct of the carrier in trying
  to return the employee to work; (2) holding that bad faith claims do not exist
  if the bad faith occurs while trying to get the employee back to work as soon
  as possible; and (3) holding that the Ancrum court granted absolute
  immunity to the workersâ€™ compensation carrier for any conduct the carrier
  undertakes so long as the purpose is to return the employee to work as soon as
  possible.Â  These issues are not properly preserved for our review.Â  Where an
  issue presented to the trial court is not explicitly ruled on in the final
  order, the issue must be raised by an appropriate post-trial motion to be
  preserved for appeal.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 460, 535
  S.E.2d 438, 444-45 (2000) (finding where the trial judge does not explicitly
  rule on an argument raised, and the issue is not raised in a Rule 59 motion,
  the appellate court may not address the issue).Â  
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we find the court did not err in granting summary judgment.Â  Accordingly, the order on appeal is 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
  

Â [1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
 [2] We acknowledge the issue of whether Liberty was functioning as a carrier
  is not undisputed, as argued by the Altstaetters in their post-trial motion to
  correct a scrivenerâ€™s error and on appeal.Â  However, we find no genuine issue
  of material fact as to this issue and accordingly view the circuit courtâ€™s use
  of the term â€œundisputedâ€ as a scrivenerâ€™s error not entitling the Altstaetters
  to relief.Â  See Owners Ins. Co. v. Clayton, 364 S.C. 555, 563,
  614 S.E.2d 611, 615 (2005) (finding error without prejudice does not warrant
  reversal).

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Jessie Stutts, Respondent,
        v.
        Harper James Finucan, Inc., Employer, and Auto Ownerâ€™s Insurance Co., Carrier, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-300
  Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 8,
  2007

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Kirsten L. Barr and Roy A. Howell, III, both of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellants.
        Cameron Marshall and Paul N. Uricchio, III, both of Charleston,
          for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Harper
  Finucan, Inc., and Auto Workers Insurance appeal a circuit court order
  reversing the final decision and order of the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™
  Compensation Commission. Â Appellants argue the circuit court disregarded the
  proper standard of review by making its own findings of fact and awarding
  benefits to Jessie Stutts.Â  We reverse.[1]
FACTS
Stutts
  began working for Happy Finucan, owner of Harper Finucan, Inc., as a plumber in
  March 2001.Â  Stutts was an hourly employee, but was not paid for his travel
  time to or from work.Â  Finucan had initially agreed to provide Stutts with a
  work vehicle, but this never happened.Â  Instead, Stutts bought a truck himself to
  travel to and from work.Â  Stutts had his own insurance policy on his truck, was
  free to use the truck as he chose, and was responsible for all repairs on his
  truck.Â  However, Finucan or his subordinates routinely paid to fill up Stuttsâ€™
  gas tank, usually once but sometimes twice in a week.Â  
On the morning of September 12, 2002, Stutts left his truck at
  Rumphâ€™s Garage for repairs to the brakes. Finucan agreed to pay for these
  repairs because Stutts could not afford them.Â  That afternoon after work,
  Stutts picked up his truck and headed home.Â  On the way home, Stutts rear-ended
  a tractor-trailor and sustained injuries.Â  
After the
  accident, Stutts filed a claim for workersâ€™ compensation.Â  The single commissioner
  determined that Stuttsâ€™ injury was compensable under the provision of
  transportation exception to the â€œgoing and coming rule.â€Â  The Appellate Panel
  reversed, finding Stuttsâ€™ accident was unrelated to his employment and his
  injury did not â€œoccur during the course and scope of his employment.â€Â  Further,
  the Appellate Panel concluded that the exceptions to the â€œgoing and coming
  ruleâ€ did not apply to this case because Â Finucan did not provide Stuttsâ€™
  transportation, did not pay for Stuttsâ€™ travel time, and did not charge him
  with any special errand after work that day.Â  
Stutts
  appealed to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court reversed and reinstated the
  decision of the single commissioner.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act
  establishes the â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ standard for judicial review of
  decisions of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, 276
  S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981).Â  The findings of the Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Commission will not be set aside if the findings are supported by substantial
  evidence and are not controlled by legal error.Â  Gray v. Club Group, Ltd.,
  339 S.C. 173, 528 S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Substantial evidence is evidence
  that, when viewing the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach
  the conclusion the commission reached. Lockridge v. Santens, 344 S.C.
  511, 544 S.E.2d 842 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The appellate court may not substitute
  its judgment for that of the commission as to the weight of the evidence on
  questions of fact.Â  Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. S.C. Second Injury Fund,
  363 S.C. 612, 611 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App. 2005).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Finucan and Auto Workers appeal the circuit court order awarding
  benefits to Stutts, arguing the circuit court disregarded the proper standard
  of review by making its own findings of fact.Â  We agree.Â  
Injuries sustained while traveling to and
  from work are generally not compensable under workersâ€™ compensation law.[2]Â  Eadie v. H.A. Sack Company, 322 S.C. 164, 168, 470 S.E.2d 397, 399 (Ct.
  App 1996).Â  However, South Carolina recognizes five
  exceptions to this rule: 1) if the
  employer provides the means of transportation or pays travel time; 2) if the
  employee performs duties during his commute; 3) if the way used is inherently
  dangerous; 4) if the place where the injury occurs is in such close proximity
  to the workplace that it is brought within the scope of employment; and
  5) if the injury occurs while the employee is on a special errand for the
  employer.Â  Id. 168-69, 400.Â  
The first exception is the
  only one at issue here.Â  The Appellate Panel found this exception
  did not apply because the â€œEmployer did not provide [Stutts] a means of
  transportation by providing work tools, paying of one tank of gas each week,
  and paying for repairs at Rumphâ€™s . . . .Â  The evidence establishes the [Stutts]
  was driving his own vehicle.â€Â  However, the circuit court, relying on Eadie
    v. H.A. Sack Co., found that these facts clearly constituted â€œprovision of
  transportationâ€ by the employer.Â  322 S.C. 164, 470 S.E.2d 397 (Ct. App. 1996).
  Â Thus, the circuit court held that Stuttsâ€™ trip home qualified as an exception
  to the â€œgoing and coming ruleâ€ and thereby brought Stutts within the benefits
  of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act. 
Whether the circumstances of this case constitute the provision of
  transportation is a question of fact, subject to the substantial evidence
  standard of review.Â  Eadie v. H.A. Sack Co., 322 S.C. 164, 470 S.E.2d
  397 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Thus, if substantial evidence supports the Appellate
  Panelâ€™s finding, we must affirm.
In this case, Stutts purchased his own vehicle, paid his own
  insurance and taxes on the vehicle, and was not paid any wage while traveling
  to and from work.Â  Substantial evidence therefore supported the Appellate
  Panelâ€™s determination that Finucan did not provide transportation to Stutts. 
Further, we do not believe Eadie supports
  reversal of the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding of fact.Â  In Eadie, the
  employer admitted his provision of transportation to the employee, stating:
  â€œthe bottom line is that the reimbursement of Eadieâ€™s mileage in his personal
  vehicle at a rate of twenty-two cents per mile is the equivalent of providing a
  company vehicle.â€Â  Eadie, 322 at 170, 470 S.E.2d at 400 (Ct. App.
  1996).Â  The
  Appellate Panel in Eadie found there was a provision of transportation,
  and therefore claimant was entitled to benefits.Â  Thus, consistent with the
  scope of review, the court of appeals found substantial evidence supported the
  Appellate Panelâ€™s decision and affirmed the award.
In this case, however, the Appellate Panel found
  Finucan did not provide transportation to Stutts.Â  Like in Eadie, there
  is substantial evidence to support that finding, and the circuit court therefore
  erred in reversing the Appellate Panel.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s award
  of benefits is
REVERSED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., and CURETON, A.J.
  

[1] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] This is often referred to
  as the â€œgoing and coming rule.â€

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for
          Appellant.Â  
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W.
          Elliott, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for

PER

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Devario Simpson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â G. Edward Welmaker, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-304
  Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed June 8,
  2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley E. Elliott, Assistant
          Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail,
          of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Devario
  Simpson (Simpson) appeals his convictions for trafficking cocaine and resisting
  arrest. Â Simpson argues the evidence seized and admitted at trial was the
  result of an unlawful detention.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
On the night of April 19, 2003, Deputy McBee of the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Department initiated a traffic stop of a vehicle driven by
  Simpson. Â According to McBee, Simpsonâ€™s car came to a four-way stop across the
  intersection from his patrol car. Â Simpson signaled a right turn and attempted
  to yield the right-of-way to permit McBee to turn left and proceed before him. Â McBee
  declined to turn left before Simpson and instead waved Simpson through the
  intersection. Â Simpson then straightened his vehicleâ€™s wheels and proceeded to
  go straight through the intersection rather than turning right. Â McBee
  testified Simpsonâ€™s vehicle crossed the center line, before passing his patrol
  car. Â McBee then turned and followed Simpson.Â  Simpson continued on the road at
  a speed exceeding thirty-five miles per hour, which McBee believed was over the
  speed limit for a residential road with no posted speed limit. Â McBee initiated
  a traffic stop for crossing the center line and speeding. 
Simpson immediately stopped and exited the car and looked around
  in a manner interpreted by Deputy McBee as an attempt to flee. Â McBee quickly
  approached the car and pinned Simpson between the door and the body of the car.
  Â McBee noticed Simpson had bulges in his pockets, so he searched Simpson for
  weapons. Â McBee testified that as he attempted to pat down Simpsonâ€™s front
  pockets, Simpson contorted his body in an attempt to pull away, so McBee
  handcuffed Simpson and detained him for safety purposes. Â Officer McBee was
  certain, after he completed the pat down, that the bulges in Simpsonâ€™s pants
  were not weapons.
At this time, Simpsonâ€™s passenger exited the car and attempted to
  intervene, so McBee called for backup. Â Deputy Rudy arrived and took custody of
  Simpson while McBee tried to calm the passenger. Â As McBee spoke to the
  passenger, he heard a scuffle and turned and saw Simpson push Rudy with his
  shoulder. Â Rudy responded by placing Simpson under arrest for assaulting a
  police officer. Â McBee joined Rudy and subdued Simpson. 
Meanwhile, another officer responded to the scene with a drug dog.
  Â The dog alerted to the odor of narcotics inside the car. Â A search of the car
  produced 800 grams of cocaine, $11,000 in currency, and other drug
  paraphernalia. Â The officers also searched Simpsonâ€™s person incident to his
  arrest for assaulting a police officer and seized over $6500 in cash from his
  front pants pockets and a hotel key card. Â A search of Simpsonâ€™s hotel room
  pursuant to a search warrant yielded some additional drug paraphernalia.Â  
Simpson was tried by a jury and convicted of trafficking cocaine
  and resisting arrest and acquitted of assault and battery.Â  Simpson was
  sentenced to thirty years in prison for the trafficking charge and one year in
  prison for the resisting arrest charge.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Simpson
  argues his restraint and detention at the traffic stop became unlawful when
  McBee determined he was not armed, and the subsequent searches of his person,
  the car, and the hotel room were not legally justified.Â  We disagree.
In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only, and the
  appellate courts are bound by the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings unless they
  are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827,
  829 (2001).Â  â€œThis same standard of review applies to preliminary factual
  findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal
  cases.â€Â  Id. 
A.Â  Traffic
  Stop
The decision to stop a vehicle is generally reasonable when the
  police have probable cause to believe a traffic violation has occurred.Â  Whren
    v. United States, 517 U.S. 806, 810 (1996).Â  Additionally, â€œ[i]f the
  officerâ€™s suspicions are confirmed or are further aroused, the stop may be
  prolonged and the scope enlarged as required by the circumstances.â€Â  State
    v. Blassingame, 338 S.C. 240, 248, 525 S.E.2d 535, 539 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Police
  may briefly detain and question a person upon a reasonable suspicion, short of
  probable cause for arrest, that the person is involved in criminal activity.Â  Terry
    v. Ohio, 392 U.S. 1, 22 (1968).Â  
In this
  case, Deputy McBee observed Simpsonâ€™s car traveling on the wrong side of the
  road for several feet as it went through an intersection.Â  When McBee turned
  his patrol car around, Simpsonâ€™s car sped up and exceeded the speed limit.Â 
  McBee had ample justification to stop Simpsonâ€™s car.Â  Then, Simpson immediately
  exited the car and looked around in a manner that was reasonably interpreted as
  a possible attempt to flee.Â  That behavior coupled with the bulges in Simpsonâ€™s
  pockets was sufficient to justify McBee in prolonging the stop.
B. Terry Frisk
A
  police officer may frisk a person when he has a reasonable suspicion that the
  individual is armed and dangerous, and the question is â€œwhether a reasonably
  prudent man in the circumstances would be warranted in the belief that his
  safety or that of others was in danger.â€Â  Id. at 27.Â  The term
  reasonable suspicion requires that the officer articulate a particularized and
  objective basis for his belief, and in determining whether reasonable suspicion
  exists, the court must consider the totality of the circumstances.Â  Blassingame,
  at 248, 525 S.E.2d at 539.
The
  circuit court found that McBee articulated a particularized and objective basis
  for his belief that Simpson might be armed and dangerous.Â  Simpson exited the
  car and looked around frantically as soon as the car came to a stop.Â  McBee
  testified that it looked like Simpson was going to run away, so he quickly
  pinned Simpson against the car.Â  McBee testified that Simpsonâ€™s eyes were wide
  and bulging, he was sweating profusely on a cool night, he looked nervous, and
  he had two bulges in his pants pockets.Â  Based on those observations, McBee
  justifiably believed the bulges could have been weapons, and he feared for his
  safety.Â  
When
  McBee informed Simpson he was going to search him for weapons, Simpson became
  combative and twisted his body in an attempt to escape.Â  At this point, McBee
  handcuffed Simpson as an additional safety measure.Â  When McBee completed the
  pat down, he stopped searching Simpson because he was certain the bulges were
  not weapons.Â  Under the circumstances, these actions were also justified.Â  
C.Â  Search
  Incident to Arrest
Once a person is under lawful arrest, a
  contemporaneous search incident to arrest is proper.Â  Shipley v. California, 395 U.S. 818, 819 (1969).Â  The full search of a person under lawful arrest
  does not require a search warrant and is considered reasonable under the Fourth
  Amendment.Â  State v. Freiburger, 366 S.C. 125, 131, 620 S.E.2d 737, 740
  (2005).Â  Furthermore, a trained narcotics dogâ€™s sniff of a vehicle stopped in a
  public place does not constitute a search, and the dogâ€™s positive alert for
  drugs gives probable cause for a subsequent search of the vehicle.Â  State v.
    Jeffus, 22 F.3d 554, 557 (4th Cir. 1994).Â  
Simpsonâ€™s
  passenger began to intervene in the situation by yelling and walking around the
  scene.Â  When Deputy Rudy arrived on the scene, he attempted to further secure
  Simpson while McBee attempted to calm Simpsonâ€™s passenger.Â  When Simpson pushed
  Deputy Rudy, he was immediately arrested for assaulting an officer.Â  Simpson
  was then lawfully searched incident to that arrest.Â  Independent of that
  arrest, the trained drug sniffing dog alerted on Simpsonâ€™s car, which provided
  the probable cause to search the car.Â  Under these circumstances, both the
  search of Simpsonâ€™s person and the search of Simpsonâ€™s car were justified.Â  The
  evidence obtained in these searches provided the probable cause to obtain the
  search warrant for the search of Simpsonâ€™s hotel room.Â  The search of the hotel
  room pursuant to a valid warrant was constitutionally valid as well.Â 
  Therefore, the evidenced seized during these searches was properly admitted
  into evidence at trial.Â  
CONCLUSION
The
  circuit court properly considered the totality of the circumstances surrounding
  Simpsonâ€™s initial traffic stop, Terry frisk, search incident to arrest,
  and search of the hotel room.Â  The record supports the circuit courtâ€™s rulings
  on the admissibility of the evidence.
Accordingly,
  the circuit courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.[1]Â  
HUFF,
  BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ronnie E. Robinson, Respondent,
				v.
				Greenville Water System and State Accident Fund, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal from Greenville County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-311
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 12, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Cynthia Burns Polk and T. McRoy Shelley, III, both of Columbia, for Appellants.
				Kathryn Williams, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  A Single Commissioner of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission awarded continuing benefits to Ronnie E. Robinson for an injury to his right shoulder and resulting psychological harm.Â  The award was upheld by both the Appellate Panel of the Commission and the circuit court.Â  The Greenville Water System and the State Accident Fund (collectively, â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal.Â  We affirm, holding substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s findings.[1]
FACTS
On July 1, 2003, Robinson, then 26 years old, suffered an admitted injury to his right shoulder while working for the Greenville Water System performing maintenance and construction work.Â  Robinsonâ€™s job required a lot of physical exertion, including lifting, climbing, and pulling.Â  At the time of his injury, Robinson was leaning over to lift or pull a cast iron meter box out of the ground when he â€œfelt something popâ€ in his right shoulder.Â  
 
On July 2, 2003, Robinson went to Exigent, an urgent care center, complaining of pain after pulling something in his neck and right arm while working the day before.Â  Dr. Thomas Maskell diagnosed Robinson as having a muscle strain, recommended medications, and allowed him to return to full work duties at Robinsonâ€™s request.Â  Dr. Maskell instructed Robinson to follow-up if he experienced any problems.Â  At a follow-up visit to Exigent on July 23, 2003, Dr. Lynn Owens noted Robinson continued to complain of throbbing pain in his right shoulder and difficulty with movement.Â  Dr. Owens recommended different medications and the restriction of his work to light duty.Â  Â Â 
On August 1, 2003, Dr. Maskell reported Robinson had been continuing to work full time, but his right shoulder still bothered him.Â  Dr. Maskell scheduled an MRI scan and restricted Robinson to light duty.Â  According to Dr. Maskellâ€™s notes of August 11, 2003, Robinson had been sent home from light duty work by his employer.Â  The results of the MRI scan showed Robinson actually had a torn rotator cuff, not a pulled muscle as initially diagnosed, so Dr. Maskell referred Robinson to an orthopedist.Â  Â Â 
Dr. Stephen Geary, an orthopedic surgeon, evaluated Robinson on August 18, 2003 and diagnosed him as having a full-thickness tear of the right dominant[2] rotator cuff, as well as some â€œmoderate degenerative changes of the AC jointâ€[3] and labrum.Â  On August 28, 2003, Dr. Geary performed surgery on Robinson.Â  Robinson continued to experience pain after the surgery, and he began undergoing physical therapy.Â  Â Â 
Because of his continuing pain, Robinson sought a second opinion and was sent to another orthopedic surgeon, Dr. Alan Posta, for an examination.Â  On November 26, 2003, Dr. Posta recommended additional physical therapy and pain management treatment.Â  Dr. Posta found Robinson had a loss of range of motion, pain with overhead motion, tenderness throughout the shoulder, and decreased rotator cuff strength.Â  Dr. Posta opined Robinson had chronic pain and was in need of pain management treatment and further physical therapy, but he was capable of light duty.Â  According to Robinson, there was, effectively, no work for him with his employer because he was told that â€œthere was no such thing as light duty at [his] job.â€Â  Â Â Â Â 
On December 17, 2003, Dr. Geary noted Robinson continued to complain of pain, especially with overhead activity.Â  Nevertheless, Dr. Geary determined Robinson had reached maximum medical improvement (â€œMMIâ€) â€œin regard to his right shoulderâ€ and released him from care, finding he had â€œa 15% (fifteen percent) permanent and partial impairment of his right dominant upper extremity.â€Â  Dr. Geary remarked in his notes that he had â€œnot placed any permanent restrictions onâ€ Robinson.Â  Â Â 
Robinson did not receive additional physical therapy past December 2003 despite repeated requests from his attorneys.Â  Robinson believed Dr. Gearyâ€™s attitude towards him changed after he requested a second opinion.Â  Robinson was terminated from his job with the Greenville Water System in February 2004.Â  Â Â 
Robinson suffered psychological distress from being unable to work and to resume his other normal activities.Â  Robinsonâ€™s pre-existing Touretteâ€™s syndrome became worse due to the psychological stress he was under from his work injury and chronic pain.Â  Robinson went to his family physician, Dr. Danny Caddell, for treatment of his worsening symptoms.Â  On April 19, 2004, Dr. Caddell concluded â€œRobinsonâ€™s Touretteâ€™s syndrome was aggravated by his work injury of July 1, 2003.â€Â  The same day, Dr. Caddell also reported that â€œRobinsonâ€™s problem with his nerves [was] caused and/or aggravated by his work injury of July 1, 2003.â€Â  In May 2004, Dr. Caddell expressly determined Robinson was in need of pain management treatment for the injuries he received at work.Â  Â Â 
In June 2004, Robinson was evaluated by a licensed clinical psychologist, Dr. C. David Tollison, who stated in his professional opinion that Robinson had suffered the â€œexacerbation of a pre-existing psychological condition.â€Â  Specifically, Dr. Tollison opined that chronic pain has affected Robinsonâ€™s psychological state, which, in turn, has generated a level of anxiety, stress, and depression that has created protracted muscular spasms, thus increasing the intensity of Robinsonâ€™s pain and his perception of such.Â  Dr. Tollison recommended that Robinson â€œbe referred for specialty treatment in the two primary areas of impairment, that being residual pain and psychological symptoms.â€Â  Â Â 
On May 25, 2004, Dr. George Bruce, an orthopedic surgeon, noted Robinson continued to complain of constant right arm and shoulder pain that limited his ability to raise his arm over his head or lift more than fifteen pounds.Â  Dr. Bruce stated â€œto a reasonable degree of medical certainty . . . [Robinson suffered] a full-thickness tear of his rotator cuff . . . .Â  As he presents today, he has decreased range of motion and decreased strength of his right shoulder, and decreased right hand grip.â€Â  Dr. Bruce believed Robinson had aggravated pre-existing degenerative conditions in his right shoulder in the accident and stated Robinson now has a â€œ27% physical impairment of the right upper extremity.â€Â 
 
Appellants, meanwhile, moved to terminate Robinsonâ€™s disability payments.Â  Appellants admitted Robinson sustained a compensable injury to his right shoulder, but denied that he was entitled to additional treatment or that he had suffered a compensable injury to any other body part or system.Â  Robinson contended that he needed additional medical treatment and continued temporary compensation benefits due to the injury to his right shoulder and a resulting psychological injury.Â Â Â  
 
By order filed March 9, 2005, the Single Commissioner found Robinson had not reached MMI and the injuries to his right shoulder and his psyche were compensable.Â  The Single Commissioner ordered continuing medical treatment â€œto include additional physical therapy, pain management treatment, and psychological counseling.â€Â  Â Â 
The Single Commissioner specifically found:Â  (1) while Dr. Geary had opined that Robinson was able to return to work in mid-December 2003, Dr. Posta stated at the end of November 2003 that Robinson should continue light duty; (2) Dr. Posta recommended additional physical therapy and pain management treatment that has not yet been provided; (3) the employer â€œis unable to provide [Robinson with] light duty workâ€; (4) Robinson â€œremains totally disabled from working because of his injuries, as he is still under light duty work restrictions and [the employer] is unable to provide work within these restrictionsâ€; (5) Robinson â€œhas developed emotional distress, including depression and anxiety, and increased symptoms of his Touretteâ€™s syndrome as a result of his continued right shoulder pain and his inability to work and function as he did before the accidentâ€; and (6) Robinson â€œhas sustained compensable injury to his psyche, including depression, anxiety and aggravation of his pre[-]existing Touretteâ€™s syndrome as a result of his injury by accident, his related physical injuries, and his ongoing pain and limitations.â€ Â Â Â Â Â 
A unanimous Appellate Panel adopted the order of the Single Commissioner in its entirety on September 30, 2005, concluding the Findings of Fact and Rulings of Law were correct as stated therein.Â  By order filed March 1, 2006, the circuit court affirmed the order of the Appellate Panel, upholding the Commissionâ€™s findings.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  MMI
On appeal, Appellants assert the only evidence in the record is that Robinson has reached MMI and that his benefits should be terminated.Â  They assert the Commission erred in awarding continuing benefits.Â  We disagree.
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Under the APA, an appellate court may reverse or modify an administrative agencyâ€™s ruling if the agencyâ€™s findings, inferences, conclusions, or decisions are affected by an error of law or are clearly erroneous in view of the substantial evidence in the whole record.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(d) & (e) (Supp. 2006).Â 
 
â€œThe findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 519, 466 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1996).Â  Substantial evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion reached by the Commission.Â  Id. 
 
The Commission is the ultimate fact-finder in workersâ€™ compensation cases and is not bound by the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Brayboy v. Clark Heating Co., 306 S.C. 56, 409 S.E.2d 767 (1991) (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-17-50); see also Ross v. Am. Red Cross, 298 S.C. 490, 381 S.E.2d 728 (1989).Â  The final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Commission.Â  Ross, 298 S.C. at 492, 381 S.E.2d at 730.Â  A court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Commission concerning the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2006); see also Ellis v. Spartan Mills, 276 S.C. 216, 219, 277 S.E.2d 590, 591 (1981) (stating â€œit is not the task of courts to weigh the evidence as found by the [C]ommissionâ€).Â 
 
The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not mean the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Ellis, 276 S.C. at 218, 277 S.E.2d at 591. Â â€œWhere there is a conflict in the evidence, either by different witnesses or in the testimony of the same witness, the findings of fact of the Commission are conclusive.â€Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333, 338, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845 (1999). 
 
MMI â€œis a term used to indicate that a person has reached such a plateau that in the physicianâ€™s opinion there is no further medical care or treatment which will lessen the degree of impairment.â€Â  Oâ€™Banner v. Westinghouse Elec. Corp., 319 S.C. 24, 28, 459 S.E.2d 324, 327 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Even if an employee has reached MMI, further medical care or treatment may still be appropriate.Â  See Dodge v. Bruccoli, Clark, Layman, Inc., 334 S.C. 574, 581, 514 S.E.2d 593, 596-97 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œAlthough this medical care or treatment may not reduce the claimantâ€™s degree of physical impairment, it may â€˜tend to lessen the period of disability.â€™â€ (citation omitted)).Â  Whether an employee has reached MMI is a factual determination that is left to the discretion of the Commission.Â  Gadson v. Mikasa Corp., 368 S.C. 214, 224, 628 S.E.2d 262, 268 (Ct. App. 2006).
We agree with the circuit court that substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s finding that Robinson has not reached MMI and that he is entitled to additional benefits.Â  As the circuit court noted, although there was some evidence from Dr. Gearyâ€™s notes that Robinson had reached MMI, at least as to his physical injury, there was conflicting evidence that Robinson had not.Â  Such conflicts should be resolved by the Commission and do not preclude a determination that the Commissionâ€™s findings are supported by substantial evidence.Â 
 
In contrast to Dr. Gearyâ€™s findings, Dr. Posta recommended additional physical therapy and pain management treatment for Robinson and restricted him to light duty on November 26, 2003.Â  In addition, Dr. Caddell continued to treat Robinsonâ€™s shoulder pain and his worsening Touretteâ€™s syndrome.Â  In May 2004 Dr. Caddell specifically recommended additional treatment for Robinson.Â  There was also medical evidence from Dr. Tollison, a licensed clinical psychologist, that Robinson sustained an injury to his psyche as a result of his work accident and had continuing pain from his physical injuries.Â  As late as June 2004, Dr. Tollison recommended that Robinson be referred for specialty treatment for two areas of impairment, Robinsonâ€™s residual pain and his psychological symptoms.Â  Â Â 
Appellants argue Dr. Postaâ€™s recommendation of additional physical therapy occurred prior to Dr. Gearyâ€™s determination of MMI; therefore, no additional therapy is needed.Â  Dr. Posta recommended additional physical therapy and pain management treatment on November 26, 2003.Â  Just a few weeks later, on December 17, 2003, Dr. Geary ended Robinsonâ€™s treatment when he concluded Robinson was at MMI as to his right shoulder.Â  The Commissionâ€™s interpretation was that Dr. Posta was recommending a continuation of treatment, not an imminent cessation of treatment in December, and we find this interpretation reasonable in light of the evidence that Robinson continued to have both physical and psychological problems as a result of his work accident well into the following year.Â  Robinson testified he sought a second opinion from Dr. Posta because Dr. Geary was winding up his treatment even though he was still experiencing problems.Â  The Commission also relied on the medical records of Dr. Caddell, who recommended additional treatment in 2004.Â  Accordingly, we hold substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s findings in this regard.
II.Â  Psychological Injury
Appellants next contend the Commission erred in finding Robinson has sustained a compensable injury to his psyche as a result of his work accident.Â  They further contend even if the condition is compensable, it does not preclude a determination that Robinson has reached MMI.Â  We disagree.
The Commission determined Robinson â€œhas sustained compensable injury to his psyche, including depression, anxiety and aggravation of his pre[-]existing Touretteâ€™s syndrome as a result of his injury by accident, his related physical injuries, and his ongoing pain and limitations.â€Â  This finding was based on Robinsonâ€™s testimony and the medical records of Dr. Caddell and Dr. Tollison.Â 
 
Our supreme court has held that â€œ[m]ental injuries are compensable if they are induced either by physical injury or by unusual or extraordinary conditions of employment.â€Â  Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 493, 541 S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001).Â  â€œAggravation of pre-existing psychiatric problems is compensable if that aggravation is caused by a work-related physical injury.â€Â  Id.Â  When deciding if causation has been established, the Commission has the discretion to weigh and consider both lay and expert evidence, including lay testimony regarding the employeeâ€™s health before and after the accident.Â  Tiller, 334 S.C. at 339-40, 513 S.E.2d at 846.
We agree with the circuit court that substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s finding that Robinson has sustained a compensable injury to his psyche.Â  As noted above, Dr. Tollison expressly determined Robinsonâ€™s pre-existing psychological problems and Touretteâ€™s syndrome were exacerbated by his work injury.Â  Dr. Tollison stated Robinson reported being unable to sleep well because of his discomfort and that he had lost twenty pounds as constant pain left him with no appetite.Â  He noted Robinson has experienced frustration, stress, and depressive symptoms and has had a difficult time adjusting to the multiple lifestyle changes caused by his chronic pain and not being able to work and live as he did prior to the accident.Â  Dr. Tollison concluded Robinsonâ€™s chronic pain had affected his psychological state.Â  

In April 2004 Dr. Caddell also opined that Robinsonâ€™s Touretteâ€™s syndrome was aggravated by his work injury.Â  Dr. Caddell further stated Robinsonâ€™s â€œproblem with his nerves [was] caused and/or aggravated by his work injury of July 1, 2003.â€Â  In May 2004 Dr. Caddell recommended pain management for Robinson.Â Â Â 
 
Moreover, Robinson himself testified that his continued pain and inability to function as he did before his injury had caused him emotional problems and increased his pre-existing problems with Touretteâ€™s syndrome.Â  He expressly stated his inability to return to work has almost â€œmade [him] go crazy.â€Â  Robinson, who had four children, stated he had worked since he was twelve years old and had been with his employer for five years and wanted to get better so he could return to work.Â  Robinsonâ€™s employer reported no problems with Robinson prior to this accident for the five years he had been there.Â  Although Robinson acknowledged he did have some marital problems, he stated he had a normal marriage until this accident.Â  As the circuit court observed, Dr. Tollison specifically recognized the other stressors in Robinsonâ€™s life, such as his pre-existing Touretteâ€™s syndrome and his marital situation, but still opined that Robinsonâ€™s psychological condition was caused by his work injury.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the Commissionâ€™s finding of a compensable psychological injury and its related findings regarding MMI.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Robinson is right-handed.Â  
 
[3]Â  The â€œAC jointâ€ refers to the acromioclavicular joint, i.e., the joint between the acromion (shoulder blade) and the clavicle (collarbone).Â  See generally Taberâ€™s Cyclopedic Dictionary 32, 398 (17th ed. 1993) (discussing the acromioclavicular joint and the clavicle, respectively).

title: Owens v. Thompkins
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Charles Owens, Respondent,
				v.
				Gracie B. Thompkins, individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate of Joseph Thompkins, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â Clifford L. Welsh, Special Referee
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-312
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 12, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Ralph J. Wilson, of Conway, for Appellants
				Howell V. Bellamy, Jr., and Robert S. Shelton, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Gracie Thompkins appeals the special refereeâ€™s decision finding her in contempt of court and awarding costs and attorney fees to Charles Owens.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In an order filed January 16, 2003, the special referee found Charles Owens enjoyed a prescriptive easement over Gracie and Joseph Thompkinsâ€™ land for the purpose of accessing his borrow pit.[2]Â  The special referee further found Owens was entitled to commercial use of the full width of this easement known as Joseph Road.Â  These findings were not appealed.
On December 14, 2004, Owens motioned the Horry County Court of Common Pleas for a Rule to Show Cause why Gracie and Joseph Thompkins should not be held in contempt of court for violating the January 16, 2003 order.Â  In his supporting memorandum, Owens alleged the order was violated because the placement of two boats partially obstructed Joseph Road and because Gracie Thompkins stopped trucks as they attempted to enter the site.Â  Â Â Gracie and Joseph Thompkins responded with a motion to Correct and Define Final Order seeking to have the special referee designate the boundaries of the prescriptive easement.Â 
 
Upon agreement of the parties, the above motions were referred with finality to the special referee.Â  Subsequent to a hearing on this matter, the special referee, in his April 26, 2005 order, dismissed Gracie and Jospeph Thompkinsâ€™ motion as time barred, held them in contempt of the January 16, 2003 order, and ordered them to pay Owensâ€™s costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The special referee denied Thompkins motion to alter or amend the April 26, 2005 order, and she now appeals.Â 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe power to punish for contempt is inherent in all courts and is essential to preservation of order in judicial proceedings.â€Â  Davis v. Davis, 372 S.C. 64, ___, 641 S.E.2d 446, 455 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  On appeal, the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding contempt should be reversed only if it is without evidentiary support or if the trial judge has abused his discretion.Â  Id.Â  When a party is found to have violated a court order, the question of whether or not to impose sanctions remains a matter for the courtâ€™s discretion.Â  Browning v. Browning, 366 S.C. 255, 263, 621 S.E.2d 389, 392-93 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs where either the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support.Â  Browning, 366 S.C. at 263, 621 S.E.2d at 393.Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Thompkins contends the special referee erred in finding her in contempt for violating his previous order because the order did not identify the location or dimensions of the subject road with specificity.Â  We disagree.
Contempt results from the willful disobedience of a court order.Â  Davis, 372 S.C. at ___, 641 S.E.2d at 455.Â  â€œA willful act is one which is â€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™ â€ Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 557 S.E.2d 693, 705 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988)).Â  In a contempt proceeding for violation of a court order, the moving party must show the existence of a court order and the facts establishing the respondentâ€™s noncompliance with the order.Â  Davis, 372 S.C. at ___, 641 S.E.2d at 455.Â  Once the moving party has made out a prima facie case, the burden is then shifted to the respondent to establish his or her defense and inability to comply with the courtâ€™s order.Â  Id.Â  
 
After the special refereeâ€™s January 2003 order was issued, Thompkins did not make any motion to clarify the boundaries of Owens easement on Joseph Road.Â  It was only after Owens had filed his rule to show cause that Thompkins informed the special referee that his order had left her unsure of the boundaries of the easement.Â  This motion was properly found to be time barred, but Thompkins continues to rely upon this reasoning as a defense to her contempt.Â 
 
Owens utilized testimony, photographs, county records, police incident reports and other written documentation between his counsel and counsel for Thompkins to establish that obstructions were placed upon Joseph Road.Â  Through photographs and testimony, Owens established that these obstructions did not exist at the time the January 2003 order was issued, and now resulted in non-compliance with that order.Â  Having established a prima facie case, Owens effectively switched the burden to Thompkins to establish a defense.
Thompkins does not deny that the complained of items were placed where Owens states they were placed; she states that she is not in contempt because she did not know the boundaries of the Joseph Road easement.Â  Thompkins, having not requested the special referee clarify the boundaries prior to Owensâ€™s action, now seeks to plead ignorance as an excuse for failing to comply with the January 2003 order.Â  However, even after the special referee, in his August 9, 2005 amended order and rule to show cause, specifically instructed Thompkins to â€œrelocate all boats, campers, and other vehicles parked along Joseph Lane [Road],â€ Thompkins failed to comply.Â Â 
 
In his January 2003 order, the special referee utilized â€œpictures, plats, and affidavits in finding â€œoverwhelming evidenceâ€ that Joseph Road has been in its current location for more than twenty years.Â  The special referee visited Joseph Road and determined the boundaries represented in a 2001 plat were accurate.Â  In his April 26, 2006 order which found Thompkins to be in contempt, the special referee noted that he had relied on the boundaries established in the 2001 plat in preparing his January 2003 order.[3]Â  Further, the 
 
April 2006 order stated that the 2001 plat boundaries were identical to the boundaries noted in the 2005 survey which was provided to the special referee during the contempt hearing.Â  This 2005 survey included the two boats of which Owens complained and illustrates that each boat is clearly within the boundaries of Joseph Road.Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The special referee found that Owens had â€œshown clearly and convincingly that [Thompkins] had repeatedly violated the January 2003 order as well as the December 2004 order and rule to show cause and the August 2005 amended order and rule to show cause.â€Â  Thompkins claims that she did not personally place the objects on or near Joseph Road, however, Thompkins has repeatedly stated that Joseph road is her personal property.Â  Accordingly, in his April 2006 order, the special referee noted that Thompkins has â€œfull control of it [Joseph Road] as it is [her] personal propertyâ€ and that she had â€œcontinuously permitted [her] tenants to place upon Defendantâ€™s [Thompkins] private property the many vehicles and other items shown in Plaintiffâ€™s [Owens] hearing exhibits.â€Â Â Â Â  Â Â 
Under our limited standard of review and granting the required deference[4] to the special referee who was in a better position to observe the witnesses and adjudge their credibility as well as having the opportunity to visit the site itself, we find there is sufficient evidence to uphold the contempt finding.Â  Because we find no abuse of discretion and uphold the finding of contempt, we uphold the special refereeâ€™s award of costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
 
CONCLUSION
We find the special referee did not abuse his discretion in finding Thompkins to be in contempt.Â  Based on the foregoing, the special refereeâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.         
 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Joseph Thompkins is now deceased.Â  Any mention of only â€œThompkinsâ€ in this appeal refers to Gracie Thompkins individually and as Personal Representative of Josephâ€™s estate.Â 
 
[3] We note the special referee referred to â€œplats,â€ but did not specifically refer to the 2001 plat in his January 2003 order.Â  However, this was the plat available to the court and the parties during the July 2002 hearings which determined the existence of an easement.
[4] See Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 329, 536 S.E.2d 427, 429 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œBecause the appellate court lacks the opportunity for direct observation of witnesses, it should accord great deference to trial court findings where matters of credibility are involved.â€)
