title: Self v. City of Gaffney
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Amy M. Self, Appellant,
				v.
				City of Gaffney, County of Cherokee, and Mark D. Vanderburg, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Cherokee County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-313
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 12, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Fletcher N. Smith, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellant.
				William B. Darwin, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Amy M. Self appeals the circuit courtâ€™s award of summary judgment to defendants City of Gaffney (City), County of Cherokee (County), and Mark D. Vanderburg.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On February 15, 1997, Self was arrested in Gaffney at the home of John D. McCall on a charge of trespass after notice.Â  Self, who was dating or had recently dated McCall, had entered the dwelling with permission but refused to depart when asked.Â  In response, McCall called 911. Â Officer Vanderburg and another policeman responded to the call and informed Self she would have to exit the home.Â  When she again refused, she was arrested.Â  There is no evidence or allegation that Self was injured or otherwise mistreated or mishandled during the arrest.Â  She was transported by Vanderburg to the Gaffney city jail without incident.Â 
 
Self was booked and placed in a holding cell at the jail with several other female inmates.Â  She was taken before a magistrate after approximately three hours; however her bond was not set at that time because she was crying so hysterically that the magistrate did not feel he could properly communicate with her.Â  She was then taken back to the holding cell.Â  At some point, Self complained of breathing problems, irregular heartbeat, and numbness.Â  A detention officer responded to her complaint, and she was taken to Upstate Carolina Medical Center approximately twenty minutes later.Â  According to Self, the officers who transported her dragged her down the hallway, placed her in a swivel chair, and rolled her outside to a police car for transport to the hospital.Â  She asserts that she was bruised as a result of this conduct.
Once at the medical center, Self demanded to be transported elsewhere and refused to sign a consent form in order to receive treatment.Â  She then returned to jail but was soon released.Â  Her entire time of incarceration totaled twenty seven hours.Â  She was later adjudicated not guilty of the trespass after notice charge.
The morning of her release from jail, Self chose to return to Upstate Carolina Medical Center for treatment.Â  One to two weeks after her arrest, she visited a family doctor who prescribed her migraine medication.Â  No other diagnosis or other treatment, physical or psychological, was ever given or recommended.
Self brought suit against the City, County, and Vanderburg, alleging: (1) malicious prosecution; (2) assault and battery; and (3) gross negligence in failing to properly train, discipline, and supervise employees.Â  The circuit court awarded the defendants summary judgment as to all three causes of action.
DISCUSSION
Self claims the circuit court improperly granted summary judgment for the defendants.Â  We disagree.
Selfâ€™s claims are governed by the provisions of the South Carolina Tort Claims Act. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-10 et. seq.Â  The Act provides for a limited waiver of general sovereign immunity; however, it specifically limits the liability of the State, its agencies, political subdivisions, and other governmental entities for causes of action sounding in tort.Â  The Act contains a nonexclusive list of thirty seven specific exceptions to the limited waiver of immunity.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-60 (2005).Â  Selfâ€™s remedy under the Act is the sole, exclusive civil remedy for any tort committed by a governmental entity or government employee acting within the scope of his or her employment.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-20(b), 15-78-30 (2005).Â  Based on these exceptions, the City, County, and Vanderburg were all properly awarded summary judgment on each of Selfâ€™s tort claims.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-60(25) (2005) provides that a governmental entity is not liable for a loss resulting from â€œresponsibility or duty including but not limited to supervision, protection, control, confinement or custody of any . . . prisoner [or] inmate . . . of any governmental entity, except when the responsibility or duty is exercised in a grossly negligent manner.â€ Â Despite Selfâ€™s arguments to the contrary, the Tort Claims Act clearly places a standard of gross negligence on her claims.
In her complaint, Self makes only vague and general allegations of negligence.Â  Self never identifies any particular individual in conjunction with her assault and battery claim, but only generally claims that she received bruises from jail personnel in conjunction with her transport to the hospital.Â  In the body of her complaint, there is a general allegation the defendants failed to properly train and supervise officers in the jail. Â In the prayer for relief, there is another â€œclaimâ€ of gross negligence for the alleged failure to provide medical care.Â  In order to prove any of her claims, Self must show the City, County, or Vanderburg was grossly negligent in their actions.Â  A showing of simple negligence is not enough to defeat the protections of the Act.
South Carolina courts have recognized that â€œgross negligenceâ€ is a relative term, generally meaning the â€œabsence of care that is necessary under the circumstances.â€Â  Hicks v. McCandlish, 221 S.C. 410, 415, 70 S.E.2d 629, 631 (1952).Â  Gross negligence essentially involves an â€œintentional, conscious failure to do something which it is incumbent upon one to do or the doing of a thing intentionally that one ought not to do.â€Â  Richardson v. Hambright, 296 S.C. 504, 506, 374 S.E.2d 296, 298 (1988).Â  This degree of negligence connotes the failure to exercise even a slight degree of care.Â  Wilson v. Etheredge, 214 S.C. 396, 400, 52 S.E.2d 812, 814 (1949); Anderson v. Ballenger, 166 S.C. 44, 55, 164 S.E. 313, 317 (1932).Â  Conversely, there is no gross negligence where slight care is exercised.Â  While gross negligence is ordinarily a mixed question of law and fact, when the evidence supports but one reasonable inference, the question is solely a matter of law.Â  Etheredge v. Richland County Sch. Dist. One, 341 S.C. 307, 534 S.E.2d 275 (2000).
In Etheredge v. Richland County Sch. Dist. One, a high school student was stabbed and killed on campus. Upholding the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to the school, our supreme court held that because the school had only indirect knowledge, if any, of the animosity between the students, provided the hall monitors with walkie-talkies, locked doors between classes, and circulated a daily list of suspended students, the school exercised at least slight care and was entitled to summary judgment pursuant to Â§ 15-78-60.
In Moore v. Berkley County Sch. Dist., 326 S.C. 584, 486 S.E.2d 9 (Ct. App. 1997), the plaintiff sued the school because her son was sexually assaulted by a teacher.Â  This court held that even though there was evidence the teacher conducted her classroom in a lax manner, allowed the lights to be dimmed, and allowed her students to give her back rubs, this did not amount to sufficient notice to hold the school liable under the gross negligence standard.Â  The court held the school had no notice the teacher had made any inappropriate advances toward the student and that, in any event, the inappropriate classroom behavior would still not have created notice that the teacher would have the student over to her home to have sexual contact with him there.
In this case, the jail had requirements for jailer training and experience.Â  These included a high school diploma, two years experience in a job requiring public contact, eighty hours of training and graduation from the Criminal Justice Academy, and twenty additional hours of formal training annually.Â  The jailâ€™s physical force policies prohibited the unnecessary use of force.Â  Nonetheless, even assuming the detention officers performed all of the acts Self alleged, upon examining the types of conduct our appellate courts have held do not rise, as matter of law, to the level of gross negligence, it is clear the City and County were not grossly negligent in failing to properly train, discipline, and supervise employees.
As to the claim relating to an alleged failure to provide medical care, an inmate is entitled to reasonable medical care but is not entitled to choose the particular course of treatment he or she receives, so long as the treatment is adequate.Â  See Deâ€™Lonta v. Angelone, 330 F.3d 630 (2003).Â  Transport to a different medical facility was neither Selfâ€™s right nor the jailâ€™s obligation.Â  By promptly transporting Self to Upstate Carolina Medical Center, the City and County were obviously not grossly negligent in this regard.
Because there is absolutely no evidence in the record indicating any gross negligence on the part of the City and County, the circuit court properly dismissed Selfâ€™s claims against these defendants.
Self argues the circuit court erred in dismissing Vanderburg as a individual defendant because Self swore in her affidavit that he arrested her with malice.Â  She infers this malice directly from her opinion that the arrest was made without probable cause.Â  A plain reading of the trial courtâ€™s order shows, however, that its ruling on Vanderburgâ€™s liability was based on other grounds, each of which supports his dismissal.
The circuit court held that under the Tort Claims Act, an employee is not personally liable for torts committed while acting within the scope of his official duty.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-70(a) (2005).Â  Because Vanderburg was clearly within the scope of his official duty when he responded to a 911 call as the on duty police officer, he is not properly named as a defendant in this suit.
Additionally, the court held that even if Vanderburg could be properly named as a defendant, in light of Selfâ€™s claim of malice based on lack of probable cause, her claims as they relate to him are barred by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-60(3) and Â§ 15-78-60(4).Â  These Tort Claims Act exceptions provide immunity for an alleged loss arising out of the lawful implementation of process and the enforcement of state law.Â  Vanderburg was one the arresting officers and was not involved in any way with Selfâ€™s claims arising from her alleged injuries during her detention.Â  Her claims, therefore, are based solely on Vanderburg arresting her for trespass after notice and he was therefore entitled to be dismissed from the action.
Lastly, Vanderburg was entitled to be dismissed on the ground that Self, despite her bare and conclusory allegations of malice, failed to offer any evidence to prove the common law elements of her malicious prosecution claim.Â  Lack of probable cause is an essential element to a malicious prosecution claim.Â  Whitner v. Duke Power Co., 277 S.C. 397, 288 S.E.2d 389 (1982).Â  â€œâ€˜Probable causeâ€™ is defined as a good faith belief that a person is guilty of a crime when this belief rests on such grounds as would induce an ordinarily prudent and cautious man, under the circumstances, to believe likewise.â€Â  Jones v. City of Columbia, 301 S.C. 62, 65, 389 S.E.2d 662, 663 (1990). Â Trespass after notice is a misdemeanor criminal offense and involves â€œthe failure to leave a dwelling house, place of business or premises of another after having been requested to leave.â€Â  State v. Cross, 323 S.C. 41, 44, 448 S.E.2d 569, 570 (Ct. App. 1994); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-620 (2003).Â  Selfâ€™s obvious trespass after notice was committed in Vanderburgâ€™s presence, clearly providing him probable cause to make the arrest and was therefore properly granted summary judgment and dismissed.
CONCLUSION 
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s award of summary judgment for the respondents is 
 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Watts v. Watts
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Mace Watts, Respondent,
				v.
				Karen Watts, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Horry County
Â Wylie H. Caldwell, Jr., Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-315
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 12, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART,
REVERSED IN PART

	
		
			
				Johnny Gardner, of Conway, for Appellant.
				Anita Ruth Floyd, of Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In this domestic matter, Karen Watts (Mother) argues the family court erred in:Â  (1) failing to award her attorneyâ€™s fees and costs; (2) modifying the partiesâ€™ visitation schedule; and (3) finding her in contempt for denying Mace Watts (Father) visitation with their minor child.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.[1]
FACTS
The parties were married on September 2, 1995, and they had one child, Tyler (Son), born on February 13, 1996.Â  In 2002, Mother discovered Father was involved in an adulterous relationship, and both parties filed for divorce.Â  Father never denied the adultery, and a decree granting a divorce on that basis was filed March 27, 2003.Â  Incorporated into the divorce decree was a consent agreement concerning custody, visitation, property division, alimony, and additional payments to Mother.Â  It was agreed that primary custody of Son would go to Mother, with liberal visitation to Father, including: Â every other weekend; every other Tuesday evening; the first Wednesday of every month for Boy Scouts; four weeks of visitation during the summer months; from the beginning of Christmas break until 4:00 p.m. on Christmas Eve; alternating Spring Break/Easter and Thanksgiving holidays; every Fatherâ€™s Day weekend; and daily telephone visitation on days Son was with Mother.Â  It does not appear from the record that either party appealed from the final divorce decree. 
 
Thereafter, the parties had a contemptuous relationship at the expense of their son.Â  A few days after the final divorce hearing, Mother requested money from Father to help with Sonâ€™s candy sale fundraiser at school.Â  Instead of placing the check under Motherâ€™s doormat in advance, as requested, Father sent a check to the school late through an assistant, and Mother tore the check up in front of Son and his classmates.Â  Although Mother was awarded custody of Son every Motherâ€™s Day weekend, Father planned his wedding to his former paramour, Bobbie, for the Friday of Motherâ€™s Day weekend at Bald Head Island, North Carolina. Â Mother refused to allow Son to attend the wedding, and she insisted that Son attend the â€œMoms and Muffinsâ€ event that same Friday morning at school in Horry County.Â  Father claimed Mother interfered with his court-ordered telephone visitation with Son by not answering the telephone or by yelling at him over the phone in Sonâ€™s presence.Â  Mother denied interfering with telephone visitation, but she claimed Father called all the time and she sometimes avoided the constant telephone calls.Â  There was also an incident where Father came to Motherâ€™s house, despite being warned that he should not appear there, demanded that Mother sign the partiesâ€™ tax returns on short notice and without giving her a copy, and still failed to file the tax returns for several months.Â  Â Â Â Â 
On April 30, 2003, Father filed the underlying action primarily requesting modification of visitation so that he could have Son on Motherâ€™s Day weekend to participate as his best man in his wedding.Â Â  The complaint also requested modification of visitation in general, a finding of contempt against Mother for denying him visitation with the child, and a determination of whether Mother was a fit and proper person to maintain custody of the child.Â  Father obtained an emergency order to ensure that Son could go to the wedding in North Carolina.Â  However, on the morning of the wedding, Father returned Son to his school at 7:15 a.m. for the â€œMoms and Muffinsâ€ event.Â  Mother did not arrive at the â€œMoms and Muffinsâ€ event until it was nearly over, and she later drove Son that morning to Bald Head Island, North Carolina, for Fatherâ€™s wedding that evening.Â Â Â  
 
After Fatherâ€™s wedding, several confrontations between Mother, Father, and Bobbie took place.Â  Mother changed Sonâ€™s school without informing Father.Â  Mother refused to allow Bobbie and Father to pick up Son for Fatherâ€™s visitation at Sonâ€™s school.Â  In one instance, when Mother learned Bobbie had accompanied Father to the school to pick Son up for weekend visitation, Mother took Son, placed him in her car, and attempted to leave with him.Â  Father then blocked Motherâ€™s exit, causing the police to be called and again embarrassing Son in front of his classmates.Â  Mother claimed that the visitation agreement did not allow Father to pick Son up from school.Â  Mother also arranged to volunteer at Sonâ€™s school on Fridays when Father picked Son up for visitation, which led to unnecessary confrontations.Â  Mother further failed to inform Father that notices were sent to the former marital home regarding a bad check that he had written, ultimately resulting in Father getting arrested at Sonâ€™s school for writing a bad check. Â Â Â Â 
Mother eventually filed an answer and counterclaim, generally denying Fatherâ€™s allegations and claiming that Bobbie was a dangerous, immoral person and not proper to care for Son.Â  A trial was held on the matter on February 17, 18, and 19, 2004.Â  The court issued an order chastising both parties for their behavior which was detrimental to Son and modifying visitation.Â  Because the parties disputed the location that Father should pick up Son for exercising visitation, the court specified that Father should pick up Son at school and return Son to school during the school year and pick him up from his home at noon on Friday and return Son home at noon on Monday when school is not in session.Â  The court granted Father additional overnight visitation on alternating Wednesdays.Â  The court also specified the weeks Father could exercise summer visitation, granted Father visitation every Thanksgiving holiday, changed the partiesâ€™ previously agreed upon Christmas visitation schedule, and limited Fatherâ€™s telephone visitation with Son to 7:00 p.m. every Thursday.Â  The court held Mother in contempt for interfering with Fatherâ€™s visitation and directed each party to pay their own attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  Motherâ€™s motion to reconsider was denied, and this appeal followed. Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 244-45 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œNor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 307, 608 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996) (noting that because the appellate court lacks the opportunity for direct observation of witnesses, it should accord great deference to the family courtâ€™s findings where matters of credibility are involved).Â  Our broad scope of review does not relieve appellant of her burden to convince this court that the family court committed error.Â  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Attorneyâ€™s Fees 
Mother contends the family court erred in failing to award her attorneyâ€™s fees and costs and erred in failing to consider and apply the relevant criteria for determining such awards.Â  We disagree. 
 
Initially, we note this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Mother complained in her Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion that the family court should have awarded her attorneyâ€™s fees and costs because:Â  (1) Husband had the greater financial ability to pay the fees; and (2) Husband was largely unsuccessful in gaining custody or in most of his contempt complaints.Â Â  Mother never argued that the family court failed to consider the appropriate factors in reaching the decision that each party be responsible for their own fees.Â  Because the issue is being raised for the first time on appeal, it is not preserved for appellate review.Â  See Bryant v. Waste Mgmt., Inc., 342 S.C. 159, 171-72, 536 S.E.2d 380, 387 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding that a party may not argue one ground at trial and an alternate ground on appeal); Joubert v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Serv., 341 S.C. 176, 184, 534 S.E.2d 1, 5 (Ct. App. 2000) (noting that issues not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate review).Â Â Â  Â 
In any event, the family court has statutory authority to assess attorneyâ€™s fees against a party.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420 (38) (Supp. 2006); Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).Â  An â€œaward of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs is a discretionary matter not to be overturned absent abuse by the trial court.â€ Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989). Â In determining whether attorneyâ€™s fees should be awarded, the court should consider the following factors:Â  the partyâ€™s ability to pay his/her own attorneyâ€™s fees; beneficial results obtained by the attorney; the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M, 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  In determining the reasonable amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to award, the family court should consider the nature, extent and difficulty of the services rendered, the time necessarily devoted to the case, counselâ€™s professional standing, the contingency of compensation, the beneficial results obtained, and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  The same considerations apply when awarding litigation expenses.Â  Patel, at 533, 599 S.E.2d at 123.Â  An award of attorneyâ€™s fees will be upheld as long as there is sufficient evidence in the record to support each factor.Â  Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 308, 486 S.E.2d 750, 760 (1997).Â  
 
Mother argues her case is on point with this courtâ€™s recent case of Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 318, 608 S.E.2d 147, 155 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  In Lacke, the mother had to bring an action to enforce the fatherâ€™s obligation from their divorce decree to help with their daughterâ€™s college expenses.Â  The family court denied the motherâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees, stating:Â  â€œI further find that both parties shall be responsible for their own attorney fees and costs associated with this action.â€Â  Lacke, 362 S.C. at 317, 608 S.E.2d at 155.Â  The Lacke court held that the â€œsuccinct and brief statement fail[ed] to provide any evidence the trial court considered the appropriate factors in reaching its decision.â€Â  Id.Â  The question of whether attorneyâ€™s fees should be awarded was remanded to the family court for consideration of the â€œappropriate factors.â€Â  Id. at 318, 302 S.E.2d at 155.Â  
 

	In the present case, the family courtâ€™s order stated: 
	
	
		Having concluded that both parties are at fault in this controversy, I conclude they should pay their own attorney fees.Â  The guardian ad litem worked hard on this case and rendered valuable service to [the child.]Â  He is a practicing attorney and his fees and costs of $10,569.56 plus $2,500.00 for his time in court (3 days) are reasonable.Â  The parties have each paid him $1,500.00 leaving a balance of $10,069.00.Â  This should be paid $7,500.00 by [Father] and $2,569.00 by [Mother.]Â 
		
	

Although the language from the underlying order is strikingly similar to the language found insufficient in Lacke, the instant case can be distinguished.Â  It is clear from the order that the family court in the present case considered both partiesâ€™ faults in bringing about the action and their respective abilities to pay when denying attorneyâ€™s fees and apportioning the guardian ad litem fees according to a percentage of their respective incomes.Â  The record reflects that Father had a monthly income of $6,500, while Mother had a monthly income of $3,375, solely from alimony and child support. Â Further, Father had to initiate this action after Mother interfered with this visitation rights, and the family court found in Fatherâ€™s favor on several of the issues.Â  Although Mother claims she obtained some beneficial results from the suit, she was found in contempt for interfering with Fatherâ€™s visitation and visitation was modified.Â 
 
Unlike the order in Lacke, we can glean from both the order and the record in the present case that the family court considered the appropriate factors in denying Mother attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, we find the court did not abuse its discretion.
II.  Modification of Visitation 
Mother contends the family court erred in modifying the visitation schedule.Â  Mother argues the modification was in error because: Â there was already a court-approved agreement regarding visitation filed less than two months before the present action was filed; the modified visitation was not in the childâ€™s best interest; the modification was not necessary or appropriate to resolve the partiesâ€™ visitation problems; and neither party requested such a modification in his/her pleadings.[2]Â  Mother argues that the only visitation problems raised at trial had to do with Fatherâ€™s failure to give notice of the weeks he chose to exercise visitation during the summer of 2003 and the partiesâ€™ conflicting interpretations of the appropriate location to transfer Son for visitation.Â  
 
â€œWhen awarding visitation, the controlling consideration is the welfare and best interest of the child.â€Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 12, 471 S.E.2d 154, 158 (1996).Â  Visitations orders are subject to continuing review and decisions regarding modification of visitation are also controlled by the best interest of the child.Â  King v. Gardner, 274 S.C. 493, 495, 265 S.E.2d 260, 262 (1980).Â  However, â€œ[w]hile visitation orders are subject to continuing review, a party may not receive relief not contemplated in the pleadings.â€Â  Aiken v. Aiken, 289 S.C. 370, 371, 345 S.E.2d 710, 711 (1986).Â  Decisions regarding visitation are left to the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Woodall, 322 S.C. at 12, 471 S.E.2d at 158.Â  
 
As a preliminary matter, it is clear that the family court had the authority to modify visitation because it was requested by both parties. Â Although Fatherâ€™s complaint focused primarily on modification of visitation so that Son could attend Fatherâ€™s wedding, Father also made the following general statement: Â â€œ[Father] brings this action for a modification of visitation, for Contempt, and for a determination of whether [Mother] is a fit and proper person to maintain custody of the partiesâ€™ minor child.â€Â  Mother also requested in her answer and counterclaim that the â€œamount of visitation to be exercised by [Father] should be reviewed.â€Â  Thus, because modification of visitation was generally requested by both parties in their pleadings, the family court had authority to modify visitation.Â  Aiken, 289 S.C. at 371, 345 S.E.2d at 711.Â  
 
However, while the family court had the authority to modify visitation, some of the modifications went beyond the complaints at issue in the instant case.Â  We address Motherâ€™s individual complaints regarding the modification of visitation separately. 
 
A.Â  Additional Mid-Week Visitation 
The visitation agreement incorporated into the partiesâ€™ final divorce decree stated that â€œOn the Tuesday prior to his scheduled visitation weekend, [Father] will be entitled to visitation on Tuesday from after school until 7:00 p.m.â€ Â The modified visitation order stated that on the Wednesday of the week following weekend visits, Father will pick Son up from school and return him to school the following morning.Â  The modification allowed Father a mid-week overnight visitation not previously agreed to by the parties.Â  
 
We find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s decision to grant an additional overnight visitation.Â  One of the major issues at trial concerned the partiesâ€™ confrontations when exchanging Son.Â  This modification allows Father his mid-week visitation and allows the parties to avoid contact with one another. Â Â 
B.Â  Summer Visitation 
Mother states in her brief that she agrees with the family courtâ€™s modification of summer visitation to outline the specific weeks that Father must exercise visitation.Â  However, she argues the court inadvertently failed to address how weekend visitation would be handled during the summer months.Â  Mother alleges that it is possible that Father would spend nearly sixty days with Son and Mother would only spend thirty days with Son if Father is still entitled to weekend visitation during the summer months.Â 
 
The original visitation agreement stated that â€œ[Father] will be entitled to 3 additional weeks of visitation during the summer months of 2003 and thereafter, he will be entitled to 4 weeks of visitation during the summer months, to be exercised in 2 increments of 2 weeks each.â€Â  The agreement provided that Father could pick the dates for two of the weeks, that Mother could pick the dates for two of the weeks, and that both parties were to inform each other of the dates selected by April 15th of every year.Â  The original visitation agreement did not address how normal weekend visitation by Father would be handled during the summer months.Â  
 
In the underlying order, the family court modified visitation to provide that Father would have the child from noon Sunday until noon the following Sunday the second full week of June; the first and third full weeks of July; and the first week of August each summer.Â  The modifications allowed for the same amount of visitation during the summer as was provided in the original visitation agreement, but the modified visitation order specified the dates so as to reduce the disagreements between Father and Mother.Â  The order did not address how Fatherâ€™s normal weekend visitation would be handled during the summer months.Â  Motherâ€™s motion for reconsideration argued that Father had â€œno basis to complain about summer visitation, as it was outside the period of time contemplated by the change of custody and visitation action and, furthermore, [Father] failed to give proper notice as required by the Decree as to the weeks he chose to exercise.â€Â Â  
 
It is apparent that the family court was attempting to alleviate confrontations and communication problems between Father and Mother by setting precise dates for Fatherâ€™s summer visitation.Â  Mother concedes on appeal that she approves of setting the dates.Â  Her only complaint is regarding how weekend visitation will be handled.Â  However, it does not appear that the issue of how to address weekend visitation during the summer months was ever determined in the original visitation agreement or ruled upon by the family court in the underlying case.Â  Thus, the issue is not preserved for appellate review and we may not address it.Â  Bryant, 342 S.C. at 171-72, 536 S.E.2d at 387; Joubert, 341 S.C. at 184, 534 S.E.2d at 5.Â  Although the manner in which weekend visitation is exercised during the summer may substantially impact the amount of time Mother would be able to spend with Son, Mother is still free to seek modification of the order in the family court for clarification of this issue.Â  Â Â 
C.Â  Holiday Visitation 
Mother argues in her brief that the family court erred in modifying the holiday visitation schedule because neither party complained about the holiday schedule and the modifications substantially impacted her familyâ€™s holiday traditions.Â  We agree.
 
The original visitation agreement provided that the parties would alternate the Spring Break/Easter and Thanksgiving holidays.Â  It also stated that: Â â€œ[Father] will be entitled to visitation during the Christmas holiday from 12:00 noon on the day after school is released for this holiday until 4:00 p.m. Christmas Eve, when [Son] shall be returned to [Motherâ€™s] home. Â [Mother] will then have continued possession until school resumes.â€Â  
 
The modified visitation order changed holiday visitation to grant Father visitation every Thanksgiving holiday.Â  The order also modified the Christmas holiday schedule by granting Father visitation on Christmas Eve from 4:00 p.m. until 7:00 p.m. and from 2:00 p.m. Christmas Day until December 31 at 2:00 p.m.Â  The modified visitation order did not address which parent would have Son during the Spring Break/Easter holiday.Â  
 
Fatherâ€™s complaint did not address the holiday visitation schedule, and thus it was inequitable for the family court to modify holiday visitation.Â  The modified visitation significantly reduces the holidays Mother spends with Son, and it allows a significant portion of all holidays to be spent with Father.Â  Furthermore, the modified visitation failed to address how visitation during other holidays was to be divided between the parties.Â  Accordingly, the family court erred in modifying holiday visitation.Â  Holiday visitation shall revert to the visitation as specified in the original visitation agreement.Â  
 
III.  Contempt
Mother contends the family court erred in finding her in contempt for denying Father visitation. Â We disagree.Â  
 
A finding of contempt rests within the sound discretion of the court.Â  Henderson v. Henderson, 298 S.C. 190, 197, 379 S.E.2d 125, 129 (1989).Â  â€œA trial courtâ€™s determination regarding contempt is subject to reversal where it is based on findings that are without evidentiary support or where there has been an abuse of discretion.â€ Â Henderson v. Puckett, 316 S.C. 171, 173, 447 S.E.2d 871, 872 (Ct. App. 1994). Â â€œEven though a party is found to have violated a court order, the question of whether or not to impose sanctions remains a matter for the courtâ€™s discretion.â€ Â Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 503, 597 S.E.2d 897, 900 (Ct. App. 2004). Â â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs either when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support.â€ Â Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003).
â€œThe power to punish for contempt is inherent in all courts and is essential to preservation of order in judicial proceedings.â€Â  In re Brown, 333 S.C. 414, 420, 511 S.E.2d 351, 355 (1998).Â  Contempt results from a partyâ€™s willful disobedience of a court order.Â  Smith v. Smith, 359 S.C. 393, 396, 597 S.E.2d 188, 189 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1350 (Supp. 2006) (â€œAn adult who wilfully violates, neglects, or refuses to obey or perform a lawful order of the court . . . may be proceeded against for contempt of court.â€). Â â€œA willful act is one which is â€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™â€ Â Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 557 S.E.2d 693, 705 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988)). Â â€œ[B]efore a court may find a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically reflect the contemptuous conduct.â€ Â Widman, 348 S.C. at 119, 557 S.E.2d at 705.
â€œIn a proceeding for contempt for violation of a court order, the moving party must show the existence of a court order and the facts establishing the respondentâ€™s noncompliance with the order.â€Â  Hawkins, 359 S.C. at 501, 597 S.E.2d at 899.Â  â€œOnce the moving party has made out a prima facie case, the burden then shifts to the respondent to establish his or her defense and inability to comply with the order.â€Â  Widman, 348 S.C. at 120, 557 S.E.2d at 705.Â  Furthermore, it is generally recognized that â€œwhere a contemnor is unable, without fault on his part, to obey an order of the court, he is not to be held in contempt.â€Â  Hicks v. Hicks, 280 S.C. 378, 381, 312 S.E.2d 598, 599 (1984). 
 
The original visitation agreement stated that â€œ[Fatherâ€™s] visitation will consist of every other weekend, from after school on Friday until Monday morning, when he will return [the child] directly to school.â€Â  The agreement further provided that:Â  â€œIn the event school is not in session, [Father] will pick up [the child] at the home at noon on Friday and will return him to his home on Monday at noon.â€Â  
 
Mother interpreted the language that Father would have Son â€œfrom after school,â€ to mean that Father should pick up Son from Motherâ€™s house and not pick up Son from school.Â  Thus, she believed that there was no interference with Fatherâ€™s visitation the times she picked Son up from school and took him home, despite the fact that Father and Bobbie were there to pick him up for weekend visitation.Â  The family court noted that the partiesâ€™ prior visitation practice and the spirit of the original visitation agreement meant that Father would pick Son up at school for weekend visitation.Â  The court held Mother in contempt for interfering with Fatherâ€™s visitation.Â Â  
 
Mother argues on appeal that the only way she could adequately supervise the pick-up of Son for visitation was to have the exchange at her home.Â  She now argues that the agreement does not allow pick-ups from school, and she has made Fatherâ€™s attempt to pick the child up at school very difficult.Â  We find a clear reading of the agreement means that Father should pick-up Son at school on days when school is in session.Â  Otherwise, there would be no need for arrangements for when school is not in session.Â  Furthermore, since the inception of the agreement, pick-ups have been done at the school.Â  By preventing Father from doing so, Mother has interfered with Fatherâ€™s visitation with Son.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err in finding Mother in contempt for denying Father visitation.Â  
 
CONCLUSION
We affirm the family courtâ€™s finding that Mother should not be awarded attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We also affirm the family courtâ€™s finding that Mother be held in contempt for interfering with Fatherâ€™s visitation.Â  However, we reverse the family courtâ€™s modifications of visitation concerning holiday visitation, and the original visitation agreement concerning holiday visitation shall be reinstated.Â  The modifications made concerning after school pick-up and mid-week visitation are affirmed.Â  For the reasons stated herein, the family courtâ€™s decision is 
 
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART.Â  

HUFF, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Mother also contends the family court erred in denying her Motion to Reconsider and in denying her request for a hearing on the motion.Â  However, this argument is merely conclusory and deals only with the issue of modification of visitation.Â  Therefore, it will be treated as raising the same issues discussed in this section.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        James W. Williams, Appellant,
          
                  
        v.
        Otis David Gould, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Colleton County
Benjamin Goldberg, Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-316
  Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 14,
  2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Ronnie L. Crosby, of Hampton, for Appellant.
        James D. Mosteller, III, of Barnwell and Robert J. Harte, of
          Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this boundary dispute, James W. Williams appeals the special refereeâ€™s
  determination that Williams and Otis David Gould acquiesced to the boundary
  between their respective properties.Â  Williams argues on appeal that a dispute
  or uncertainty as to the actual boundary line is required to support a finding
  of acquiescence.Â  Because there is no such requirement under South Carolina
  law, we affirm.
I.
In
  1961, Raymond M. Gatch granted to G.M. Gould (Father) certain real property
  fronting the western bank of the Edisto River.Â  Father built a cabin on the
  eastern portion of this property.Â  In 1976, Father deeded the western portion
  to Dolphus and Betty G. Bridges.Â  Father retained the eastern portion (the
  Gould Property) until 1990, when he granted it to his son, Otis David Gould.Â  
In
  1970, Dorothy Hadley received the property directly south of the Gould
  Property.Â  In 1974, she deeded this tract to a church for which she acted as
  trustee.Â  In 1993, James Williams obtained this property and subdivided it into
  three tracts.[1]Â 
  Tract C (the Williams Property), containing 2.32 acres, now lies south of the
  Gould Property.[2]Â  
Sometime
  in the 1970s, Hadleyâ€™s husband dug a canal on the northern portion of the
  Williams Property.Â  Several witnesses later testified the canal had been dug in
  the early 1970s, but the record contains a 1976 plat with only a proposed
  canal.Â  The 1976 plat shows the northern bank of the proposed canal as the
  border between the Williams and Gould Properties.[3]Â  
After the canal was finished, Father and Gould proceeded as if it
  marked the boundary between the Williams and Gould Properties.Â  For instance,
  Father and Gould built a fish cleaning table near the canal and installed a
  septic tank in this area. Â Further, the cabin which Father and Gould used when
  they visited the property encroached into the area that is now in dispute.Â  Finally,
  Gould built a river wall up to the edge of the canal in 1992 or 1993.Â  Despite
  Father and Gouldâ€™s continued use of the area in question, Williamsâ€™
  predecessors-in-interest never complained.[4]
In
  1999, Williams filed an action against Gould claiming he owned property north
  of the canal upon which he asserted Gould had trespassed.Â  Gould denied these
  allegations and claimed his and Williamsâ€™ predecessors in title acquiesced to
  the northern bank of the canal as the border between the Gould and Williams
  Properties.Â  The circuit court held a bench trial, ruled in favor of Williams,
  and found no evidence supported Gouldâ€™s acquiescence defense.Â  In Williams
    v. Gould, Op. No. 2003-UP-153 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Feb. 20, 2003), this
  court held the circuit court committed an error of law in ruling no evidence of
  acquiescence existed.Â  Accordingly, we remanded to the circuit court â€œfor
  reconsideration of the acquiescence of title question in light of this
  opinion.â€Â  
On
  remand, the case was heard by a special referee.Â  At trial, Buddy Gatch
  testified he witnessed Bill Hadley dig the canal between the Gould and Williams
  Properties.Â  Gatch explained Hadley surveyed his northern boundary â€œto find out
  where his line went so he would know where to start his canal, I would assume.â€
  Â According to Gatch, the neighbors and Hadley agreed where to place the line.Â 
  Hadley thus placed a marker on a spot six or eight feet from the edge of the
  canal.Â  The referee found Gould met his burden of proving boundary by
  acquiescence.Â  After the referee denied Williamsâ€™ reconsideration motion, this
  appeal followed.Â  
II.
â€œA
  boundary dispute, if it encompasses an issue of title, is an action at law.â€Â  Knox
    v. Bogan, 322 S.C. 64, 66, 472 S.E.2d 43, 45 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  In an
  action at law, tried without a jury, the judgeâ€™s factual findings will not be
  disturbed unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports them.Â  Bodiford
    v. Spanish Oak Farms, Inc., 317 S.C. 539, 544, 455 S.E.2d 194,
  197 (Ct. App. 1995).
III.
 Williams
  contends the referee committed an error of law in finding a boundary by
  acquiescence because uncertainty or dispute as to the actual boundary line is
  required to support such a finding.Â  We disagree.Â  
The common law doctrine of acquiescence occurs when adjacent
  landowners mutually recognize and accept a clear line as the boundary between
  their properties for a long period of time.Â  See 9 Powell on
    Real Property Â§ 68.05(2) (2000); see
      also Croft v. Sanders, 283 S.C. 507, 509, 323 S.E.2d 791, 792 (Ct. App. 1984) (â€œA
  boundary line may be determined by mutual recognition of and acquiescence in a
  particular line.â€)Â  â€œIt is well established that if landowners occupy their
  respective premises up to a certain line which they mutually recognize and
  acquiesce in for a long period of time . . . they are precluded from claiming
  that the boundary line thus recognized and acquiesced in is not the true one.â€ Â Klapman v. Hook, 206 S.C. 51, 57, 32 S.E.2d 882, 884
  (1945).Â  When a boundary line is
  acquiesced to by adjoining landowners, the acquiescence â€œis binding on the
  parties and their successors in interest.â€Â  12 Am. Jur. 2d Boundaries Â§
  83 (1997).
The essence of Williamsâ€™ appeal is the claim that the doctrine of
  acquiescence requires a showing of a dispute or uncertainty as to the true
  property line.Â  The law, however, imposes no such requirement.Â  Evidence of a
  dispute or uncertainty is not required in a case, such as this one, in which
  acquiescence is established by the actions of adjoining landowners occupying
  their respective properties up to a certain line over a long period of time.[5]Â  In Knox v. Bogan, 322 S.C.
  64, 73, 472 S.E.2d 43, 49 (Ct. App. 1996), this court explained:

  [W]here, as here, there has been a recognition by adjoining
    property owners of a clearly defined line for a long period of time, there is
    no requirement under South Carolina law that the plaintiff show an active
    dispute or uncertainty as to the true line and a settlement of that dispute or
    uncertainty by the parties as an element of proof of title by acquiescence.

Based on this precedent, we hold the referee did not commit an
  error of law in finding the parties acquiesced to the northern edge of the
  canal as the boundary between the Gould and Williams Properties.Â  
We find Williamsâ€™ remaining arguments manifestly without merit.Â  Accordingly, we dispose of
  them pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR.Â  
IV.
Evidence
  supports the refereeâ€™s finding that Gould established the affirmative defense
  of acquiescence of title.Â  The judgment of the special referee is
AFFIRMED.

HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] Â Although this property was actually deeded to
  Williams Farms Partnerships, Gould failed to object to Williams proceeding as
  the real party in interest.Â  
[2] Â Later, Williams further subdivided Tract C.Â  
[3] Â Â Â However, Gene Whetsell, a registered land surveyor, testified 35 to
  40 feet of riverfront property to the north of the canal belonged to the Williams Property.Â  Whetsell based
  his conclusion on recorded deeds and plats in both Williamsâ€™ and Gouldâ€™s chain
  of title.Â  
[4]  The only evidence to the contrary is the
  testimony of Roy Walker, who owned the Williams Property in 1982.Â  He attempted
  to access the cabin because it was partially within the property description in
  his deed.Â  He testified â€œsomebody put me out of itâ€ because â€œit was not my
  building.â€Â  
[5]  We note that even if a dispute or uncertainty were required, that
  requirement is met here under our deferential scope of review.Â  Portions of
  Gouldâ€™s testimony reflect some uncertainty about the true boundary line.Â  In
  addition, both Gatchâ€™s testimony and the 1976 plat support inferences that
  Hadley did not know where the true boundary line was located.Â

Appeal From Charleston County
  Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-317
Heard June 5, 2007 â€“ Filed June 14, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Brian E. Peltier, of Charleston, for
          Appellant.
        Sandra J. Senn and Robin L. Jackson, of Charleston, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Brian
  Peltier appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting Dr. Jobe Mettsâ€™ motion to
  dismiss because Peltier failed to comply with the two-year statute of
  limitations under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  See S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 15-78-110 (2005).Â  We affirm. 
On
  September 25, 2002, Dr. Metts performed a lithotripsy procedure on Peltier.Â  At
  the time, Dr. Metts worked at a satellite urology clinic for the Medical
  University of South Carolina (â€œMUSCâ€).Â  On September 25, 2005, Peltier brought
  this action against Dr. Metts, among others, alleging Dr. Metts negligently
  performed the lithotripsy procedure.Â  Dr. Metts moved the circuit court to
  dismiss Peltierâ€™s action against him because it exceeded the two-year statute
  of limitations under the Tort Claims Act.Â  The circuit court agreed, and
  dismissed Peltierâ€™s action.Â  Peltier appeals. 
On
  appeal, Peltier argues the circuit court erred in dismissing his action for
  failing to file and serve it within the applicable statute of limitations.Â 
  Peltier also asserts the circuit court erred in refusing to allow him to
  proceed to discovery.Â  While we recognize Peltierâ€™s position, the record
  establishes to the exacting summary judgment standard that Dr. Metts worked for
  MUSC, a government entity under the Tort Claims Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  15-78-30(d) (2005); Tatum v. Med. Univ. of S.C., 346 S.C. 194, 199, 552
  S.E.2d 18, 21 (2001) (â€œMUSC is a governmental agency subject to the provisions
  of the Tort Claims Act.â€).Â  Accordingly, absent a verified claimâ€”which Peltier
  did not fileâ€”Peltier had two years to bring his action against MUSC.Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 15-78-110; see also Joubert v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 341
  S.C. 176, 186, 534 S.E.2d 1, 6 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Because Peltier exceeded this
  two year limitation, his action is time-barred.[1]Â 
  Therefore, the circuit court did not err. 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., KITTREDGE, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.
  

[1]Â  Because we decide this case based on the applicable statute
  of limitations, we decline to address Peltierâ€™s remaining assignments of error.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598,
  613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (noting that an appellate court need not
  address the remaining issues when disposition of a prior issue is dispositive).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Michael Kelley, Appellant,
        v.
        Debra Kelley, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
C. David Sawyer, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-324
  Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 15,
  2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Michael Kelley, of Aiken, pro se Appellant.Â  
        John L. Creson, of Augusta, for Respondent.
        Paige Weeks Johnson, of Aiken, Guardian Ad Litem.Â  
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Michael
  Kelley filed this divorce action against Debra Kelley. Â The family court
  awarded custody of the partiesâ€™ two minor children to wife. Â Husband appeals.Â 
  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
The parties were married when both were
  residents of California. Â They had two sons, Sean (12) and Joshua (11).Â  The
  parties remained in California until husbandâ€™s business failed, and the parties
  declared bankruptcy. Â The parties decided to move to Aiken, South Carolina,
  where husband intended to start a business with his father.Â  In June 2001,
  husband and the children left California for Aiken.Â  Wife remained behind to
  assist her family, intending to follow in a few weeks. Â During several
  telephone calls prior to wifeâ€™s move, husband dissuaded her from joining them because
  the house he was renovating for the family was not complete.Â  Husband and
  children lived with husbandâ€™s parents during the renovation. Â Wife testified
  that despite husbandâ€™s continued dissuasion, she traveled to Aiken in August.Â 
  While in Aiken, husband refused to move into an apartment while the house was being
  completed, stalled wife when she attempted to get a South Carolina driverâ€™s
  license, was reluctant to add her to their automobile insurance, and limited
  her access to the partiesâ€™ vehicle.Â  Husband told the wife it was â€œtoo crampedâ€
  at his parentsâ€™ home, and wife returned to California to await completion of
  the house.Â  During the next few months, husband continually discouraged wife
  from returning.Â  Again, despite his attitude, she arrived in Aiken in early
  December, and the parties moved into the marital home.Â  
In February 2002, wife returned to California for gastric bypass
  surgery, which would have been prohibitively expensive in Aiken due to the
  partiesâ€™ insurance coverage.Â  Without her knowledge, husband filed an action
  for separate support and maintenance seeking, inter alia, custody of the
  children.Â  A week before wife was scheduled to return to Aiken, husband called
  and ordered her to live with his parents upon her return to Aiken.Â  Husband
  threatened to limit her visitation with the children to his parentsâ€™ home
  during the hours after school until he returned home from work.Â  Wife sought
  advice of counsel in California and learned of the pending action for divorce
  in South Carolina.Â  Wife filed for divorce in California.Â  The children
  remained in Aiken with husband.Â  
Numerous school witnesses testified wife remained very involved
  with the children, whereas husband was very controlling and had difficulties
  with anger management.Â  For instance, the school was piloting an â€œall studentsâ€
  breakfast program.Â  Husband did not want the children to participate and
  brought them to school late.Â  The school pursued the matter, as the children
  were missing instruction time in addition to breakfast.Â  Husband consented to
  adhering to the time, but refused to allow them to eat with the rest of the
  class.Â  Husband forbade the children from attending field trips, argued with a
  teacher about providing a particular type of composition book, required notice
  before the children could see the school nurse, omitted virtually all required
  personal information during registration, and sent the children to school
  without proper clothing.Â  When the children brought fundraising material home
  from school, the husband â€œwadded it up and sent it backâ€ saying â€œhe sent his
  children to school to learn and not to raise money for the school.â€Â  Seanâ€™s
  third-grade teacher explained: Â â€œIt seemed like everything was an issue with
  him.Â  That was negative and hard to fit and hard to do.Â  Just I had a really
  hard time with him.â€Â  She described a class science project of planting seeds.Â 
  Sean was not permitted to water his seeds with school water, but had to bring
  water from home.Â  Husband also forbade the school from teaching his children
  that drugs and guns were bad.Â  Seanâ€™s teacher felt that the communication with husband
  was so poor, she would not notify him of anything for fear Sean would be
  severely punished.Â  In a similar vein, wifeâ€™s mother testified that husband was
  quick to anger and spanked the children with â€œforce [that] was extremely hard.â€ 
Prior
  to the move to Aiken, wife was the primary caretaker. Â While in California after the family move, wife communicated with the principal, teachers, and Sean
  by letters and e-mail.Â  When in Aiken, wife and her mother visited the school.Â 
  She notified Joshuaâ€™s teacher about his birthday and explained that, although
  she did not have access to a vehicle, she wanted to provide cupcakes for the
  class.Â  
The
  family court in Aiken held a temporary hearing in June 2002, as a result of
  which it awarded husband temporary custody and appointed a guardian ad litem.Â  Three
  additional hearings were held over the course of the summer of 2003, and the
  guardian ad litem submitted her report.Â  The guardian testified she interviewed
  over twenty individuals in preparing her report and testimony.Â  Her concerns
  about husband related to his temper, controlling behavior, some indications of
  depression, and the overall effects upon his ability to parent.Â  She was also
  concerned about husbandâ€™s alleged cruelty to animals, particularly in view of
  the fact the cruelty was committed in the presence of the children.Â  She
  concluded that it was in the best interest of Joshua and Sean to live with wife
  in California.Â  
Following the three hearings during the summer of 2003 and after
  the submission of the guardianâ€™s report, the court issued a supplemental
  temporary order transferring custody of the children to wife and limiting husbandâ€™s
  visitation.Â  The final hearing was held in November 2003, after which the court
  took the matter under advisement due to the voluminous record.Â  In its final
  order, issued on May 25, 2004, the court granted the parties a divorce and
  awarded custody of the children to wife.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family courtÂ This broad
  scope of review, however, does not relieve the appellant of the burden of
  convincing us that the family court committed
  error.Â  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892
  (1979). Â Nor are we required to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw
  and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility
  and assign comparative weight to their testimonies.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson,
  276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

Husband argues the
  family court violated his rights to due process by failing to issue the final
  order within thirty days.Â  We disagree.
Rule 26(c), SCRFC
The South Carolina Rules
  of Family Court provide:Â  â€œExcept under exceptional circumstances, an order in
  a domestic relations case shall be issued as soon as possible after the
  hearing, but not later than 30 days thereafter.â€Â  Rule 26(c), SCRFC.Â  The
  family court did not issue an order until more than six months after the conclusion
  of the hearing in this case. Â We can understand husbandâ€™s angst because of the
  delay in the final order.Â  However, this case was more difficult than the
  ordinary case, requiring four days of testimony.Â  The court informed the
  parties at the conclusion of the final day of hearings that due to the volume
  of evidence and the necessity of the court reviewing it carefully it was
  unlikely that a final order would comply with the mandate of Rule 26(c).Â  Additionally,
  the final order itself consists of fourteen pages, and was obviously carefully
  crafted, particularly as it relates to husbandâ€™s visitation privileges.Â  The delay
  in filing and serving the final order resulted in little or no prejudice to
  husband.Â  See Matter of Price, 277 S.C. 169, 170, 284 S.E.2d 356,
  356 (1981) (finding denial of motion to dismiss for failure to comply with
  Rules of Family Court prescribing maximum forty day period between filing of
  petition against minor and adjudicatory hearing not reversible where no
  material prejudice).
Custody
Husband also argues
  the family court erred in granting custody of the children to wife.[2]Â 
  We disagree.
 In reviewing a
  family court order awarding custody, â€œ[w]e are â€˜guided by several principles.â€™â€Â  Davis v. Davis, 356 S.C. 132, 135, 588 S.E.2d 102, 103 (2003).Â 
  â€œFirst, an
  appellate court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence.Id.Â Second, the appellate court need not disregard the family
  courtâ€™s findings or ignore the fact the family court judge observed the
  witnesses and was in a better position to judge their credibility. Â â€œThis
  degree of deference is â€˜especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of children.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Dixon v. Dixon,
  336 S.C. 260, 262-63, 519 S.E.2d 357, 358-59 (Ct. App. 1999)). Â â€œThird, â€˜[t]he welfare of the child and what is in his/her best interest is the primary, paramount and controlling consideration of the court in all child custody controversies.â€™â€Â  Id. at 135, 588 S.E.2d
  at 103-104 (quoting Cook v. Cobb, 271 S.C. 136, 140, 245 S.E.2d 612, 614
  (1978)).
The family court
  temporarily awarded custody to wife after the first three days of testimony on
  May 28, 2003, July 28, 2003, and August 5, 2003. Â The court expressed concern
  that school was about to begin, and the children needed stability for the
  upcoming year. Â At that time, most of the partiesâ€™ witnesses had testified,
  including a counselor, numerous teachers and school officials, and husband.Â  The
  guardian had submitted a detailed report and actively participated in the
  hearings. Â The only remaining witnesses were the guardian and wife. Â The
  guardianâ€™s initial report favored custody with wife.Â  The school officials and
  guardian indicated husband suffered from anger and control issues, and the
  court temporarily suspended husbandâ€™s visitation. Â The guardian testified the
  final day, stating the children seemed to be faring well in California, and her
  opinion had not changed. 
The court stated it
  had â€œnever heard teachers and school officials who were as emphatic as
  witnesses.â€Â  The court considered the many confrontations between husband and
  school personnel in which husband expressed dissatisfaction with school policy
  involving the children. Â The court also noted that even after two years, the
  children had few friends in Aiken.Â  Finally, the court considered the
  guardianâ€™s experience, qualifications, and conclusions.Â  The court ordered
  custody to remain with wife in California, and required husband to complete
  anger management and parenting skills classes prior to receiving unsupervised
  visitation.Â  After review of the record, we find no error.Â  The courtâ€™s
  paramount concern in determining custody issues is to protect the best interest
  of the children.Â  The preponderance of the evidence demonstrates that it is in
  the childrenâ€™s best interest to be with wife.
Guardian ad litem Fees
Husband
  finally argues the guardian failed to be impartial and submitted exorbitant
  fees.Â  We find no reversible error. 
The guardianâ€™s
  report listed over twenty individuals she had interviewed and her supplemental
  report included follow-up with the childrenâ€™s California counselor.Â  One of the
  primary functions of a guardian, in a case of this type, is to make
  recommendations to the court as to custody and other issues.Â  Just because a
  guardian comes down on the side of one party or the other does not, in and of
  itself, indicate a lack of impartiality.Â  As an indication of the guardianâ€™s
  impartiality, she recommended a consultant to perform testing who thereafter
  disagreed with her by indicating he thought custody should remain with
  husband.Â  The guardian concluded both parents loved the children and were able
  to meet their basic physical needs.Â  We find no evidence the guardian failed to
  exercise independent, impartial judgment. 
We likewise find
  support in the record justifying the guardianâ€™s fees.Â  An award of guardian
  fees is within the discretion of the family court.Â  Shirley v. Shirley, 342
  S.C. 324, 341, 536 S.E.2d 427, 436 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The court ordered each
  party to pay one-half of the guardianâ€™s total fees of $7,071.36.Â  We find the
  guardian expended a substantial amount of time in interviewing witnesses and
  preparing for and participating in the hearings. Â The fees are reasonable considering the complexities
  of the case.Â  Accordingly, we find no error.
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] We consolidate several of husbandâ€™s issues on appeal.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Allegiant, a
          division of Telerent Leasing, Respondent,
        v.
        Emerald Inns,
          Inc., d/b/a Inn on the Square of Greenwood, C. Allan Peterson, and S. Craig
          White, Defendants,
        Of Whom S. Craig White is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
  Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr, Circuit Court
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-325
  Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed June 15,
  2007

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Leonard R. Jordan, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Robert Wallis Cone, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â S.
  Craig White appeals from the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment awarding
  Allegiant $69,897.26 against him as damages for a breached lease of which White
  was a guarantor.Â  We reverse and remand. [1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On January 14, 2003, White and C. Allan
  Peterson, doing business as Emerald Inns, Inc, (Defendants) entered into an
  agreement to lease from Allegiant furnishings and equipment for use in the
  operation of a hotel.Â  The cash sale price of the goods leased was $67,698.17.Â 
  Emerald Inns, White, and Peterson agreed to make lease payments in the amount
  of $1,461.81 per month plus applicable sales tax for 60 months, beginning on
  June 1, 2003.Â  The Defendants made the last payment on April 27, 2004.Â  
On July 27, 2004, Allegiant brought this
  action for breach of the lease seeking immediate and permanent possession of
  the leased good together with any deficiency remaining after a commercially
  reasonable sale of the goods with interest thereon, judgment against Emerald
  Inns, White, and Peterson for value of the goods, including depreciation and
  pre-judgment interest, and for â€œactual, consequential, and punitive damagesâ€
  arising out of the breach of the lease agreement.Â  Allegiant also sought
  damages against Emerald Inns and Peterson for breach of a carpet purchase
  agreement.Â  White was not a guarantor under that agreement.Â  White answered the
  complaint denying most of the allegations, while Peterson was in default.
The trial court granted Allegiant summary judgment as to liability
  as to the lease agreement against all of the defendants and on the carpet
  agreement against Emerald Inns and Peterson.Â  However it held the issue of
  damages for both agreements in abeyance pending recovery and disposition of the
  goods that were the subject of the lease agreement.Â  Allegiant took inventory
  of the goods remaining at the hotel and sold them to the new owner of the hotel
  for $5000.00.Â  
Allegiant
  subsequently filed a supplemental motion for summary judgment seeking
  acceleration of all of the payments due under the lease reduced by the amount
  received from the sale of the remaining goods, as well as attorneyâ€™s fees and
  costs.Â  White filed an affidavit asserting the indebtedness was not simply a
  total of all of the rent payments past due and to be become due in the future,
  but rather the amounts of unpaid rent due at the date of the default plus the
  present value of the remaining payments.Â  
The trial court found the language of the lease allowing Allegiant
  a variety of remedies available â€œunder this agreement or otherwise . . .â€
  allowed it to claim as damages the aggregate of all of the payments that would
  have become due under the lease.Â  In addition, the trial court found that since
  White submitted his affidavit disputing damages less than five days prior to
  the hearing, his request for a damages hearing was not timely and was therefore
  denied.Â  The court awarded Allegiant judgment in the amount of $66,320.60
  against Emerald Inns, White, and Peterson as well as $3200.00 in attorneyâ€™s
  fees and $376.66 in costs for a total of $66,320.60.Â  The court also added
  $376.66 in costs to the judgment awarded under the carpet agreement for a total
  judgment against Emerald Inns and Peterson of $30,861.94.Â  The court
  subsequently denied Whiteâ€™s motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  This appeal
  followed.Â  
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Request for
  damages hearing
White argues the trial court erred in holding he was obligated to
  request a damages hearing and that, by failing to request such a hearing, he
  waived the right to the hearing.Â  We agree.Â  
The burden for proving damages for breach of contract rests on the
  plaintiff.Â  Depositions And . . . Inc. v. Campbell, 305 S.C. 173, 175, 406
  S.E.2d 390, 391 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  Furthermore, the party seeking summary
  judgment has the burden of clearly establishing the absence of a genuine issue
  of material fact.Â  McCall v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 359 S.C.
  372, 376, 597 S.E.2d 181, 183 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP, provides the
  party opposing summary judgment may serve affidavits â€œnot later than two days before the hearing.â€ Â (Emphasis added).
White executed his affidavit opposing summary judgment on February
  17, 2004.Â  The hearing was held on February 21, 2006.Â  Thus, Whiteâ€™s affidavit
  was timely under Rule 56(c).Â  We find no provision in the South Carolina Rules
  of Civil Procedure to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling that a defendant is
  barred from receiving a hearing on damages because he failed to file his
  affidavit more than five days before the hearing.Â  According, we hold
  the trial court erred in finding White was not entitled to challenge
  Allegiantâ€™s claimed damages.Â  
II.Â  Amount of
  damages
White argues the trial court erred in its calculation of damages.Â 
  We agree.
The Remedies section of the lease agreement provides:Â  â€œIf an
  event of default occurs, Lessor is entitled to exercise in any order any one or
  more of the following remedies and the exercise of any one or more of such
  remedies shall not preclude Lessor from any other remedies available to Lessor
  under this Agreement or otherwise: . . . .â€Â  The section then lists a number of
  remedies.Â  Emphasizing the phrase, â€œunder this agreement or otherwise: . . . ,â€
  the trial court found â€œunder the clear terms of this statement, [Allegiant] as
  Lessor, may seek relief through a variety of remedies, including those
  available under statutory and common law.â€Â  
Although the lease agreement allowed Allegiant a wide variety of
  remedies, the damages awarded must still be within those allowed by contract
  law.Â  â€œIn a breach of contract action, damages serve to place the nonbreaching
  party in the position he would have enjoyed had the contract been performed.â€Â  South Carolina Fed. Sav. Bank v. Thornton-Crosby Dev. Co., 303 S.C. 74, 77,
  399 S.E.2d 8, 10 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  The measure of damages is â€œthe loss actually
  suffered by the contractee as the result of the breach.â€ Â Collins Holding
    Co. v. Landrum, 360 S.C. 346, 350, 601 S.E.2d 332, 333-34 (2004). 

  Damages will be computed as of the date fixed for performance,
    because a court does not treat the contract as though it contained a promise to
    render performance as of the date of the repudiation.Â  Thus the damages for the
    repudiation of a contract are to be computed as of the date when performance is
    due, and not as of the date of the prior repudiation.Â  This amount must be
    reduced to its present value.Â  Judgment should be rendered for all accrued
    payments plus interest, plus the present value of all unaccrued payments the
    plaintiff would have received if the contract had been performed. Â 

22 Am.Jur.2d Damages Â§63 (2003).Â  
We hold
  the trial court erred in granting Allegiant the aggregate of all payments past
  due and due in the future.Â  The correct measure of damages would include the balance
  due at the time of the default plus the present value of all unaccrued payments
  at the time of the default.Â  Accordingly, we remand the case to the trial court
  for a damages hearing.Â Â  Â 
III. Â Â Â  Award of
  costs
White argues the trial court erred in adding costs of $376.66 to
  both of Allegiantâ€™s judgments.Â  
Initially
  Allegiant contends this issue is not preserved because the parties agreed to
  the apportionment of attorneyâ€™s fees and White did not object to the award of
  costs and did not seek apportionment of costs between the two judgments. Â In
  our review of the record, we find the partiesâ€™ agreement involved only the
  apportionment of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In his motion to alter or amend the
  judgment, White objected to the award of costs, sufficiently raising the issue
  to the trial court and preserving it for our review.Â  See Godfrey v.
    Heller, 311 S.C. 516, 520, 429 S.E.2d 859, 862 (Ct. App. 1993) (stating
  that where an appellant learns for the first time when the appellant receives
  the order that the respondent would be granted certain relief, the appellant
  must move, pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment to
  preserve the issue).Â Â  
White
  contends the issue of costs was not raised at the hearing.Â  However, in its
  complaint Allegiant requested costs and its attorney stated in his affidavit
  that Allegiant had incurred costs in the amount of $376.66.Â  Therefore, the
  issue of costs was properly before the trial court.Â  However, we agree with
  Allegiant that the trial court erred in adding an award of costs of $376.66 to
  both the judgment on the lease agreement and the judgment on the carpet
  agreement.Â  The trial court found Allegiant had incurred costs of $376.66 and
  that this amount was reasonable.Â  By adding this amount to both judgments, the
  trial court in fact awarded Allegiant costs in the amount $753.32.Â  Thus, we
  remand the issue of costs to the trial court.Â  
CONCLUSION
The order of the trial court is reversed
  and the issues of the amount of damages and the awarding of costs are
  remanded.Â  
REVERSED
  and REMANDED.
HUFF,
  BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ. concur.Â 
  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
