THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED UPON AS PRECEDENT
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control, Respondent,
        v.
        Shane Gould, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Administrative Law Court
  Ralph King Anderson, III, Administrative
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-326
  Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed June 18,
  2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        C.C. Harness, III, of Mount Pleasant, for Appellant.
        Van Whitehead, of North Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Shane Gould appeals the administrative
  law judgeâ€™s (ALJ) order requiring relocation of a covered pierhead in a permit
  revocation action initiated by the South Carolina Department of Health and
  Environmental Control (DHEC).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Gould
  resides and owns a house at 29 Sea Olive Road on Hilton Head Island, adjacent
  to Point Comfort Creek. Â He applied for a dock permit in November 2001, which
  was granted on December 19, 2001. Â Based on Gouldâ€™s permit application, all
  parts of the dock were to be built at least twenty feet inside his extended
  property line.Â  Gould began building the dock in 2003.Â  
Contemporaneously
  with construction of the dock, Margaret Maxwell, Gouldâ€™s neighbor, complained
  that the dock crossed the extended property line separating her property from
  Gouldâ€™s.Â  Indeed, as completed, the dockâ€™s roofed pierhead and a floating dock
  crossed the extended property line separating the properties.Â  Maxwell
  continued to complain to the Office of Ocean and Resource Management (OCRM) and
  government officials about the dockâ€™s placement, the resulting obstruction of
  her view, and her access to the creek. Â 
Based
  upon her complaints, OCRM reviewed the permit and discovered the inaccuracy of
  the submitted application.Â  OCRM instituted an enforcement action in 2004, but
  instead proceeded with this revocation action.[1]Â 
  In the action, OCRM sought to revoke Gouldâ€™s permit based on the material
  inaccuracy of the drawings, as well as to require him to submit a new permit
  application with new drawings.Â  However, OCRM did not seek to require Gould to
  alter the dock in the interim.Â  
During
  the pendency of this action, Gould agreed to move his floating dock to the
  other side of the pierhead onto his side of the extended property line.Â  However,
  he did not agree to move the roofed pierhead, which remained across the line
  separating his property from Maxwellâ€™s.
The ALJ
  found that after Gouldâ€™s floating dock was moved, the only material harm would
  be the impact on Maxwellâ€™s view. Â Accordingly, the ALJ found this matter could
  be solved without revoking the existing permit and requiring a new application.Â 
  Thus, the ALJ ordered modification of the existing permit such that (1) the
  gangway and float be moved to the opposite side of the pierhead, and (2) any
  portion of the pierhead roof lying over the extended property lines be removed.Â 
  He further required that the new location of the floating dock be approved by
  OCRM consistent with his order, and any partial removal of the roofing be
  approved by OCRM.Â  Gould Appeals.Â  DHEC did not file a brief.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  appellate court may reverse or modify an administrative decision if such
  decision is affected by errors of law, characterized by an abuse of discretion,
  or clearly erroneous in view of the substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Professional
    Samplers, Inc. v. South Carolina Employment Sec. Comâ€™n, 334 S.C. 392, 395,
  513 S.E.2d 374, 376 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œSubstantial evidenceâ€ is not a mere
  scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the
  case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow
  reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in
  order to justify its action.Â  Hull v. Spartanburg Co. Assessor, 372
  S.C. 420, 641 S.E.2d 909, 911 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  The appellate court may not
  substitute its judgment for that of an agency as to the weight of evidence on
  questions of fact.Â  Grant v. South Carolina Coastal Council, 319 S.C.
  348, 353, 461 S.E.2d 388, 391 (1995).Â  
LAW / ANALYSIS
I.  Legal Authority to Order
  Removal of the Pierhead-Roof
Gould argues that
  the ALJ lacked legal authority to order the removal of the portion of the
  pierhead roof that crosses the extended property lines. Â Specifically, he
  argues because the roof removal was not agreed to by the parties, and because
  OCRM did not request this relief or make any general prayer for relief, there
  is no basis for that portion of the order. Â We
  disagree.Â  
This
  issue is not preserved for appellate review. Â During examination of the trialâ€™s
  first witness, the ALJ asked the parties: 

  In
    light of the tenure that this case comes before me, do I have the authority to
    if I find in (sic) fitting with the facts to amend the permit and to allow the
    permit of the dock crossing the extended property line within my authority to
    modify?Â  

Counsel for OCRM answered in the
  affirmative and Gould made no response.Â  The ALJ further noted â€œWell, I just
  wanted to ask that to let both parties know what I may be thinking about and so
  you can ask your questions accordingly.â€Â  Again, Gould did not object or
  respond.Â  At the conclusion of the hearing, the ALJ stated that â€œa proper
  resolution to this case would be to modify the permit and require that . . .
  that no dock or anything else extend beyond the extended property line from that
  point on,â€ notifying the parties that the hearing would be adjourned other than
  any response to that proposed resolution.Â  Gould again made no objection or
  argument in response.Â  By failing to object to the ALJâ€™s comments, Gould waived
  any objection he may have raised to the remedy granted.Â  Rule 15(b), SCRCP, (â€œWhen
  issues not raised by the pleadings are tried by express or implied consent of
  the parties, they shall be treated in all respects as if they had been raised
  in the pleadings.â€); Andrews v. von Elten & Walker, Inc., 315 S.C.
  199, 202, 432 S.E.2d 500, 502, (Ct. App. 1993) (holding an issue that was
  discussed extensively at trial without objection was tried by consent of the
  parties).
Additionally,
  we note Gouldâ€™s position at trial was markedly contrary to his position on
  appeal.Â  Gould argued before the ALJ that an enforcement action was the proper
  means for OCRM to address Gouldâ€™s dock permit issue, rather than a revocation
  action.Â  As Gould apparently acknowledges in his brief, in an enforcement
  action for a permit violation, modification and removal are proper remedies.Â  See South Carolina Coastal Council v. Vogel, 292 S.C. 449, 357 S.E.2d 187
  (1987) (affirming a removal order of an illegally constructed dock); Brownlee
    v. Dept. of Health and Env. Control, 372 S.C. 119, 641 S.E.2d 45, 46 (Ct.
  App. 2007) (discussing an enforcement action by the predecessor to OCRM in
  response to a dock that, having been built not in compliance with the issued
  permit, had been subject to an administrative order to relocate the pierhead
  and walkway).Â  Thus, in effect, Gould now appeals the ALJâ€™s enforcement-like
  resolution of this matter, after arguing enforcement was the proper form for
  this action in the first place.Â  â€œIt is well settled that one cannot present
  and try his case on one theory and then change his theory on appeal.â€Â  Gurganious
    v. City of Beaufort, 317 S.C. 481, 488, 454 S.E.2d 912, 916 (Ct. App.
  1995).Â  
Because
  Gould raised no objection when the ALJ stated his intent to modify the permit
  rather than revoke it, and because of the inconsistency of his arguments on
  appeal and before the ALJ, we find this issue not preserved for appellate review.Â 
  Therefore, we find no error in the ALJâ€™s order. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, the ALJâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and
  GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.
  

[1] Maxwell was denied the right to intervene on October
  18, 2005.Â  She did not appeal from this decision.Â  Although it is unclear from
  the record, it appears that Maxwellâ€™s intervenor status was denied while this
  action was still in the posture of an enforcement action.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Raphael Suber, Appellant,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-327
  Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 18,
  2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Raphael M. Suber, of Ridgeville, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
          Attorney General Karen Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Raphael
  Suber filed a habeas corpus petition in Greenville County.Â  The lower court
  dismissed Suberâ€™s petition, and this appeal follows.Â  We affirm. Â 
FACTS
Raphael Suber was indicted for possession
  with intent to distribute crack cocaine within the proximity of a school,
  trafficking crack cocaine, and possession of a weapon during the commission of
  a violent crime.Â  Suber pled guilty to trafficking crack cocaine and possession
  of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime and received concurrent
  imprisonment terms of twenty five and five years respectively for the offenses.Â  
Suber
  did not appeal his sentence but filed an application for post conviction relief
  (PCR) in Greenville County.Â  In the application, Suber alleged ineffective
  assistance of counsel and that his plea was not voluntary.Â  Following an
  evidentiary hearing, the lower court dismissed Suberâ€™s application.Â  Subsequently,
  Suber appealed this dismissal by filing a writ of certiorari with the South
  Carolina Supreme Court, which was denied.Â  Approximately three years later,
  Suber filed a habeas corpus petition in a Greenville County court.Â  The lower
  court dismissed the habeas petition.Â  This appeal follows. Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS 
The function of a habeas
  corpus writ is to test the legality of a prisonerâ€™s imprisonment.Â  Gibson v.
    State, 329 S.C. 37, 40, 495 S.E.2d 426, 427 (1998).Â  Habeas corpus is
  obtainable only if other remedies, such as PCR, are inadequate or unavailable.Â  Id.Â  at 41, 495 S.E.2d at 428.Â  Any matter which is recognizable under
  the Uniform Post Conviction Act[1] (the Act) must be raised in a PCR application and may not be raised in a habeas
  petition.Â  Simpson v. State, 329 S.C. 43, 46, 495 S.E.2d 429, 431
  (1998). Â Â 
Thus,
  an individual is procedurally barred from relying on a habeas petition when the
  matter alleged is such that it could have been raised in a PCR proceeding.Â  Keeler
    v. Mauney, 330 S.C. 568, 571, 500 S.E.2d 123, 124 (Ct. App. 1998).Â 
  Consequently, if an individual is procedurally barred, his or her only remedy
  lies in filing the habeas petition with the South Carolina Supreme Court.Â  Id.
On appeal, Suber
  states the lower court erred in denying habeas relief because his trial counsel
  was ineffective.[2]Â 
  However, ineffectiveness of counsel is an issue that can only be asserted in
  proceedings under the Act.Â  State v. Kornahrens, 290 S.C. 281, 287, 350
  S.E.2d 180, 184 (1986). Â Therefore, Suber is procedurally barred from filing a
  writ of habeas corpus in the lower court. 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the lower courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.[3]Â  
STILWELL,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â 
  

[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 17-27-10 to 17-27-160 (2003). 
[2] As grounds for relief in his habeas petition to the
  lower court, Suber argued the lower court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to
  accept his guilty plea and ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  However, on
  appeal Suber assigns error only to the ineffective assistance claim and does
  not assert the subject matter claim. Â Because the subject matter issue was not
  appealed we do not address it.Â  State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 50, 625
  S.E.2d 216, 221 (2006) (issues not argued in the briefs are deemed abandoned). 
[3] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Hasseini v. Hamilton
text:
The South Carolina Court of Appeals


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jafar Hasseini, Appellant,
				v.
				Alicestine Hamilton, Personal Representative of the Estate of Melvin Hamilton, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Mikell R. Scarborough, Master in Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-328
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 21, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Gregg E. Meyers, of Charleston, for Appellant.Â  
				
				Benjamin Goldberg and Charles Goldberg, both of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Jafar Hasseini appeals the masterâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Alicestine Hamilton, personal representative of the estate of Melvin Hamilton. Â We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Hasseini purchased commercial property from Melvin Hamilton in 1999. Â Hasseini believed the property could be connected to water and sewer service via lines running in front of the property.Â  In January 2000, he discovered that was not the case and shortly thereafter filed suit against Hamilton and other parties, including both the real estate agency and agent.Â 
 
Hasseini did not know Hamiltonâ€™s address, although documents from the transaction showed Hamiltonâ€™s forwarding address as that of the commercial property itself (â€œ3729 Ashley Phosphate NCâ€) and â€œJohn C. Calhoun Apt NC.â€ Â Hasseini delivered four copies of the summons and complaint to the Dorchester County Sheriff on May 14, 2002 for service on Hamilton and other defendants.Â  He made periodic checks with the Sheriffâ€™s office regarding the status of service on Hamilton and was told â€œthey were working on it.â€Â  In October 2003, during a deposition, the real estate agent indicated he had some knowledge as to Hamiltonâ€™s location.Â  Hamilton was ultimately served by a private process server on February 23, 2004. Â 
Sheriffâ€™s office employees testified they had no record of a summons and complaint being delivered for service upon Hamilton.Â  However, the Sheriffâ€™s office did have records showing that pleadings for both the real estate agent and agency were left with the office and service was actually accomplished as to these defendants.Â  
 
Hamilton moved for summary judgment, arguing the statute of limitations had run on Hasseiniâ€™s claims by the time he was served. Â The master concluded that service was not effected upon Hamilton within a reasonable time after the summons and complaint were delivered to the Sheriff, and therefore the statute of limitations was not tolled.Â  Consequently, Hasseiniâ€™s case against Hamilton was dismissed.Â 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The master found that Hasseiniâ€™s claim accrued in January 2000 when he discovered there was no access to sewer lines from the property.Â  Therefore, the applicable rule governing service was the rule in effect at that time.Â  See Bergstrom v. Palmetto Health Alliance, 358 S.C. 388, 397, 596 S.E.2d 42, 46-47 (2004) (quoting Stephens v. Draffin, 327 S.C. 1, 5, 488 S.E.2d 307, 309 (1997)) (â€œIn South Carolina, the law in effect at the time the cause of action accrued controls the partiesâ€™ legal relationships and rights.â€).Â  At that time, Rule 3(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provided for the tolling of the statute of limitations when the summons and complaint were delivered to the sheriff for service, provided actual service was then made within a reasonable time.[2]Â  See Hughes v. Water World Water Slide, Inc., 314 S.C. 211, 215, 442 S.E.2d 584, 586 (1994); Montgomery v. Mullins, 325 S.C. 500, 504, 480 S.E.2d 467, 469 (Ct. App. 1997).
Whether service was made within a reasonable time depends on the circumstances of the case.Â  Montgomery, 325 S.C. at 504, 480 S.E.2d at 470.Â  In this case, the record shows that Hamilton indeed resided at the John C. Calhoun Apartments in North Charleston immediately following the sale of the property and for the next ten months. Â Hamiltonâ€™s wife and daughter testified that the family completed a change of address form for the U.S. Postal Service and had no trouble receiving mail at that address.Â  Hamilton then moved to Hollywood, South Carolina, in Charleston County, and again completed a change of address form.Â  Hamilton was also listed in the Greater Charleston/North Charleston phone book from 2001 through 2004.Â  Furthermore, Hasseini was in possession of Hamiltonâ€™s social security number which, when given to the private process server, led to Hamiltonâ€™s location.Â 
 
At the summary judgment hearing, Hamilton did not dispute that the summons and complaint were delivered to the Sheriffâ€™s office for service on Hamilton.Â  Nevertheless, Hamilton was not actually served until one year and nine months later.Â  The master found that to be an unreasonable time.Â  We agree.Â  Although Hasseini called the Sheriffâ€™s office â€œperiodicallyâ€ to check on the status of service, there comes a point when it is incumbent upon a plaintiff to take further steps.Â  In this case, Hasseini continued to rely on the Sheriffâ€™s office for well over a year before even beginning to pursue service through an investigator based on information already in his possession or readily accessible through public means.Â  As a result, Hamilton was not served until more than a year after the statute of limitations had run.Â 
 
In Montgomery v. Mullins, 325 S.C. 500, 480 S.E.2d 467 (Ct. App. 1997), this court affirmed the trial courtâ€™s determination that service was not made within a reasonable time after delivery to the sheriff.Â  In that case, the summons and complaint had been filed with the clerk of court in late September 1992, just as the statute of limitations was about to expire, and were forwarded to the sheriff for delivery. Â Id. at 502-03, 480 S.E.2d at 468.Â  The plaintiff had pursued the whereabouts of the defendants through various means and ultimately served them by publication.Â  Id. at 504, 480 S.E.2d at 469.Â  Service was completed in late December 1993, approximately one year and two months after delivery to the sheriff.Â  Id.Â  
 
The plaintiff in Montgomery did receive an affidavit of non-service from the sheriffâ€™s office, which distinguishes it from this case.Â  Id. at 504, 480 S.E.2d at 469.Â  However, the elapsed time between delivery to the sheriff and actual service is considerably longer in this case and there is no evidence Hasseini was taking any significant action to aid the sheriff in effecting service.Â  The determination of whether Hamilton was served within a reasonable time is in the masterâ€™s discretion, and there is ample evidence in the record to support his ruling.Â  Id. at 506, 480 S.E.2d at 470.Â  Consequently, the ruling of the master is 
 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â The present form of the rule omits any reference to delivery of the summons and complaint to the sheriff and simply provides â€œ[a] civil action is commenced when the summons and complaint are filed with the clerk of court if: Â (1) the summons and complaint are served within the statute of limitations . . . ; or (2) if not served within the statute of limitations, actual service must be accomplished not later than one hundred twenty days after filing.â€Â  Rule 3(a), SCRCP.

title: Watson v. Babb
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The Estate of Charles L. Watson, and Eleanor G. Watson, and Pamela Watson Fehlig, as Personal Representatives of the Estate of Charles L. Watson, and CLW Investments, Inc., d/b/a Salt Marsh Cove, and Wilbur M. McLamb, Individually, Respondents,
				v.
				Malcolm M. Babb, Appellant
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-329
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 25, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Malcolm M. Babb, of Calabash, N.C., pro
				se.
				Stephan Victor Futeral, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Malcom M. Babb appeals orders of the circuit court sanctioning him and denying his motion to quash a subpoena.Â  Babb further contends the circuit court abused its discretion by entering judgment on a prior judgeâ€™s order.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On July 17, 2001, the Watsons filed a lawsuit against Babb and amended the complaint on July 25, 2001, alleging abuse of process, malicious prosecution, frivolous proceedings, slander of title, conversion, and breach of fiduciary duty.Â  The Watsons noticed Babbâ€™s wife (Witness) for a deposition for December 29, 2003.Â  Witness requested that her deposition not be held at the office of the Watson properties, but rather at the Georgetown County Courthouse.Â  Not having received a response from the circuit court setting the location for her deposition, she notified the Watsons by letter, dated December 23, 2003, that she would not appear at the December 29th deposition. On January 13, 2004, the Watsons filed a motion to compel Witnessâ€™s testimony because she did not appear at the December 29th deposition.Â  The circuit court granted the Watsonsâ€™ motion to compel and orderedÂ  the deposition take place at the Georgetown County Courthouse.
Witnessâ€™s deposition was held on April 19, 2004.Â  Babb attended the deposition and frequently made objections on behalf of Witness.Â  The Watsons claim Babbâ€™s objections were inappropriate and his behavior was disruptive.Â  As a result, the Watsons terminated the deposition with the intention of filing an appropriate motion asking the circuit court to continue it to a later date.Â  Accordingly, the Watsons made a motion for sanctions and to compel the deposition testimony of Witness.Â 
 
The circuit court heard the motion on September 13, 2004, and on November 24, 2004, the court ordered Babb pay $5,665.05 to the Watsons in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs for the failed deposition.Â  The court also ordered that Babb pay the sum of $2500 to the South Carolina Bar Association as a sanction. The court further ordered the Watsons to reschedule Witnessâ€™s deposition and Babb to pay all costs of taking the second deposition at aÂ  hourly fee of $250 for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Babb then retained an attorney, who, on December 16, 2004, filed a motion for the circuit court to reconsider its award of sanctions against Babb.Â  On May 9, 2005, the circuit court partially granted Babbâ€™s motion for reconsideration, reducing the payment to the South Carolina Bar to $1000 and rescinding the award of attorneyâ€™s fees and mileage for the taking of Witnessâ€™s second deposition.Â 
 
Prior to issuance of the May 9, 2005 order, counsel for Carolina First Bank sent Babb a letter, dated December 22, 2004, which stated that the bank had been served with a subpoena for the records regarding Babbâ€™s relationship with the bank.[2]Â Â  Counsel further stated that unless he received an order from the court that the subpoena should not be complied with, the bank would produce the requested records â€œon or before January 24, 2004â€ [sic], as directed by the subpoena.Â  On January 19, 2005, Babb filed a motion to quash the subpoena issued to the bank.Â  The circuit court denied Babbâ€™s motion on the ground that it was untimely.Â  

On July 20, 2005, the Watsons filed a motion for sanctions for Babbâ€™s failure to comply with both the November 24, 2004 order and the May 9, 2005 order.Â  The circuit court granted the Watsonsâ€™ motion for sanctions and entered a monetary judgment against Babb in the amount of $7,040.05, which represented the $5,665.05 previously awarded by the court, plus an additional $1375 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs incurred by the Watsons in preparation for and attendance at the hearing before the court.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Sanctions
Babb contends that in sanctioning him, the circuit court abused its discretion by: (1) ordering that he pay both the Watsonsâ€™ attorneyâ€™s fees and expenses for Witnessâ€™s first deposition, as well as the video expenses of the second deposition; (2) failing to find that the Watsons attempted to use the deposition as a means of intimidation, and finding that Babbâ€™s objections were sanctionable, when the trial judge had granted him the right to object; (3) failing to make a determination of Babbâ€™s ability to pay before ordering that he pay attorneyâ€™s fees; (4) requiring that Babb pay the South Carolina Bar Association the sum of $1000; (5) failing to give him an opportunity to challenge the Watsonsâ€™ affidavit of their expenses in attempting to obtain Witnessâ€™s deposition; and (6) sanctioning Babb in excess of what is usual for practicing attorneys in the state.Â  We disagree.
A.  Attorneyâ€™s Fees and Retaking of Deposition
The imposition of sanctions is generally entrusted to the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  Barnette v. Adams Bros. Logging, Inc., 355 S.C. 588, 593, 586 S.E.2d 572, 575 (2003).Â  A trial judgeâ€™s exercise of his discretionary powers with respect to sanctions imposed in discovery matters will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  The burden is on the party appealing from the order to demonstrate the trial court abused its discretion.Â  Id.Â  An abuse of discretion may be found where the appellant shows that the conclusion reached by the trial court was without reasonable factual support and resulted in prejudice to the rights of the appellant, thereby amounting to an error of law.Â  Dunn v. Dunn, 298 S.C. 499, 502, 381 S.E.2d 734, 735 (1989) (citing Darden v. Witham, 263 S.C. 183, 209 S.E.2d 42 (1974)). 
 
In In re Anonymous, 346 S.C. 177, 194, 552 S.E.2d 10, 18 (2001), our Supreme Court noted the broad discretion given South Carolina judges in addressing misbehavior during depositions.Â  The court stated that in addition to their traditional contempt powers, judges may impose sanctions for improper deposition conduct, including an award of reasonable expenses such as attorney fees.Â  Id.Â  The court also stated that â€œamong the costs a judge may deem appropriate could be those incurred for future judicial monitoring of depositions or payment for the retaking of depositions.â€Â  Id.
In the present case, the circuit court found that Babb engaged in conduct specifically prohibited in depositions.Â  The court found the prohibited conduct included making multiple and ongoing speaking objections and coaching the witness, both of which continued after objection from opposing counsel; engaging in disruptive behavior, including inappropriate and inflammatory references to opposing counsel; and making numerous incorrect objections that were dilatory in nature and purpose.Â  The court concluded Babbâ€™s conduct was a â€œknowing and willful effort to subvert the cause of justice and undermine the judicial process. . . .â€ 
 
Thus, pursuant to In re Anonymous, we hold it was within the courtâ€™s discretion to sanction Babb by ordering him to pay the Watsonsâ€™ attorneyâ€™s fees and costs, including the video expenses of Witnessâ€™s second deposition.
B.  Abuse of Discovery Process 

Moreover, Babb argues that the Watsons abused the discovery process by attempting to use Witnessâ€™s deposition as a means of intimidation.Â  However, we find no evidence of such an objective on the part of the Watsons.Â  Despite Babbâ€™s contention, we also find no evidence that the circuit court granted Babb any right to make speaking objections during the deposition.
C.  Ability to Pay Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Babb also argues theÂ  court erred by failing to make a determination of his ability to pay before ordering that he pay attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees as a sanction for discovery abuse, the court should weigh the nature of the abuse, the discovery posture of the case, willfulness, and the degree of prejudice.Â  Samples v. Mitchell, 329 S.C. 105, 112, 495 S.E. 2d 213, 216 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The thrust of the discovery rules is to afford full and fair disclosure of evidence, â€œto prevent a trial from becoming a guessing game or one of surprise for either party.â€ State v. Highway Department v. Booker, 260 S.C. 245, 252, 195 S.E.2d 615, 619 (1973). 
 
Unlike in the family court area, the cases discussing imposition of attorney fees as a sanction for discovery abuse do not focus on the ability of the offending party to pay.Â  Nevertheless, we think the financial condition of the offending party should factor into the adequacy of the sanction.Â  However, in this case Babb filed a Rule 59(e) motion wherein he claimed he was not financially able to pay the sanctions.Â  Additionally, he filed an affidavit setting forth his financial condition. We note also that the Watsons filed a reply to Babbâ€™s motion for reconsideration vehemently attacking his claim of poverty.Â  Thus, it is clear the trial court had before it Babbâ€™s financial information and presumably considered it in granting partial relief on his motion for reconsideration by reducing the sum Babb was required to pay to the South Carolina Bar and eliminating the requirement for paying for the retaking of the deposition.Â  Â 
D.  Payment Â to the South Carolina Bar Association
In addition, Babb argues the circuit court abused its discretion by requiring him to pay $1000 to the South Carolina Bar Association, because the association was not a party to the litigation.Â  The court ordered Babb pay that sum to the association â€œfor use in its Law Related Education Program in educating our stateâ€™s laymen about substantive and procedural law.â€ Although the association was not a party in this case, the sanction requiring Babb to pay the association was aimed at Babbâ€™s specific misconduct, pursuant to Karppi v. Greenville Terrazzo Co., Inc., in which the court of appeals held that the sanction should be aimed at the specific misconduct of the party sanctioned.Â  327 S.C. 538, 543, 489 S.E.2d 679, 682 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Karppi further notes the policy reasons for the imposition of sanctions, which is to â€œpenalize those whose conduct may be deemed to warrant such a sanction, and to deter those who might be tempted to such conduct in the absence of such a deterrent.â€Â  327 S.C. at 545, 489 S.E.2d at 683 (citing Natâ€™l Hockey League v. Metro. Hockey Club, Inc., 427 S.C. 639, 643, 96 S.Ct. 2778, 2781 (1976).Â  Because we find a connection between the order to pay the association and Babbâ€™s misconduct during the deposition, including his violation of the rules of procedure, we find the circuit court did not err by sanctioning Babb in this way.
 II.  Motion to Quash Subpoena
Babb contends the circuit court abused its discretion by denying his motion to quash the subpoena on the ground it was not timely filed, because the bank provided his banking records to the Watsons prior to the time prescribed to respond with a motion to quash.Â  Babb further contends it was error for the court to disregard the bankâ€™s representations of the January 24, 2005 due date for filing a motion to quash and rely solely on the time frame set out in Rule 45, SCRCP.Â  We disagree.
Rule 45(c)(2)(B), SCRCP, provides that a person must file a motion to quash a subpoena within fourteen (14) days after service of the subpoena or before the time specified for compliance if such time is less than 14 days after service.Â  Considering this rule, Babbâ€™s January 21, 2005 filing of the motion to quash, after having received notice of the subpoena as early as December 21, 2004, was untimely.Â  However, on December 22, 2004, counsel for Carolina First Bank sent Babb a letter stating that unless they received an order from the court that the subpoena should not be complied with, the bank would produce the records requested â€œon or before January 24, 2004â€ [sic], as directed by the subpoena. Nevertheless, the bank provided Babbâ€™s records to the Watsons on January 7, 2005.
 
As we read the bankâ€™s letter to Babb, there was no representation as to the deadline for Babb to file a motion to quash.Â  The timeliness of Babbâ€™s motion was governed by the Rules of Civil Procedure, which could neither be lengthened nor shortened by the bankâ€™s letter.Â  Therefore, we ascribe no error to the court when it relied on the Rules of Civil Procedure in finding Babbâ€™s motion to be untimely.Â  
 
Moreover, we perceive no prejudice to Babb in the allegedly premature furnishing of the records by the bank inasmuch as he does not contend that the records were not discoverable.[3]Â  Thus, the bankâ€™s release of them before the deadline set out in the letter to Babb, does not give rise to reversible error. We find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion by denying Babbâ€™s motion to quash the subpoena.Â Â Â Â  
 
III.  Other Issues Argued
Babb also argues the circuit court abused its discretion by sanctioning him in excess of sanctions that would have been entered against a licensed attorney for like conduct citing In the Matter of Golden, 329 S.C. 335, 496 S.E.2d 619 (1998); that theÂ  court erred in sanctioning him because he was not given the opportunity to challenge the Watsonsâ€™ attorneyâ€™s fee affidavit; and that the court did not have jurisdiction and/or abused its discretion by entering judgment on a judgment and awarding additional attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We hold these arguments are manifestly without merit and affirm the trial court pursuant to Rule 220(c), SCACR, (which provides that the appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, decision or judgment upon any grounds appearing in the record on appeal) and the following authorities: Ball v. Canadian American Express Co., Inc., 314 S.C. 272, 277, 442 S.E.2d 620, 623 (Ct. App. 1994) (failure to object to the use of affidavits during a hearing waives the right to object on appeal); and Rule 37 SCRCP (dealing with the right of a court to sanction a party for failure to cooperate in discovery).
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion when sanctioning Babb and denying his motion to quash the subpoena.Â  The circuit court also did not abuse its discretion by ordering that Babb pay additional attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED. 
SHORT, WILLIAMS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The letter also indicated that Babb had been notified of or served with the subpoena on December 21, 2004.
[3] Babbâ€™s counsel conceded to the trial court that at least part of the documents furnished by the bank were relevant to the case.

title: Mack v. Mack
text:
Â THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Mary Jones Mack, Personal Representative of the Estate of Leroy Mack, Appellant.
				v.
				
				Philip Leroy Mack, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-in-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-330
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 26, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Lawrence M. Kasen, of Summerville, for Appellant.
				Joseph P. Cerato, of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â Appellant Mary Jones Mack (Wife) brought this action to set aside a deed executed by her late husband, Leroy Mack, Sr. (Father), in favor of his son from a prior marriage, Philip Mack (Son).Â  Wifeâ€™s complaint alleged Father lacked mental capacity to execute the deed and that Son exercised undue influence over Father at the time of his executing the deed. Â The Master-in-Equity found 1) no evidence Father lacked mental capacity and dismissed that cause of action and 2) no undue influence was exerted by Son over Father in the execution of the deed.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
 
FACTS
Father purchased the property at issue on Birdâ€™s Nest Road in Wadmalaw Island, South Carolina in 1980, and built a home on the property in 1988.Â  Father and Son lived together on the property until Wife moved in some time prior to 1999.Â  Because there was tension and a mutual dislike between Wife and Son, Son moved out approximately the same time Wife moved to the home.Â  Father made it clear to Son he did not want Son around the home because of the problems it created between Wife and Son.Â  Often times, when Son visited, Father called the police to remove him from the property.Â  During one such incident in March 2000, Father demanded, at gunpoint, that Son leave the property.Â  When Father married Wife later that year, Father and Son stopped communicating and Son stopped visiting the property.Â  There is conflicting testimony as to the duration and extent of Father and Sonâ€™s estrangement, but for roughly four years the two communicated in limited circumstances and only when Wife was not present. Â 
In October 2003, Fatherâ€™s mother died.Â  Father fell into depression and began to drink and lose weight.Â  On November 16, 2003, Father admitted himself to the Medical University of South Carolina Hospital (MUSC) complaining of excessive alcohol intake and abdominal pain.Â  Two days later, Father voluntarily discharged himself, and soon thereafter, he reconnected with Son.Â 
 
On December 26, 2003, Wife called the police to the property after Father became violent with her and began punching the walls.Â  The police took Father to a hospital where, after a psychiatric and substance abuse assessment, he was determined not to be suicidal.Â  The mental status exam indicated Fatherâ€™s thought process was organized and void of any delusions, hallucinations, or paranoid ideas.Â  Father was subsequently released.Â  Three days later, Wife sought to commit Father, believing he needed medical attention and supervision.Â  A hearing was scheduled for January 21, 2004, to determine if Father was a chemically dependant individual in need of voluntary commitment.Â  Â Â 
When Father learned Wife was seeking to involuntarily commit him, Father informed Son of his plan to deed the property to him.Â  A few days prior, on Christmas day, Father also spoke to his sister, Shirley Mae Mack Brown (Brown), of his intent to leave his property to someone in the family, and specifically of his intent to leave it to Son.Â  On January 14, 2004, Father, under the mistaken belief that he could sign over the original deed to Son through a notary, called Son to pick him up and take him to his notary friend, Rueben Davisâ€™s house.Â  Davis told Father he would need to see an attorney to execute the deed.Â  Son contacted his attorney, who recommended the law firm of Davidson, Wigger and Bennett.Â  Two days later, Father executed the deed at the law firm office.Â  Jim Olson, a paralegal, dealt with Father immediately after Father executed the deed.Â  

Father did not attend the hearing for his involuntary commitment on January 21, and died three days later on January 24, 2004.Â  Wife learned of the deed execution the following day and received a letter of eviction to vacate the property on January 28, 2004.Â  
 
Wife filed this action to set aside the deed claiming Father lacked mental capacity and Son exercised undue influence over Father at the time he executed the deed.Â  Son counterclaimed alleging Wife committed waste at the property. Â The master denied Sonâ€™s counterclaim of waste and dismissed Wifeâ€™s first cause of action based on the lack of capacity of Father.[2] Â Further,  
the master found: (1) no confidential relationship existed between Father and Son; (2) Son did not exercise dominion over Father; (3) even if the evidence were sufficient to shift the burden to Son, the Son rebutted the shift by showing there was no undue influence exercised over Father; and (4) adequate consideration supported the conveyance based on the totality of circumstances.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action to set aside a deed is equitable in nature. Â Bullard v. Crawley, 294 S.C. 276, 278, 363 S.E.2d 897, 898 (1987).Â  â€œIn an appeal from an action in equity, this court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Pinckney v. Warren, 344 S.C. 382, 387, 544 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2001).Â  However, this does not require an appellate court to disregard the findings below, or ignore the fact that the trial judge was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of witnesses.Â  Id.Â  Moreover, the appellant maintains the burden of convincing the appellate court the trial judge committed error in his findings.Â  In re Thames, 344 S.C. 564, 571, 544 S.E.2d 854, 857 (Ct. App. 2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Confidential Relationship
Wife argues the master erred in failing to find a confidential relationship existed between Father and Son at the time of the execution of the deed. Â We disagree.
 
â€œA deed regular and valid on its face raises a presumption of validity. Â Generally, the party attacking the deed has the burden of proof.â€Â  Hudson v. Leopold, 288 S.C. 194, 196, 341 S.E.2d 137, 138 (1986) (citation omitted).Â  Where, however, a confidential relationship exists between the grantor and grantee, the deed is presumed invalid and the burden is upon the grantee to show an absence of undue influence.Â  Middleton v. Suber, 300 S.C. 402, 405, 388 S.E.2d 639, 641 (1990).Â  
 
A confidential relationship arises when the grantor places trust and confidence in the grantee, and the grantee exerts dominion over the grantor.Â  Bullard, 294 S.C. at 281, 363 S.E.2d at 900.Â  While a familial relationship, alone, is insufficient evidence of a confidential relationship, Hudson, 288 S.C. at 196, 341 S.E.2d at 139, â€œa familial relationship certainly supports an argument that a confidential relationship exists.â€Â  Dixon v. Dixon, 362 S.C. 388, 398, 608 S.E.2d 849, 853 (2005).Â  Yet, the relationship must be one implying confidence, with some evidence that the grantor actually reposed trust in the grantee in the handling of his affairs. Â Bullard, 294 S.C. at 281, 363 S.E.2d at 900.
In this case, while there was a familial relationship between Father and Son, there is little, if any, evidence that a relationship of trust and confidence existed.Â  There is no evidence that Son was entrusted with any of Fatherâ€™s business affairs or financial matters or was ever asked to take care of any of Fatherâ€™s personal matters prior to the deed transfer.Â  Wife asserts Sonâ€™s involvement in the actual deed transfer reveals Father placed his trust and confidence with Son.Â  Wife suggests Sonâ€™s selection, hiring, and paying of the attorneys that prepared the deed supports her assertions.Â  Although Son assisted in the details of the transfer, he did so at Fatherâ€™s request and only after Fatherâ€™s expressed decision to make the transfer.Â  Further, there is no evidence that Son exerted dominion over Father.Â  In his order, the master found Father was an â€œindependent personâ€ â€œaware of his actions and the consequences of his actions at the time of execution of the Deed.â€ Accordingly, the master found Son did not exert dominion over Father and held no confidential relationship existed between Father and Son. Â We hold a preponderance of the evidence supports this finding.
II.  Undue Influence
Regardless of whether there existed a confidential relationship, Wife argues the master erred in failing to find Son exerted undue influence over Father.Â  We disagree.
 
Absent a confidential relationship, the party challenging the deed must show undue influence was brought to bear upon the conveyance such that the grantorâ€™s will was overborne by the grantee.Â  Dixon, 362 S.C. at 398-99, 608 S.E.2d at 854. Â The Supreme Court has described the nature of undue influence as â€œthe kind of mental coercion which destroys the free agency of the creator and constrains him to do things which are against his free will, and that he would not have done if he had been left to his own judgment and volition.â€Â  Id. (citing Russell v. Wachovia Bank, N.A., 353 S.C. 208, 217, 578 S.E.2d 329, 333 (2003)).[3] Â Further, the challenging party is required to show â€œthe grantor was unquestionably susceptible to undue influence as a result of [his] physical and mental condition or for some other reason,â€ andÂ  â€œclear evidence of opportunity and disposition by the grantee . . . to influence the grantor must be present.â€Â  Bullard, 294 S.C. at 281-82, 363 S.E.2d at 900. 
 
We find no evidence in the record that Fatherâ€™s free will was ever overcome.Â  The master found that Father â€œacted of his free will up to the time of his deathâ€ and was aware of the â€œconsequences of his actions at the time of the execution of the Deed.â€Â  The record also indicates that Father, by his own motivation, decided to convey the property to Son, his only child, in an attempt to keep the property in the Mack family.Â  Additionally, the record is devoid of evidence indicating Father was susceptible to undue influence or that Son had the opportunity or disposition to influence Father.Â  Wife claims Fatherâ€™s alcoholic and weakened mental and physical condition placed him in a more susceptible position to Sonâ€™s exertion of dominion over his affairs.Â  While there is evidence that Fatherâ€™s drinking increased and his health deteriorated from October 2003 until his death on January 24, 2004, the master noted that Fatherâ€™s â€œmental acumen remained steadyâ€ and he was â€œan independent person with a strong will despite poor health in his final days.â€ Â Further, Olson, the paralegal who helped with the deed, testified that Father was under no duress at the time of executing the deed.Â  Thus, we find the evidence insufficient to establish undue influence. 
 
III.  Admission of Testimony 
Wife next argues the master erred in admitting trial testimony of Brown and Olson as to Fatherâ€™s wish to leave his property to Son over Wifeâ€™s hearsay objection.[4]Â  We disagree.Â   
Hearsay is an out of court statement offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted.Â  Rule 801(c), SCRE.Â  The rule against hearsay prohibits the admission of such a statement unless an exception to the rule applies.Â  Rule 802, SCRE. Â Rule 803(3), SCRE, provides that a statement of the declarantâ€™s then existing state of mind, emotion, sensation, or physical condition (such as intent, plan, motive, design) is excluded from the hearsay rule.Â 
 
Wife contends the state of mind exception does not apply to the testimony of Brown and Olson because both were offered to prove the truth of the matter, namely, that Father was considering leaving his property to Son.Â  We disagree with Wifeâ€™s assertion.Â 
 
First, the testimony of Olson is non-hearsay because it is not offered for the truth of the matter, but rather to prove Fatherâ€™s capacity at the time of the execution of the deed.Â  Thus, Olsonâ€™s testimony was admissible as non-hearsay.Â  
 
Further, Brownâ€™s testimony reveals that Father made statements to her that indicated Fatherâ€™s then existing state of mind.Â  In December 2003, less than a month before Father executed the deed, Father told Brown of his plan to leave the property to someone in the family.Â  Father initially stated to Brown he was going to leave the property to Son, but asked if she would want it if Son did not want the property.Â  These statements show that, at the time he made them, he intended to keep the property within the Mack family.Â  Father made the statements to Brown before he executed the deed, and they show how he intended to subsequently dispose of his property.Â  Therefore, pursuant to the state of mind exception, Brownâ€™s testimony was admissible and relevant to the issue at hand. 
 
IV.  Reimbursement for Contributions 
Lastly, Wife asserts that, if this court were to affirm the masterâ€™s rulings, equity requires the court remand the case on the issue of reimbursement for contributions made by Wife to the property before and after Fatherâ€™s death.Â  We disagree.
 
At trial, Wife attempted to testify as to monetary amounts she paid for the general upkeep, maintenance, and improvements to the property.Â  Sonâ€™s counsel objected on the basis that it was outside of the scope of Wifeâ€™s complaint and that she should not be permitted to amend her pleadings to conform to objectionable testimony at such a late stage in the proceeding.Â  The master allowed Wife to make an offer of proof through which the master would later rule on the admissibility.Â  After Wifeâ€™s testimony the master specifically gave Wife the opportunity to make a motion to modify the pleadings to conform to the testimony.Â  Wife made no such motion and the master made no ruling on the admissibility of Wifeâ€™s testimony regarding her monetary contributions to the property.Â  Accordingly, we find this issue is not adequately preserved for review. See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (holding that an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court in order to be preserved for appellate review).
CONCLUSION
We find no confidential relationship existed between Father and Son at the time of the execution of the deed.Â  Absent a confidential relationship, we hold Wife failed to present sufficient evidence to establish undue influence.Â  Further, we hold the master did not err in admitting trial testimony as to Fatherâ€™s wish to leave his property to Son.Â  Lastly, we find Wifeâ€™s request to remand the case on the issue of reimbursement for contributions she made to the property is not adequately preserved for our review.
 
Therefore, the Master-in-Equityâ€™s ruling is  
AFFIRMED. 
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Respondent did not appeal from the masterâ€™s denial and, therefore, it is the law of the case. Â Â Sims v. Hall, 357 S.C. 288, 293 n. 2, 592 S.E.2d 315, 318 n.2 (Ct. App. 2003) (finding an unappealed ruling becomes the law of the case and precludes further consideration of the issue on appeal).Â  Likewise, the Appellant did not appeal the masterâ€™s dismissal of the action based on lack of capacity and, therefore, it is the law of the case. Â Id.
[3] The supreme court acknowledged the cited case dealt with a will, but found no reason such a discrepancy should change its analysis.Â  
 
[4] Wifeâ€™s counsel made timely objections to the testimony of both Brown and Olson; however, the master admitted the testimony without any specificity as to the basis for his ruling.

title: Washington v. Wright Construction Company
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ex Parte:
				
				Kristen Janee Washington, Dependent Child of Donnell Washington, Deceased Employee, Respondent,
				In 
				Re:
				Annette Washington, Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Wright Construction Company, Defendant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-331
Submitted June 6, 2007 â€“ Filed June 26, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Stephen Bucher, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
				James K. Holmes, of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Annette Washington (Wife) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s finding that she was not the surviving spouse of Donnell Washington (Husband), and accordingly, did not qualify for death benefits.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On September 5, 1998, Husband and Wife married and resided together in North Charleston.Â  Both parties had children from prior relationships but they did not have any children together.Â  On June 13, 2002, the police were called to the coupleâ€™s home over a domestic dispute.Â  Wife denied any violence occurred and did not press criminal charges.Â  In spite of that, Husband was arrested for domestic violence.Â  The parties dispute whether Husband returned to the home when he was released from jail the following day.
On August 6, 2002, Husband fell from a ladder during the course of employment and suffered a fatal head and neck injury.Â  On November 14, 2002, Wife filed a claim for death benefits alleging Husband suffered an accidental injury arising out of and in the course of his employment with the Marlowe-Chandler Company, which she later corrected to the Wright Construction Company.Â  Wife further contended Husband died as a result of his injuries and as his surviving spouse, she was entitled to death benefits.
On February 13, 2004, a hearing was scheduled, but because Wife could not be found, her attorney withdrew the claim.Â  On July 9, 2004, Wife filed another claim seeking death benefits under the same grounds as the previously withdrawn claim.Â  On March 25, 2005, the single commissioner conducted a hearing on the matter.Â  
 
At the hearing, Wife testified Husband returned home two days after the domestic dispute, and they continued living together, but sometimes he stayed with his son or mother because it was more convenient to where he worked.Â  Wife further testified from July 14, 2002, until Husbandâ€™s death, she stayed with her daughter in the hospital, and Husband stayed with his son or mother.Â  Additionally, she testified Husband was responsible for all of the bills including rent, electricity, and water, and her financial situation deteriorated following Husbandâ€™s death.Â  Wife further testified that after Husbandâ€™s death, she was evicted and homeless for five months and now lived in subsidized housing. Â 
However, Husbandâ€™s son testified he picked Husband up from jail following the domestic dispute and took him to the marital home where they found Husbandâ€™s personal belongings packed in his car.Â  Further, Husbandâ€™s son and nephew both testified Husband lived with Husbandâ€™s son or mother upon his release from jail until his death.Â  Husbandâ€™s mother testified Husband lived with her for approximately five weeks following his release from jail. Â Â 
On August 5, 2005, the single commissioner found Husband and Wife were living separate and apart at the time of Husbandâ€™s death, and Wife was not dependent on Husband for support at the time of his death.Â  Accordingly, the single commissioner found the claim compensable but found Wife was not a surviving spouse and Kristen Washington, as Husbandâ€™s minor beneficiary, was solely entitled to death benefits.Â  Wife appealed, and the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission affirmed and adopted the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  Wife appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed, adopting the Appellate Panelâ€™s order.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions by the Appellate Panel.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  Under the scope of review established in the APA, this court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Stone v. Traylor Bros., Inc., 360 S.C. 271, 274, 600 S.E.2d 551, 552 (Ct. App. 2004).
The substantial evidence rule governs the standard of review in a workersâ€™ compensation decision.Â  Frame v. Resort Servs. Inc.,357 S.C. 520, 527, 593 S.E.2d 491, 494 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The Appellate Panelâ€™s decision must be affirmed if supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  
Shuler v. Gregory Elec., 366 S.C. 435, 440, 622 S.E.2d 569, 571 (Ct. App. 2005). Â An appellate court can reverse or modify the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision only if the appellantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2006); Bursey v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004). 
 

	â€œSubstantial evidenceâ€ is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its action.

Lark, 276 S.C. at 135, 276 S.E.2d at 306.
â€œ[T]he possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984). Â Where the evidence is conflicting over a factual issue, the findings of the Appellate Panel are conclusive.Â  Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co.,360 S.C. 276, 290, 599 S.E.2d 604, 611 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Appellate Panel is the ultimate finder of fact.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  â€œThe final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Appellate Panel.â€Â  Bass v. Kenco Group,366 S.C. 450, 458, 622 S.E.2d 577, 581 (Ct. App. 2005).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Wife argues the Appellate Panel erred in finding she was not a surviving spouse.Â  Wife contends the Appellate Panelâ€™s findings that she and Husband were separated and Husband was not providing her with support because he left the marital home after his arrest for domestic violence are erroneous.Â  We disagree.
 
Section 42-9-290 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) provides if an employee dies as the result of an accident arising out of the course of employment, the employer must provide death benefits to dependents wholly dependent on the decedentâ€™s earnings for support.Â  â€œA surviving spouse or a child shall be conclusively presumed to be wholly dependent for support on a deceased employee.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-110 (Supp. 2006).Â  â€œThe term â€˜surviving spouseâ€™ includes only the decedentâ€™s wife or husband living with or dependent for support upon the decedent at the time of the decedentâ€™s death or living apart from the decedent for justifiable cause or by reason of desertion by the decedent at such time.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-175 (Supp. 2006). 

Wifeâ€™s testimony is the only evidence that Husband remained in the marital home.Â  She testified they still lived together except that he sometimes stayed with his mother or son because it was more convenient to where he worked but would come home to change clothes.Â  All of the other testimony contradicts her assertion he returned to the marital home.Â  The Appellate Panel found Wifeâ€™s testimony inconsistent with other credible witnesses and not supported by any corroborating evidence.Â  Accordingly, the Appellate Panel found Wife not to be credible.Â  Husbandâ€™s son testified Husband lived with him or Husbandâ€™s mother following his release from jail.Â  Husbandâ€™s mother testified that Husband lived with her once he was released.Â  Husbandâ€™s nephew testified in July and August 2005, he lived with Husband and Husbandâ€™s son and took Husband to work everyday.Â  Further, Husbandâ€™s ex-wife testified Husband lived with their son and Husbandâ€™s mother at the time of his death.Â  

Additionally, in regards to Wifeâ€™s assertion that Husband continued to support her, she testified Husband was planning on putting a down payment on a trailer for them to live in together.Â  She also testified he continued to pay the rent and provide her with support, but because he only dealt in cash she could provide no record.Â  She did not call her landlord to testify that Husband continued paying the rent or provide any evidence Husband provided her with support after he went to jail. Â Accordingly, the record contains substantial evidence to support the Appellate Panelâ€™s findings that Husband and Wife did not live together and Husband was not supporting Wife at the time of his death.
 
Additionally, Wife argues the Appellate Panel erred in finding Wife was not a supported spouse because the only conclusions from the evidence were the separation was for justifiable cause or Husband deserted Wife.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  In her testimony before the single commissioner, Wife testified she and Husband still lived together.Â  Wife did not argue Husband deserted her or that they were separated for justifiable cause.Â  The single commissioner found Wife was not a surviving spouse based on the finding they were not living together and Wife was not dependent on Husband for support.Â  The single commissioner failed to find whether Husband deserted Wife or whether they were living apart for justifiable cause.Â  When Wife appealed, she asserted she and Husband were living together and she was dependent on him for support.Â  Wife also asserted, in the alternative, if she and Husband were separated, the only other conclusions were Husband deserted her or they were living apart for justifiable cause, which was Husbandâ€™s alleged domestic abuse.Â  The Appellate Panel affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s report, adopting it in full, and did not rule on the issues of desertion and justifiable cause.Â  Wife appealed to the circuit court asserting the same grounds as in her appeal to the Appellate Panel.Â  The circuit court affirmed adopting the findings of the Appellate Panel, thereby not addressing the desertion and separation for justifiable cause issue.Â  Wife did not file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion.Â  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See In re Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an issue for appeal, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€); Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (â€œIt is well settled that, but for a very few exceptional circumstances, an appellate court cannot address an issue unless it was raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).Â  
 
Further, this issue also fails on its merits.Â  Husbandâ€™s son testified that upon Husbandâ€™s release from jail, he took Husband home where they discovered Wife had packed all of Husbandâ€™s belongings in his car. Â Wifeâ€™s own testimony was that she and Husband still lived together.Â  Thus, Wife did not meet the elements of desertion.Â  See Vickers v. Vickers, 255 S.C. 25, 30, 176 S.E.2d 561, 563 (1970) (â€œThe essential elements of desertion are . . . (1) [c]essation from cohabitation for the required statutory period; (2) intent on the part of the absenting party not to resume it; (3) absence of the opposite partyâ€™s consent; and (4) absence of justification.â€).Â  Further, there was no evidence the parties were separated for justifiable cause.Â  Wife testified Husband did not abuse her and provided no evidence of Husbandâ€™s abuse.Â  Further, Wife testified she and Husband were not living apart.Â  Therefore, the record contains substantial evidence to support the Appellate Panelâ€™s findings.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, because the record contains substantial evidence Husband and Wife did not live together and Husband was not supporting Wife at the time of his death, substantial evidence supports the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding. Â Additionally, the issue of whether Husband deserted Wife or whether Husband and Wife were separated for justifiable cause is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Further, the record contains substantial evidence to support the finding that Husband did not desert Wife, and Husband and Wife were not separated for justifiable cause.Â  Therefore, the Appellate Panelâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.Â

title: Bennett v. Wilson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Willie J. Bennett Appellant,
				v.
				Tommy Wilson Respondent,
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County 

Â Reginald L. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-332
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 27, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Willie J. Bennett, of Hopkins, Pro Se.
				No Respondent brief filed.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Willie J. Bennett appeals a circuit court order remanding his case for a new trial.Â  In his brief, Bennett argues that:Â  (1) the property Tommy Wilson left at his residence should have been found abandoned, (2) the magistrate court erred in reducing Bennettâ€™s award of damages on remand, and (3) Wilson fraudulently and illegally entered into a contract without the required licenses and surety bonds.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Bennett contracted with Wilson to make repairs on Bennettâ€™s home for $7,000 in total.Â  Wilson claimed he and his subcontractor were insured and bonded by the state and local municipalities to perform all necessary work.Â  Wilson provided Bennett documentation in support of this claim.Â  Bennett paid Wilson $3,250 by check in advance, and agreed to pay the remaining contract balance upon completion.Â  However, Wilson only appeared at Bennettâ€™s house for one day of work and did not return thereafter.Â  Wilsonâ€™s subcontractor began painting Bennettâ€™s home on April 9, 2002, but failed to do the proper prep work.Â 
 
As a result, Bennett contacted the South Carolina Residential Builders Commission Program Coordinator, who investigated the matter and determined that Wilson and his subcontractor were not properly bonded or licensed to perform contract work with a cost greater than $4,999. The coordinator thus issued a cease and desist order to Wilson and his subcontractor.Â 
 
Bennett made numerous phone calls and sent three certified return receipt letters to Wilson requesting that he retrieve the equipment he left behind.Â  Wilson never did so, and Bennett disposed of the equipment.
Bennett filed a complaint in the magistrate court to recover damages associated with Wilsonâ€™s incomplete work.Â  A non-jury trial was held at which both parties appeared pro se.Â  The magistrate ordered that Wilson pay Bennett $5,000 in damages, including $325 in punitive damages, plus $55 in costs.Â  Wilson appealed to the circuit court, which remanded the case to the magistrate court. Â The magistrate court order dated July 15, 2004, awarded Bennett judgment in the amount of $3,000 plus $55 in costs.Â  Both parties appealed from this decision, but Bennettâ€™s appeal was dismissed.Â  The second appeal to the circuit court culminated in yet another remand to the magistrateâ€™s court for a new trial.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A circuit court sitting in an appellate capacity in a civil case from the magistrate has the ability to make a determination in the same manner as the circuit court in trials without a jury and to reverse for errors of fact even though the circuit court did not have the opportunity to observe witness demeanor. Â Vacation Time of Hilton Head Island, Inc., v. Kiwi Corp., 280 S.C. 232, 234, 312 S.E.2d 20, 21 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  On review from the circuit court, the appellate court is without authority to reverse findings of fact of the circuit court if there is any supporting evidence.Â  Southeastern PVC Pipe, Mfg. Inc. v. Rothruck Const. Co., Inc., 280 S.C. 498, 500, 313 S.E.2d 50, 52 (Ct. App. 1984).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Bennett appeals the circuit court order remanding this case for a new trial.Â  We affirm.
On appeal there is a presumption in favor of the correctness of a decree, and the burden of showing error by the circuit court is on the appellant.Â  Snyderâ€™s Auto World, Inc. v. George Coleman Motor Co., Inc., 315 S.C. 183, 186, 434 S.E.2d 310, 312 (Ct. App. 1993); Cook v. Eller, 298 S.C. 395, 398, 380 S.E.2d 853, 855 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  In this matter, Bennettâ€™s arguments do not contain allegations of any error on the part of the circuit court; rather, Bennett merely argues the merits of the case as if he were before the circuit court on remand.Â  Bennett seeks reinstatement of the damage award from the original hearing, minus the punitive damages that were later overturned, plus additional costs, for a total of $4,936.Â  The new trial ordered will provide Bennett the opportunity to prove his case and damages.Â  
 
Moreover, Bennett fails to provide a sufficient record for this appeal.Â  The record includes no transcript of the circuit court hearing.Â  The order in the record, a Form 4 order, contains no findings of fact or conclusions of law.[1]Â  Therefore the record before this court does not allow for competent review of any proceeding, and contains insufficient evidence to support Bennettâ€™s arguments. Â Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 339, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005) (holding that the appealing party has the burden of providing a sufficient record).Â  Based on this record, we can find no error on the part of the circuit court.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find the trial court did not err in remanding this case to the magistrateâ€™s court for a new trial. Accordingly, the circuit court order is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] It is merely a form order stating the appeal is remanded to the magistrateâ€™s court for a new trial.Â
