title: State v. Gibbs
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Clarence Gibbs, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-333
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 27, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Kathrine H. Hudgins, South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree,Â  of Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Clarence Gibbs appeals his convictions for kidnapping, armed robbery, and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Gibbs claims the trial court erred in admitting evidence of an out of court â€œshow-upâ€ identification.Â  Gibbs also alleges the trial court erred in admitting half of the photo line-up when the other half was lost prior to trial.Â  Finally, Gibbs avers the court erred in failing to give an alibi charge.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On April 10, 2005, at approximately 9:30 p.m., the Piggly Wiggly grocery store on Highmarket Street in Georgetown was robbed.Â  John Fowlkes, the manager, Eric Sessions, the cashier, and Greg Morton, the bagger, were working when the store was robbed. Â All three employees testified that a man entered the store, approached Fowlkes and Sessions, pulled a gun, and told them he was there to rob the store. Â The robber then took Fowlkes and Sessions to the office, also taking Morton along the way. Â When they arrived at the office, Fowlkes opened the door and let the others inside. Â As directed, Fowlkes filled a garbage bag with approximately $500. Â Thereafter, the robber left the store. Â Store surveillance captured the whole incident on tape.
 
The employees immediately notified the authorities of the robbery, and each gave consistent descriptions of the robber and the incident. Â After viewing the surveillance tape, officers with the Georgetown Police Department compiled a photo line-up, consisting of two pages with six photos on each page. Â One page contained a picture of Gibbs, while the other did not. Â Though both pages were presented to the victims, the page without Gibbsâ€™s photo was lost prior to trial. Â Ten days after the incident, Fowlkes and Morton both identified Gibbsâ€™s picture as that of the robber, while Sessions was unable to identify any of the twelve individuals pictured.
 
Approximately one week later, the police brought Gibbs in for questioning.Â  All three victims were brought to the police station to view Gibbs. Â Fowlkes and Morton identified Gibbs as the robber both by his appearance and his voice. Â Meanwhile, Sessions, upon viewing Gibbs, was sure Gibbs was not the person who robbed the Piggly Wiggly.
 
Gibbsâ€™s girlfriend, Karen Dozier, and mother, Rosa Jenkins, each testified they were at home with Gibbs on the night of the robbery. Â Gibbs, Dozier, and Jenkins testified they were watching the television show JAG on Sunday, April 10, 2005, between 9:00 p.m. and 10:00 p.m. Â They remembered this particular episode of JAG because Gladys Knight had a cameo role and sang her hit song â€œMidnight Train to Georgia.â€ 
 
Both Jenkins and Dozier testified the only channels available at their house were ABC and FOX while Gibbs testified they also picked up channel 5. Â The State presented rebuttal witnesses from ABC and FOX who testified their stations did not carry JAG on the night in question. Â One of the rebuttal witnesses testified JAG was a CBS affiliated show and would have come on channel 5 in Georgetown. 
 
Prior to trial, Gibbs moved to suppress any evidence of any show-up identifications as well as any mention of the incomplete photo line-up and any identifications that came from the line-up.Â  The trial judge then held a Neil v. Biggers[1] hearing.Â  After the hearing, the court made a thorough ruling denying Gibbsâ€™s motion to suppress both types of identification.Â  
 
At the conclusion of the trial, the jury convicted Gibbs on all three counts, and the judge sentenced him to concurrent terms of twenty years imprisonment for the armed robbery and for the kidnapping, and five years imprisonment to run consecutively for the possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Gibbs argues the trial court erred in admitting evidence of an out of court show-up identification.Â  We disagree.
This issue is not properly preserved for review.Â  See State v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 37, 479 S.E.2d 57 (1996) (holding a ruling in limine is not final, and unless an objection is made at the time the evidence is offered and a final ruling procured, the issue is not preserved for review); State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 587 S.E.2d 691 (2003) (holding issues not preserved for review cannot be addressed on appeal).
The trial of this case was conducted out of order to allow Eric Sessions, one of the victims and a defense witness, to report to the United States Navy.Â  Thus, Sessions was the first witness to be asked about the show-up identification.Â  The defense thoroughly questioned Sessions about the show-up identification. Â Sessions responded that he was sure Gibbs was not the person who robbed the Piggly Wiggly.
 
Both Fowlkes and Morton were then examined as part of the Stateâ€™s case.Â  During both examinations the witnesses were asked about the show-up identification process.Â  Both witnesses confirmed that the man at the police station during the show-up was the man who robbed the Piggly Wiggly.Â  Both witnesses also identified that man as Gibbs, the defendant.Â 
 
The defense failed to object to the show-up identification during either Fowlkesâ€™s or Mortonâ€™s examination. Â Therefore, pursuant to Simpson and Dunbar, that issue is not preserved for our review.
Gibbs next argues the trial court erred in admitting half of the photo line-up identification when the other half of the line-up was lost prior to trial.Â  We disagree.Â  
 
This issue is not preserved for our review.Â  State v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 37, 479 S.E.2d 57 (1996) (holding a ruling in limine is not final, and unless an objection is made at the time the evidence is offered and a final ruling procured, the issue is not preserved for review); State v. Carlson, 363 S.C. 586, 611 S.E.2d 283 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding defendant failed to preserve issue for appeal when he responded â€œNo objectionâ€ when the previously objected-to photographs were introduced into evidence at trial); State v. Dunbar, 356 S,C, 138, 587 S.E.2d 691 (2003) (holding issues not preserved for review cannot be addressed on appeal).
Once again, the defense questioned Sessions about the photo line-up prior to the State attempting to admit the line-up into evidence.Â  The State first moved the photo line-up into evidence during Fowlkesâ€™s testimony.Â  When the State made their motion to admit the line-up, the defense responded: â€œNo objection.â€
 
Later, when the State moved to enter the surveillance tape into evidence, the defense responded as follows:

	Subject to our previous objection.Â  I mean, your Honor, for clarification when the line-up was introduced into evidence previously I think I did not voice an objection.Â  I would like the record to reflect that the line-up that was introduced was subject to a previous objection.Â  The court has ruled and admitted that line-up but Iâ€™d like the record to reflect that that is subject to our previous objection.

Thereafter, the defense made a timely objection when the State attempted to introduce Mortonâ€™s copy of the photo line-up and when the State attempted to introduce a copy of the line-up during the investigating officerâ€™s testimony.Â  Both of those objections were overruled and the line-ups were admitted into evidence.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Gibbsâ€™s argument regarding the photo line-up being admitted into evidence during Fowlkesâ€™s testimony is not preserved for our review pursuant to Simpson, Carlson, and Dunbar.Â  With respect to Gibbsâ€™s argument that the line-up should not have been admitted during Mortonâ€™s and the officerâ€™s testimony, we find even if the line-up was erroneously admitted, it was harmless error as it was merely cumulative to the other line-up, the show-up identifications, and the in court identifications.Â  See State v. Blackburn, 271 S.C. 324, 329, 247 S.E.2d 334, 337 (1978)(â€œUnder settled principles, the admission of improper evidence is harmless where it is merely cumulative to other evidence.â€).Â  
 
Gibbsâ€™s final argument is that the trial court erred in failing to give an alibi charge.Â  We disagree.
Gibbs admits he did not object to the charge as given.Â  By not raising a specific objection to the trial courtâ€™s omission of a jury instruction on the law of alibi, Gibbs waived the right to raise the issue on appeal.Â  State v. Johnson, 315 S.C. 485, 445 S.E.2d 637 (1994).
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED.[2]Â  

STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] 409 U.S. 188 (1972).
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

				Vivian Lorraine Gilmer, Respondent,
				v.
				Larry Charles Lee, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Jasper County
Â Robert S. Armstrong, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-334
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 27, 2007 
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				James H. Moss, of Beaufort, for Appellant.Â  
				
				Darrell Thomas Johnson, Jr., Warren Paul Johnson and Mills L. Morrison, Jr., all of Hardeeville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Larry Charles Lee appeals the family courtâ€™s order accepting the appraisal value of the marital home at $170,000.Â  
 
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  In re McCracken, 346 S.C. 87, 92, 551 S.E.2d 235, 238 (2001) (stating that issues raised in a brief but not supported by argument are deemed abandoned and will not be considered on appeal); Murphy v. Murphy, 319 S.C. 324, 329, 461 S.E.2d 39, 41-42 (1995) (â€œFamily court judges have wide discretion in determining how marital property is to be distributed. Engle v. Engle, 343 S.C. 444, 448, 539 S.E.2d 712, 714 (Ct. App. 2000) (citations omitted) (holding that on appeal from family court, this Court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence; however, this does not mean that we should disregard the findings of the family court judge who was in a better position to see and hear the witnesses.)
AFFIRMED.[1]
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: Thornton v. Thornton
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Susan B. Thornton, Appellant,
				v.
				Michael C. Thornton, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Oconee County
Â Barry W. Knobel, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-336Â Â 
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 28, 2007
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; AND REMANDED 


	
		
			
				John S. Nichols, of Columbia; and Julian L. Stoudemire, of Seneca, for Appellant.
				Michael Thornton, of Jacksonville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Susan Thornton (Wife) and Michael Thornton (Husband) were granted a divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous separation. Â An equitable apportionment of the marital estate was ordered.Â  Wife appeals, arguing the family court erred in (1) its valuation of the marital residence; (2) failing to credit Wife with $18,000 she contributed towards the purchase of the marital residence; (3) its valuation of Wifeâ€™s retirement account; (4) its valuation of Husbandâ€™s retirement accounts; (5) failing to require Husband to reimburse Wife for health insurance premiums; (6) awarding Husband a surround sound system without apportioning the corresponding debt to the Husband; and (7) failing to require Husband reimburse Wife for the deficiency owed on a Chevy Trail Blazer that was repossessed and sold.[1]Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part and remand.[2]Â  Â 
FACTS
Husband and Wife married August 6, 1998.Â  This was Wifeâ€™s third marriage and Husbandâ€™s second marriage.Â  Wife had two children and Husband had three children, all of prior marriages.Â  Wife and Husband had no children together.Â  
 
Wife brought an action on January 23, 2003, seeking a divorce on the grounds of physical cruelty, equitable apportionment of the marital estate, an award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs, and a restraining order against Husband.Â  Husband filed an answer and counterclaim on February 14, 2003, joining in Wifeâ€™s prayer for equitable apportionment, and seeking a divorce on the ground of Wifeâ€™s physical cruelty and a restraining order against Wife.Â  
 
The family court entered a temporary order on February 14, 2003, awarding temporary relief as well as mutual restraining orders.Â  The court entered another order on April 15, 2003, refusing to find Husband in contempt, continuing the provisions of the February 14, 2003 order, and holding all other issues in abeyance.Â  On December 19, 2003, the court entered an interim order requiring Husband to prepay Wife an amount for six months of health insurance coverage, to continue through the final hearing.Â  The court ordered the reimbursement for prior coverage to be heard at the final hearing. Â 
The final hearing was heard on May 20, 2004 and August 17, 2004.Â  Following the hearing the family court granted a divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous separation, ordered equitable apportionment of the estate, awarded Wife attorneyâ€™s fees and costs, and issued a mutual restraining order.Â  The court also found Husband in willful contempt of a prior order against disposing of marital assets. Â 
On November 17, 2004, Wife moved for reconsideration regarding several aspects of the equitable apportionment.Â  On November 18, 2004, Husband moved for reconsideration of the final order regarding equitable apportionment and the award of fees and costs.Â  The family court heard both motions for reconsideration on December 7, 2004.Â  On January 5, 2005, the family court entered an order on reconsideration disposing of both motions and amending the order. Â Wife appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, the appellate court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Â Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992). Â This broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings, and we remain mindful of the fact the family court, who saw and heard the parties, is in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign weight to their testimony. Â Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981); Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 307, 608 S.E.2d 147, 149-50 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The burden is upon the appellant to convince this court that the family court erred in its findings of fact. Â Dubose v. Dubose, 259 S.C. 418, 423, 192 S.E.2d 329, 331 (1972).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Valuation of the Marital Residence
Wife argues the family court erred in valuing the marital residence at $145,000.Â  We disagree.
In making an equitable distribution of marital property, the family court must identify real and personal marital property and determine the propertyâ€™s fair market value.Â  Cannon v. Cannon, 321 S.C. 44, 48, 467 S.E.2d 132, 134 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œIn the absence of contrary evidence, the court should accept the value the parties assign to marital assets.â€Â  Toler v. Toler, 292 S.C. 374, 379, 356 S.E.2d 429, 432 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  A family court may accept the valuation of one party over another, and the courtâ€™s valuation of marital property will be affirmed if it is within the range of evidence presented.Â  Woodward v. Woodward, 294 S.C. 210, 215, 363 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1987). 
 
In this case, Wife testified that she had the property appraised on April 30, 2002, at $135,000, and stated that was the value of the property at the time the parties filed for divorce in January 2003.Â  She further explained that Husband and Wife offered the home for sale in 2001 for $135,000.Â  Husband, however, testified that he initially allowed the property to be appraised relatively low, $135,000, but believed at that time they could sell it for $145,000 - $149,000.Â  In a trial exhibit, Husband assigned the property a fair market value of $159,000 and explained at the hearing that Husband and Wife had made substantial improvements to the property, including increasing the actual size of the residence by 1,000 square feet, adding sodding and a watering system at a cost of $10,000, and landscaping at a cost of $8,000.Â  As to the valuation of the marital residence, the family court found the Husbandâ€™s testimony slightly more credible than the Wifeâ€™s and valued the residence at $145,000.
Because the family court was free to accept Husbandâ€™s valuation over Wifeâ€™s, and the value accepted by the family court was within the range presented at trial, we find no abuse of discretion in the valuation of the marital home.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err in valuing the marital residence.Â  
 
II. Credit for Money Contributed Towards the Purchase of the Marital Residence
Wife also argues the family court erred in failing to credit her roughly $18,000 she contributed towards the purchase of the marital residence.Â  Wife contends the money she used was from the sale of her premarital residence.Â  We disagree. 
 
Generally, property acquired by either party prior to the marriage is nonmarital property.Â  Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 338, 569 S.E.2d 393, 398 (Ct. App. 2002); S.C. Code Ann. Â§20-7-473(2) (Supp 2005).Â  However, nonmarital property may be transmuted into marital property if: (1) it becomes so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable; (2) it is jointly titled; or (3) it is utilized by the parties in support of the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an intent by the parties to make it marital property. Â Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 98, 545 S.E.2d 531, 536-37 (Ct. App. 2001). 
 
Wife claims that she sold her residence from her previous marriage to raise the down payment for the marital residence.Â  She testified she netted $18,162.57 from the sale of her pre-marital residence and deposited it into a joint Wachovia bank account in the name of Husband and Wife.Â  Wife later testified that all the marital money went into that joint bank account and all house payments and bills were paid from the account.Â  Husband acknowledged that the money from Wifeâ€™s pre-marital residence was deposited into the joint bank account, but testified that it was because Husband and Wife considered the sale a â€œjoint sale.â€Â  The family court found the monies generated from the sale of Wifeâ€™s former residence were fully transmuted and she was not entitled to a credit.
After reviewing the record, we find evidence to support the family courtâ€™s ruling that the money Wife received from the sale of her premarital residence was fully transmuted.Â  The evidence shows that the money from the sale was used in support of the marriage or in some other manner evidencing the intent to make it marital property.Â  Money from the sale was directly deposited into a previously established joint bank account.Â  Money from the joint account was used to make the down payment on the marital residence and to make house payments.Â  Money from the account, as Wife testified, was also used by Husband and Wife to pay marital bills.Â  We find that by commingling the money from the sale of Wifeâ€™s premarital residence with money from the partiesâ€™ marital account so as to become untraceable, and generally using the money from the account to support the marriage, any money received from the sale of Wifeâ€™s residence was transmuted into marital property. Â Accordingly, the family court did not err in failing to credit her roughly $18,000.
III. Valuation of Wifeâ€™s Retirement Account
Wife contends the family court erroneously valued her retirement account with Oconee Memorial Hospital.Â  We agree. 
 
During the marriage, Wife worked as an RN with Oconee Memorial Hospital.Â  Her retirement account from the hospital was fully funded by her employer and at the time of the separation the account value was $8,614.03.Â  Wife submitted a statement from the hospital revealing that as of December 31, 2002, Wife was only 40% vested in the plan.Â  The family courtâ€™s order valued the account as if Wife was 100% vested in the plan at the time the parties separated.Â  On appeal, Wife asserts the family court erred in treating her account as fully vested and valuating her retirement at the full $8,614.03.
This court has consistently held nonvested retirement benefits are marital property if the benefits are acquired during the marriage and before the date of filing.Â  Ball v. Ball, 312 S.C. 31, 34-35, 430 S.E.2d 533, 534-35 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding nonvested, unvalued pension benefits are marital property subject to equitable distribution); see also Shorb v. Shorb, 372 S.C. 623, 643 S.E.2d 124, 127 (Ct App. 2007) (finding nonvested stock options comparable to nonvested retirement funds and concluding the nonvested stock options at issue were marital property subject to equitable distribution).Â  There is no doubt in this case that Wifeâ€™s retirement account is marital property.Â  However, the account is only marital property to the extent that it was earned while Wife and Husband were married.Â  At the time of the filing for divorce Wife was 40% vested.Â  Thus, if Wife were to cash in her account on the day of the filing, she would have been entitled to only 40% of the account.Â  Since the account was not fully vested at the time of the filing it should not have been valued as if it were 100% vested.Â  Therefore, we find the family court erred in its valuation of Wifeâ€™s retirement account and remand for a revaluation of the account consistent with this opinion.
IV. Valuation of Husbandâ€™s Retirement Accounts
Wife contends the family court erred in failing to include all of Husbandâ€™s retirement accounts in apportioning the marital estate.Â  We agree. 
 
In the final divorce decree, the family court noted the existence of Husbandâ€™s Roth IRA with Smith Barney, and assigned a value of $5,304.96. The family court included this value as the Husbandâ€™s retirement in the apportionment of the marital estate.Â  Wife presented evidence at the final hearing that Husband had a second retirement account with Wachovia at the time of separation, valued at $2,330.39. Â Wife testified that on March 8, 2004 Husband cashed in the account and received $2,315.82.Â  On appeal, Wife argues the family court erred in failing to include the value of the Wachovia account in the equitable apportionment.Â  
 
A review of the record reveals that Husband maintained a separate Wachovia Securities retirement account at the time of separation.Â  The evidence suggests Husband sold the securities on March 8, 2004 and received $2,315.82.Â  Rule 208(a)(4), SCACR, provides in part: Â â€œUpon the failure of respondent to timely file a brief, the appellate court may take such action as it deems proper.â€Â  Here, Husband did not file a respondentâ€™s brief and in short offers us nothing as to whether the account should have been included in the marital estate or whether the family court properly excluded the account. Â This court should not be inclined to do what Husband neglected to do, i.e, â€œsearch the record for reasons to affirm.â€ Â See Campbell v. Carr, 361 S.C. 258, 266, 603 S.E.2d 625, 629 (Ct. App. 2004) (Goolsby, J., concurring) (citing Wierszewski v. Tokarick, 308 S.C. 441, 444 n.2, 418 S.E.2d 557, 559 n.2 (Ct. App. 1992)).Â  Thus, we find the family court erred in failing to include the Wachovia Securities retirement account in the valuation of Husbandâ€™s retirement and remand the issue for a revaluation of Husbandâ€™s retirement accounts consistent with this opinion.
V. Reimbursement for Health Insurance Premiums
Wife further appeals the family courtâ€™s ruling that Husband was not required to reimburse Wife for prior health insurance premiums she paid on his behalf.Â  We agree. 
 
Under the interim order Wife was to maintain health insurance coverage on Husband for six month periods, and Husband was to reimburse her at the monthly rate of $86.99 ($521.94 per six months).Â  The order also found that at the time of the order, Husband had not paid Wife for coverage for the prior six months at $133.88 per month, for a total of $803.23 for his health insurance.Â  The order read:

	PAST INSURANCE COVERAGE: That reimbursement by the Plaintiff to the Defendant for the health insurance coverage of the Defendant in the total amount of insurance furnished the Defendant by the Plaintiff at the rate of $133.88 per month times six (6) equals $803.28 in total cost shall be heard at the final hearing in this case 
	

The final divorce decree identified this issue as an issue for resolution by the court, but failed to address Wifeâ€™s claim for reimbursement.Â  Wife raised this issue in her motion for reconsideration.Â  In the order on reconsideration the family court acknowledged the issue had been preserved by the interim order but ruled that because the temporary order required each party to pay those debts listed in his or her financial declarations and the interim order required the parties keep the insurance coverage in effect, it could â€œfind no present basis to require that the Husband reimburse the Wife for these payments.â€ Â 
While the temporary order provided that each party would be responsible for debts shown on the financial declarations it was â€œon a temporary basisâ€ â€œpending further order of the Court.â€Â  Further, the interim order did require the parties keep the insurance coverage in effect, but found Wife should not be responsible for Husbandâ€™s health insurance premiums.Â  The interim order required Husband to prepay Wife for coverage on a six month basis during the pendency of the case.Â  If Husband failed to make the prepayment, he forfeited all health insurance coverage.Â 
 
The reimbursement of coverage premiums Wife sought were for the six months prior to the interim order, July through December 2003, during which period Husband and Wife were separated.Â  We find no reason Wife should have been responsible for Husbandâ€™s health insurance for the six months prior to the interim order.Â  See Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992) (explaining that, in appeals from the family court, the appellate court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence).Â  Therefore, we reverse the family courtâ€™s ruling as to payments of health insurance premiums and find it equitable for Husband to pay Wife the portion of health insurance premiums, $803.28, she paid for the six months prior to the interim order.Â  
 
VI. Debt Corresponding to Stereo System
Wife also argues the family court erred in awarding Husband a surround sound system without apportioning the corresponding debt to the Husband.Â  We agree.
During the marriage, Husband and Wife purchased a surround sound system with a joint Wells Fargo account. Â Husband took the system when he left the marital residence. Â The system was listed on a list of marital assets in Husbandâ€™s possession at the time of the temporary order.Â  The temporary order provided, â€œHusband should have temporary use and possession of certain items of personal property located in the marital home and identified and listed on page 3 of Wifeâ€™s affidavit . . . and be responsible for the expenses associated therewith.â€Â  In the final divorce decree the family court did not specifically address the surround sound system. Â Wifeâ€™s motion for reconsideration requested the family court reconsider the award of the system. Â The family court summarily dismissed the issue.Â  
 
The family court has broad discretion in determining how marital property is to be valued and distributed.Â  Wynn v. Wynn, 360 S.C. 117, 123 600 S.E.2d 71, 74 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The family court may use any reasonable means to divide the property equitably, and its judgment will only be disturbed where abuse of discretion is found.Â  Id.Â  The same rules of fairness and equity that apply to the equitable division of marital property also apply to the division of marital debts.Â  See Hardy v. Hardy, 311 S.C. 433, 437, 429 S.E.2d 811, 813-14 (Ct. App. 1993); Smith v. Smith, 327 S.C. 448, 457 ,486 S.E.2d 516, 521 (Ct. App. 1997).
In this case, we find it equitable and fair that the debt should follow the system as required in the temporary order.Â  Because Husband took possession of the system at the time of the temporary order and maintained possession, he should be responsible for the corresponding debt.Â  Therefore, we remand for a determination of the debt corresponding to Husbandâ€™s system and thereby credit to be applied to Wife. 
 
VII. Reimbursement for Deficiency on Repossessed Chevy Trail Blazer
 
Finally, Wife appeals the family courtâ€™s ruling that Husband was not required to reimburse Wife for the deficiency owed on a Chevy Trail Blazer that was repossessed and sold.Â  We disagree.
In the temporary order Husband was awarded the Blazer, but the car was repossessed by GMAC due to Husbandâ€™s failure to make payments. Â The final divorce decree identified the partiesâ€™ Blazer as marital property, but because it had been repossessed and sold, the court valued it at zero.Â  Wife claimed she was being sued for the balance of $4,900.54 and asked the court to charge the deficiency sought by GMAC against Husband.Â  In the order on reconsideration, the family court held it could find no evidence that Wife had paid any portion of that deficiency or that GMAC was actively pursuing a deficiency claim against Wife. Â Accordingly, the family court denied Wifeâ€™s request.Â  
 
We agree with Wife that Husband should be responsible for any debt or deficiency owed on the Blazer.Â  However, after a review of the record, we find no evidence that Wife has paid any portion of the deficiency owed GMAC or that GMAC is actively pursuing a deficiency claim.Â  Therefore, the family court did not err in holding Husband was required to reimburse Wife for the deficiency owed on the Blazer.Â  
 
CONCLUSION
We affirm the family courtâ€™s valuation of the marital residence, its refusal to credit Wife for money she contributed towards the purchase of the marital residence, and its refusal to require Husband to reimburse wife for the deficiency owed on the Blazer.Â  We find the family court erred in its valuation of Wifeâ€™s retirement account, its valuation of Husbandâ€™s retirement accounts, and its award of the surround sound system to Husband without apportioning the corresponding debt.Â  We remand these three issues to the family court for a recalculation consistent with this opinion.Â  Finally, we reverse the family courtâ€™s holding that Husband was not required to reimburse Wife for health insurance premiums and require Husband to reimburse wife $803.28 for the coverage premiums. 
 
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ. concur.

[1] Husband did not file a Respondentâ€™s brief. 
 
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Roe v. David J.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE AND SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				John Roe, Respondent,
				v.
				David J., Samuel T., a Minor under the age of eight (8) years, Alicia Roe, and John Doe, Defendants, of whom David J. is Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Stephen S. Bartlett, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-339
Submitted June 6, 2007 â€“ Filed June 28, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Thomas J. Quinn, of Greenville, for Appellant
				Vanessa L. Hartman, of Greenville, for Respondent.
				Chace Damon Campbell, of Greenville, Chace Campbell, for Guardian Ad Litem.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Father appeals the family courtâ€™s order terminating his parental rights in Child based on a finding that father had willfully failed to support Child.Â  We affirm.
Facts
When Child was six months old his mother started dating and later married John Roe.Â  This action was initiated by Roe in attempt to legally adopt Child.Â  Roe claimed Fatherâ€™s parental rights should be terminated due to Fathers willful failure to visit or support Child. Â At the time of the hearing in this matter, Father was incarcerated and had been incarcerated since prior to Childâ€™s birth.
Early in Childâ€™s life, Father visited with Child on two occasions while incarcerated. Â Father sent letters to Childâ€™s mother requesting that Child be brought for additional visits.Â  However, Childâ€™s mother was uncooperative.Â  Therefore, the family court found Fatherâ€™s failure to visit Child was out of his control and was not willful.Â  
 
Fatherâ€™s only means of income was from money orders send to him by his family.Â  The court noted that it was unclear how much money Father had received but found that between August 1, 2000 and March 20, 2006, Father spent a total of $1,976.21 and that Father had not provided any support for Child.Â  Instead, Father spent the money he received in the prison canteen on snack food, cigarettes, and various other nonessential items.Â  The family court, in its order, noted Fatherâ€™s limited access to funds.Â  However, the family court found that Father had some disposable income, and he had willfully failed to use the income to support Child.Â  Based on this finding of a willful failure to support coupled with a determination that termination was in Childâ€™s best interest, the family court terminated Fatherâ€™s parental rights.Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Standard of Review
In an appeal from a TPR, an appellate court may review the record and make its own determination whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Jackson, 368 S.C. 87, 95, 627 S.E.2d 765, 770 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, the appellate court should not necessarily disregard the findings of the family court, because the family court is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Id.Â  This degree of deference is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of a minor child.Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 62, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).Â  Before parental rights can be forever terminated, the alleged grounds for the termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 356 S.C. 413, 589 S.E.2d 753 (2003). Â 
Law/Analysis
Section 20-7-1572(4) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) allows the family court to grant TPR upon a finding TPR is in the childâ€™s best interest and:

	The child has lived outside the home of either parent for a period of six months, and during that time the parent has wilfully failed to support the child.Â  Failure to support means that the parent has failed to make a material contribution to the childâ€™s care.Â  A material contribution consists of either financial contributions according to the parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child according to the parentâ€™s means.Â  The court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not the parent has wilfully failed to support the child, including requests for support by the custodian and the ability of the parent to provide support . . . .

â€œJust as it does in determining wilful failure to visit, the family court has wide discretion in determining whether a failure to support is wilful.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 612, 582 S.E.2d 419, 425 (2003).Â  â€œTo determine whether a parentâ€™s failure to support or visit during the time of incarceration evinces a settled purpose to forego parental responsibilities requires a comprehensive analysis of all of the facts and circumstances.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Wilson, 344 S.C. 332, 339, 543 S.E.2d 580, 584 (Ct. App. 2001).
Although Father had limited funds at his disposal due to being incarcerated, he clearly had some funds and failed to provide support for Child.Â  Given Fatherâ€™s expenditures on nonessential items, we find that the family court did not err in finding Fatherâ€™s failure to support was willful.Â  See 
 
S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Phillips, 301 S.C. 308, 310, 391 S.E.2d 584, 585 (Ct. App. 1990) (holding incarcerated fatherâ€™s failure to support child was willful despite his limited income when considering his expenditures on nonessential items in the canteen such as snack food and cigarettes).
Â Accordingly, the order of the family court is
AFFIRMED. [1]
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT , JJ., concur. 
 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Auto Owners Insurance v. Pittman
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

RECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Auto Owners Insurance Company, Respondent,
				v.
				Dorothy Pittman, Terri Pittman, Timmy Temple Pittman and Sharon L. Barber, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Joseph M. Taylor, Defendants,
				Of whom Sharon L. Barber, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Joseph M. Taylor is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Dillon County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-341
Heard March 7, 2007 â€“ Filed June 29, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Richard A. Harpootlian, and Graham L. Newman, both of Columbia, for Appellant
				Erin D. Dean, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â In this declaratory judgment action, Sharon Barber, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Joseph Taylor, appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment to Auto Owners Insurance Company in which the court held there was no coverage for her claim.Â  We affirm. Â 
FACTS
This action involves a general commercial liability insurance policy purchased by Dorothy Pittman.Â  Dorothy is the sole owner of Pittman Food Store, Inc., a corporation which owns several rental properties.Â  From 1994 through June 2002, Dorothyâ€™s daughter-in-law, Terri Pittman, rented one of these properties for the operation of a convenience store called JT&T Food Mart. Â The lease agreement was never reduced to writing.Â  Terri claimed that in exchange for the $500 a month in rent, Dorothy agreed to pay the property taxes on the property and to maintain liability insurance for the operation of the business.Â  Although Dorothy acknowledged that she agreed to pay the real estate taxes on the property, she denied that she had agreed to provide liability insurance for Terri, Timmy, or JT&T Foodmart.Â  Terriâ€™s husband (and Dorothyâ€™s son), Timmy Pittman, worked part-time at the store.Â 
 
In 1995, Dorothy completed an application for insurance coverage with Auto Owners seeking coverage for the properties she owned.Â  Barbara Causey, the agent who completed Dorothyâ€™s application, was aware that Dorothy did not operate JT&T.Â  Although the application listed the nature of Dorothyâ€™s business as â€œproperty-owner,â€ Causey incorrectly coded Dorothyâ€™s application as owner/operator of a convenience store and not as a lessor.Â  Dorothy thereafter paid the slightly higher premiums associated with the incorrect classification.Â 
 
On July 23, 2000, a frequent patron, Joseph Taylor, who was mentally challenged, became involved in a verbal altercation with one of the storeâ€™s part-time employees.Â  Terri, who was working at the time, called Timmy and asked him if she should call the police.Â  Timmy told her not to call the police and that he would come over to the store.Â  By the time Timmy arrived at the store, Taylor had already left.Â  Timmy searched for Taylor and found him off store premises.Â  Timmy and Taylor engaged in a struggle.Â  Timmy struck Taylor with a brick and then shot him.Â  Taylor died as a result of his injuries.Â  Timmy eventually pled guilty to voluntary manslaughter.
In September 2001, Barber, as personal representative of Taylor, filed a wrongful death suit against Dorothy d/b/a Pittman Food and Drugs and Timmy.Â  In February 2002, Auto Owners filed a declaratory judgment action seeking an order that Auto Owners did not owe a duty to defend or a duty to indemnify either Dorothy or Timmy in the underlying action.Â  Thereafter, in May 2003, Barber amended her complaint to remove all allegations against Dorothy, either individually or doing business as Pittman Food and Drug; the amended complaint also added Terri as a defendant.Â  Thus, the only issue remaining in the declaratory judgment action was whether Auto Owners owed a duty to defend or a duty to indemnify Terri or Timmy under the commercial general liability policy issued to Dorothy.Â  
 
After a hearing, the circuit court granted summary judgment to Auto Owners.Â  The court held Auto Ownersâ€™ duties only extended to Dorothy.Â  In addition, the court held Auto Owners was not estopped from arguing the insurance policy does not cover Terri and Timmy.Â  Specifically, the court found Auto Ownersâ€™ conduct did not warrant estoppel because the elements of estoppel were not met.Â  This appeal followed.
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, appellate courts apply the same standard that governs the circuit court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP, which states that summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005). â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€ Â Helms Realty, Inc., 363 S.C. at 340, 611 S.E.2d at 488. Â â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  Summary judgment should be granted when plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ.Â  Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 518, 595 S.E.2d 817, 822 (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Barber contends the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to Auto Owners.Â  Specifically, Barber argues Auto Owners should be estopped from denying coverage to Terri or Timmy because Auto Ownersâ€™ agent filed an insurance application falsely stating Dorothy owned and operated JT&T.Â  We disagree.Â 
 
First, we hold the doctrine of estoppel cannot be used to make valid a policy that would provide coverage for JT&T, a business in which Dorothy, the named insured, did not have an insurable interest.Â 
 
â€œLiability insurance, like other forms of insurance, must be supported by an insurable interest in the named insured.Â  The insurable interest required does not depend upon the named insured having either a legal or equitable interest in the property, but it is enough that the insured may be held liable for damages to its operation and use.â€Â  American Mut. Fire Ins. Co. v. Passmore, 275 S.C. 618, 620-21, 274 S.E.2d 416, 417-18 (1981) (citations omitted).Â  
 
In Passmore, the named insured added a vehicle belonging to someone else onto his own liability policy when the owner of the vehicle was unable to obtain insurance himself.Â  The trial court held the insurance company was estopped from denying coverage because it accepted premiums and issued the policy covering the vehicle.Â  Our supreme court reversed, holding that because the named insured did not have any insurable interest in the vehicle, the policy was illegal and the doctrine of estoppel may not be invoked to make it valid.
 
In the present case, it is undisputed that Dorothy did not have an insurable interest in the business of JT&T.Â  Accordingly, Barber may not invoke the doctrine of estoppel in an attempt to make valid a policy providing coverage for the business.Â 
 
Even if the doctrine of estoppel could be invoked in this case, we find the essential elements of estoppel have not been met and thus the doctrine does not apply.Â 
 
In finding estoppel was not applicable, the trial court applied the traditional essential elements of estoppel.Â  These elements are:Â  â€œ(1) ignorance of the party invoking it of the truth as to the facts in question; (2) representations or conduct of the party estopped which mislead; (3) reliance upon such representations or conduct; and (4) prejudicial change of position as the result of such reliance.â€Â  Pitts v. N.Y. Life Ins. Co., 247 S.C. 545, 552, 148 S.E.2d 369, 371 (1966).
Barber asserts Auto Owners should be estopped based on Small v. Coastal States Life Ins. Co., 241 S.C. 344, 348, 128 S.E.2d 175, 178 (1962).Â  In Small, the supreme court stated: 
 

	The knowledge of an agent acquired within the scope of his agency is imputable to his principal, and, if an insurance company, at the inception of the contract of insurance, has knowledge of facts which render the policy void at its option, and the company delivers the policy as a valid policy, it is estopped to assert such ground of forfeiture. Â 

241 S.C. 344, 350, 128 S.E.2d 175, 178 (citation omitted).Â  
 
The court held the insurer was estopped from denying coverage where the insured unintentionally misrepresented his health history.Â  In so finding, the court noted there was evidence the insurerâ€™s agent had been informed of the insuredâ€™s medical history.Â  The court did not examine whether the elements of estoppel had been proven.
Based on Small, Barber argues the correct standard for determining whether an insurer may be estopped from asserting coverage merely depends on whether the insurer â€œhas knowledge of facts which render the policy voidâ€ when the policy is issued.Â  Barber further contends Small stands for the position that the elements of estoppel need not be proved for estoppel to apply in the insurance context.Â 
 
We find Barberâ€™s assertion that the traditional elements of estoppel are not required under Small is meritless.Â  Although the supreme court did not specifically address the elements in Small, it did not reject those elements either.Â  
 
Furthermore, the appellate courts of this state have consistently considered the essential elements set forth in Pitts in determining whether the doctrine of estoppel applies in insurance cases. Â See e.g., Standard Fire Co. v. Marine Contract and Towing Co., 301 S.C. 418, 421, 392 S.E.2d 460, 462 (1990); Jost v. Equitable Life Assurances Socâ€™y of the U.S., 271 S.C. 492, 496, 248 S.E.2d 778, 780 (1978); The Crescent Co. of Spartanburg v. Ins. Co. of N. Am., 266 S.C. 598, 604, 225 S.E.2d 656, 659 (1976); Ellis v. Metro. Cas. Ins. Co. of N.Y., 187 S.C. 162, 167, 197 S.E. 510, 512 (1938) (stating that in the law of insurance contracts, â€œthe essential elements of estoppel are ignorance of the party who invokes the estoppel, representations, or conduct of the party estopped, which mislead, and an innocent and deleterious change of position in reliance upon such representations or conductâ€).
We find the circuit court did not err in applying the elements of estoppel as found in Pitts.Â  Considering these elements, the trial court held:

	In this case, there was absolutely no contact between Terri Pittman, Timmy Pittman, and Auto Owners Insurance Company.Â  Accordingly, there can be no representations or actions taken by [Auto Owners] that was relied on by [Terri and Timmy] and therefore, there are no grounds in the instant case for estoppel.Â  If [Terri and Timmy] were relying on Mrs. Dorothy Pittman to provide insurance for their business, they had the opportunity to check with her/or obtain a copy of the policy to determine whether or not Terri Pittman, Timmy Pittman, or their business, JT&T Foodmart, were shown as insured on the policy.Â  Their failure to undertake that action cannot impose liability on Auto Owners.Â 
	

Barber only challenged the standard the circuit court applied in considering estoppel and did not specifically challenge these findings of facts.Â  See Weaver v. Recreation Dist., 328 S.C. 83, 88, 492 S.E.2d 79, 82 (1997) (stating the trial courtâ€™s findings come to the appellate court with a presumption of correctness, and the burden is on the appellant to demonstrate reversible error).Â  Furthermore, we hold the circuit courtâ€™s findings are supported by the record.Â  There is no evidence Auto Owners made any representation of coverage to either Terri or Timmy.[1] Â In addition, there is no evidence that Dorothy relied on any representation or conduct by Auto Owners that would support a finding of estoppel in this case.Â  In fact, Dorothy stated in her affidavit that she only intended to obtain liability insurance for only herself individually and doing business as Pittman Food & Drug.Â  She denied intending that the policy would also cover Terri, Timmy, or JT&T Foodmart.Â 
 
We therefore find the circuit court properly concluded Auto Owners was not estopped from denying coverage.Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of the circuit court is
 
AFFIRMED.Â  Â 
HUFF, BEATTY, JJ. and CURETON, A.J., concur.Â  


[1] We note it is of no consequence that Terri thought the lease arrangement with Dorothy included a promise to provide liability coverage.Â  Any representation made by Dorothy does not translate to a representation made by Auto Owners.Â

title: Jenkins v. Jenkins
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ronald Lynn Jenkins, Appellant,
				v.
				Maria T. Jenkins, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â Berry L. Mobley, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-342
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 29, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Wendy Pauling Levine, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Robert M. P. Masella, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â In this family court matter, the appealed order vacated a prior order declaring a mistrial from a final hearing and denied post-trial motions by Ronald Lynn Jenkins (Husband) for relief from the divorce decree.Â  Husband appeals.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On September 10, 2003, Husband filed his complaint for a divorce from Maria T. Jenkins (Wife) based on a one-year separation and requested an equitable division of the marital assets.Â  Wife answered and counterclaimed in a timely manner, requesting separate support and maintenance, divorce on the ground of adultery, equitable division, a restraining order, and attorney fees and costs.Â  On November 20, 2003, Wife filed a notice of motion and motion for temporary relief. Â After a pendente lite hearing on January 14, 2004, Family Court Judge Walter B. Brown signed a temporary order on February 3, 2004, granting Wife exclusive possession and use of the marital residence, requiring Husband to pay directly to Wife $750.00 per month by the 10th day of each month toward the mortgage on the residence beginning in February 2004, and directing Husband to either pay $2,959.28 to stop the pending foreclosure action on the home or make arrangements with the mortgagee to stop the foreclosure.
Following issuance of the temporary order, a rule to show cause was issued against Husband and a hearing on the matter was scheduled for February 17, 2004.Â  Husband failed to appear on the appointed date, and on March 8, 2004, Family Court Judge H. Bruce Williams issued a bench order holding Husband in contempt and sentencing him to serve 10 days in the detention center but allowing him to purge himself by paying $200.00 in court costs by 5:00 p.m. that day.Â  Judge Williams also rescheduled the hearing for April 15, 2004.
Following the hearing on April 15, Family Court Judge Rolly Jacobs signed an order on May 20, 2004, finding Husband in willful contempt of the temporary order. Â In support of this finding, Judge Jacobs noted (1) Husband failed to pay the indebtedness on the mortgage on the marital residence or make timely arrangements with the mortgagee to stay the pending foreclosure; and (2) Husband did not pay Wife $700.00 per month toward the mortgage.[2]Â  Consequently, Judge Jacobs ordered Husband to serve 30 days in jail, with the condition that he could purge his contempt and procure his release by paying Wife $2,100.00 plus $1,800.61 in attorney fees.
Wife filed another rule to show cause alleging Husband failed to obey both the temporary order issued by Judge Brown and the order issued by Judge Jacobs.Â  A hearing on this rule to show cause took place before Family Court Judge Jack Landis on August 30, 2004.Â  By order dated and filed September 2, 2004, Judge Landis found Husband in contempt of both prior orders and sentenced him to serve no less than 6 months in the county detention center.Â  Judge Landis allowed Husband to purge himself of the contempt by paying the mortgage arrearage of $5,250.00 to Wife and previously ordered attorney fees to Wifeâ€™s counsel.[3]Â  Upon his release, Husband was to pay additional fees of $639.00 to Wifeâ€™s attorney.
A final hearing in the matter took place before Family Court Judge Berry Mobley on October 25, 2004.Â  Both parties were present and represented by counsel.Â  At the hearing, the parties announced they had reached an agreement regarding the ancillary issues, leaving only the issue of the divorce for the court to decide.Â  Judge Mobley, after hearing the terms of the agreement and examining both parties, approved the agreement and incorporated it into the final divorce decree.Â  Judge Mobley also granted Husband a divorce based on his finding that the parties had been separated more than one year.Â  Because the agreement called for Husband to pay periodic alimony, monthly installments on attorney fees awarded to Wife, and past due spousal maintenance and support, Judge Mobley, with Judge Landisâ€™s consent, suspended the contempt sentence imposed on Husband by Judge Landis the previous month and ordered Husbandâ€™s release from custody to allow Husband to begin working.Â  Judge Mobley signed the divorce decree on December 5, 2004, and the clerk of court filed it on December 9, 2004.
On December 7, 2004, Husband filed a â€œmotion to reconsider,â€ alleging in general terms that portions of the order did not seem to reflect the agreement of the parties as stated on the record and that he did not agree to certain terms of the agreement as set forth in the order.Â  On March 14, 2005, Husband, now represented by another attorney, filed a notice of motion and motion for relief pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  On July 21, 2005, Husband moved to amend his prior motions, essentially arguing that, after reviewing the trial transcript, he determined there were discrepancies between the partiesâ€™ agreement as stated on the record and the agreement as it was set forth in the divorce decree.Â  Wife did not file a response to any of Husbandâ€™s motions.
The clerk of court scheduled Husbandâ€™s motions to be heard during Judge Mobleyâ€™s next term in Richland County, which was not until November 1, 2005, and Judge Mobley ordered briefs from both parties on the salient issues.Â  On August 9, 2005, after the briefs had been submitted, Judge Mobley issued an order declaring a mistrial in the action and declaring the order that he signed on December 4, 2004, null and void except for the granting of the divorce.Â  In the order signed August 9, 2005, Judge Mobley found â€œ[b]oth parties have now filed motions to vacate the Order as it does not properly reflect the agreement as presented to the Court.â€
On August 12, 2005, counsel for Wife faxed a letter to Judge Mobley at his office in Lancaster advising that his client did not ask that the order at issue be vacated but that it be upheld.Â  Counsel further requested that Judge Mobley recommit Husband to serve the remaining time on the contempt sentence imposed by Judge Landis if the mistrial order was to remain in effect.
Judge Mobley held another hearing in the case on November 9, 2005.Â  Attorneys for both parties were present.Â  After hearing arguments from counsel, Judge Mobley ruled from the bench that he would rescind the order for mistrial. Â Judge Mobley confirmed this ruling in writing by order dated December 5, 2005, and filed December 20, 2005.Â  In the same order, Judge Mobley also denied Husbandâ€™s motions for relief under Rules 59(e) and 60, SCRCP and held the divorce decree signed December 5, 2004, would be â€œthe Order of the case.â€Â  Husband appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
1. Husband argues there was no motion filed under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to confer subject matter jurisdiction on Judge Mobley to vacate his previous order for mistrial beyond ten days of the date of issuance of that order. Â We disagree.
 
In Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 543 S.E.2d 224 (Ct. App. 2001), this court ruled that â€œa Family Court judge does not have the authority to alter or amend a judgment, sua sponte, once the judgment is more than 10-days-old.â€Â  Id. at 157, 543 S.E.2d 229.Â  In addition, because the only post-trial motion by either of the parties did not include a request for the relief granted by the family court when it decided the motion, we held there was no timely motion pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, on which the family court could base an assertion of jurisdiction. Id. at 155-56, 543 S.E.2d at 228-29.
In the present case, it is apparent from the appealed order that Judge Mobley, in noting that Wifeâ€™s attorney â€œrequested the court reconsider the rulingâ€ in his prior order declaring a mistrial in the case, considered the August 12, 2005 letter to be a motion to alter or amend.Â  In the letter, counsel noted both the execution and filing dates of the order for mistrial, thus indicating that he was responding promptly in contesting it.Â  We have found nothing in the record to suggest the letter was not sent to Husbandâ€™s counsel. Moreover, the fact that it prompted Judge Mobley to set a hearing, at which Husband was present and voiced no objection, indicates Judge Mobley considered the letter a sufficient statement of the relief Wife was requesting even though it may not have been presented in the customary form in which a post-trial motion would ordinarily be made.Â  See Arthur v. Sexton Dental Clinic, 368 S.C. 326, 334 n.5, 628 S.E.2d 894, 898 n.5 (Ct. App. 2006) (upholding the issuance of a proposed scheduling order, notwithstanding that the documents submitted by the proponent of the order â€œwere not necessarily the equivalent of a formal motionâ€ and noting that â€œ[b]ecause the circuit court and the parties were aware of the substance of Respondentsâ€™ request, we do not believe Appellants were prejudiced by the absence of a formal motionâ€); 56 Am. Jur. 2d Motions, Rules, and Orders, Â§ 16, at 15 (2000) (noting failure to comply with formalities prescribed for motions â€œmay not be fatal to the motion so long as the substantive grounds and relief desired are apparent and the nonmovant is not prejudiced by the omissionâ€). Â Because there was no dispute that Husbandâ€™s attorney received the letter within ten days after the order for mistrial was filed, we further hold the letter constituted a timely motion to alter or amend pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.
 
2. In his reply brief, Husband further contends that, under Rule 5(d), SCRCP, the August 12, 2005 letter had to be filed with the clerk of court to preserve Judge Mobleyâ€™s authority to act on it.Â  We reject this argument.Â  Â 
â€œSubject matter jurisdiction is the power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€Â  Johnston v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, 365 S.C. 293, 297, 617 S.E.2d 363, 364-65 (2005).Â  Under this definition of subject matter jurisdiction, a time limit, although mandatory, is not jurisdictional unless the governing rules for having a matter adjudicated by a particular tribunal provide otherwise.Â  See Rule 5(d), SCRCP (â€œUpon failure of a party to file other pleadings, motions, or papers, the court may permit filing or proceed as though the same had not been served.â€); In re Matthews, 345 S.C. 638, 644, 550 S.E.2d 311, 314 (2001) (holding the failure of the State either to conduct a trial regarding whether the defendant was a sexually violent predator or to seek a continuance within the statutorily-required time limit did not divest the court of jurisdiction and noting the appellantâ€™s failure to move to dismiss the case on that ground constituted a waiver of his right to challenge the Stateâ€™s failure to meet the requisite deadline); cf. McClain v. Ingram, 314 S.C. 359, 360, 444 S.E.2d 512, 512-13 (1994) (noting Rule 5(d), SCRCP, clearly requires that the summons and complaint in a civil case be filed before they are served and holding that, because â€œservice preceded filing, . . . this action was not properly commenced before expiration of the statute of limitationsâ€).
Applying the foregoing to the present case, we note (1) the only procedural requirement for a motion to alter or amend pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, is that it â€œshall be served not later than 10 days after receipt of written notice of the entry of the orderâ€; and (2) Husband does not suggest on appeal that his attorney did not receive the letter from Wifeâ€™s attorney within ten days after entry of the order for mistrial.Â  Any alleged failure to file the letter as required by Rule 5(d), SCRCP, would not have precluded Judge Mobley from exercising authority to grant Wifeâ€™s request for relief absent a pertinent objection by Husband.Â  Because Husband did not object to Wifeâ€™s proceeding on her motion or otherwise note it had not been timely filed with the clerk of court, he cannot raise this issue on appeal.Â  See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€).

  3. We disagree with Husbandâ€™s contention that Judge Mobley erred in denying his motion for relief under Rule 60(b), SCRCP, because of various alleged errors in the divorce decree.Â  Variations between that order and what was recited at the divorce hearing were not substantive discrepancies but merely changes in language for the order to be clear and enforceable.Â  Moreover, counsel for both parties reviewed the proposed order before it was submitted to Judge Mobley, and only the modifiability of the alimony amount in dispute.Â  As to that particular issue, it is clear from the transcript of the divorce hearing that alimony was to be modifiable and that the base amount was, in fact, advantageous to Husband considering his earnings during the prior year. Â Under these circumstances, we are at a loss to see how any of the alleged differences between the final order and the statements of counsel during the hearing inured to Husbandâ€™s prejudice.Â  See Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 156, 485 S.E.2d 903, 911 (1997) (stating an appellant must show prejudice to have a judgment reversed).
4.Â Finally, Husband contends Judge Mobley erred in denying his motion under Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  In support of his argument, Husband alleges the agreement was unfair from both a procedural and substantive perspective and suggests Wife took advantage of the fact that he was serving time in jail on a contempt charge issued in connection with the litigation.Â  We disagree.Â 
 
The agreement, as read into the record during the final hearing, did not address whether Husband would remain incarcerated.Â  Furthermore, it appears from the transcript that Husband was released from custody only after Judge Mobley questioned both parties about the agreement and had obtained Judge Landisâ€™s consent to suspend the contempt sentence.Â  Finally, after comparing the agreement as presented in the final order with the representations of counsel in court and after reading Judge Mobleyâ€™s examination of both parties, we are satisfied that the terms expressed in the final order were substantially the same as those recited at the hearing, that Husband assented to them notwithstanding any reservations he may have had, and that the agreement was fair to both parties.Â  
 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and KITTREDGE, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  There is no explanation as to why Judge Brown directed Husband to pay $750.00 per month to Wife toward the mortgage and Judge Jacobs, in the later order, recited the amount he was to pay was $700.00 per month.
[3]Â  Again, there is a discrepancy in that this order states the attorney fees were $1,861.00, as opposed to $1,800.61 in Judge Jacobsâ€™s order.
