title: Brown v. Worthington and Agnew
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jane Agnew Brown, Izetta Pruitt Agnew, Timothy Wigington Agnew, Thomas Simpson Agnew, Rebecca Ann Girardieau, All individually and as Trustees for Thomas Simpson Agnew as Guardian of John Pruitt Agnew, Respondents,
				v.
				Susan Agnew Worthington and James Hugh Agnew, Defendants,
				Of Whom Susan Agnew Worthington is Respondent
				And James Hugh Agnew is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Master-In-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-343
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 29, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Stephen G. Potts and Carolyn G. Baird, both of Anderson, for Appellant.
				Bernie Wellington Ellis and James A. Blair, III, both of Greenville and Susan Agnew Worthington, of Piedmont, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant, James Hugh Agnew (James), appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s order granting summary judgment on Respondentsâ€™ motion for partial summary judgment.Â  James also appeals the masterâ€™s order denying his partial summary judgment motion and motion to amend his answer, counterclaim and cross-claim.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
On August 14, 1995, J.C. Pruitt Agnew (Pruitt), Janie May S. Agnew (Janie), and their eight children formed The Agnew Family Limited Partnership (Partnership) pursuant to The Agnew Family Limited Partnership Agreement (Partnership Agreement).[2] Â Pruitt and Janie transferred certain real estate they owned to the Partnership.Â  
 
The Partnership was structured to have one thousand total units, ten general partner units, and 990 limited partner units.Â  Initially, Pruitt held six general partner units and 495 limited partner units, Janie held four general partner units and 495 limited partner units, and the children owned no Partnership units.Â  Both Pruitt and Janie made gifts of limited partner units to their eight children in 1995, 1996, 1997, and 1998.Â  As of March 4, 1998, each child owned fifty-four limited partner units and Pruitt and Janie each owned 279 limited partner units.Â  The ownership of general partner units remained the same until Janieâ€™s death on August 25, 1998, when her general partnership units passed to Pruitt under her will.
On June 7, 1999, Pruitt executed a document assigning one general partnership unit and 2.25 limited partnership units each to Jane Agnew Brown (Jane), Thomas Simpson Agnew (Tom), Izetta Pruitt Agnew (Izetta), and James.[3]Â  However, on the same day, Pruitt executed a document, Clarification of Ownership of Agnew Family Limited Partnership Interests, reflecting that Izetta and James had not accepted the general partnership units Pruitt had attempted to transfer them, had refused to sign the amendment to the certificate of limited partnership, and would receive limited partnership units instead.Â  Schedule B of the Partnership Agreement as of 6/7/99 indicate the general partners of the Partnership were Pruitt, who held eight general partnership units, and Jane and Tom, who each held one general partnership unit.Â  An amendment to the certificate of limited partnership was filed with the Secretary of State on March 9, 2000, reflecting that Jane and Tom were added as substitute general partners to the Partnership.
 
On August 1, 2000, Pruitt assigned his remaining general partnership units to Jane and Tom, who each received four units.Â  Schedule B of the Partnership Agreement as of 8/1/00 reflect the general partners of the Partnership were Jane and Tom, who each held five general partnership units.Â  An amendment to certificate of limited partnership was filed with the Secretary of State on August 18, 2000, indicating Pruittâ€™s withdrawl as a general partner.Â  Pruitt died on January 11, 2002, having transferred all of his units in the Partnership to his children.Â 
 
On July 1, 2003, Jane, Izetta, Tom, Timothy Wigington Agnew, Rebecca Ann Girardeau, and John Pruitt Agnew (the Plaintiffs) filed an action for the partition and sale of real estate against James and Susan Agnew Worthington.[4]Â  James filed an answer, counterclaim and cross-claim which sought dissolution of the Partnership and an accounting of partnership activities and transactions by Jane and Tom.Â  James was allowed to file an amended answer, counterclaim and cross-claim, which sought the same relief, but contained additional allegations.Â  The case was referred to the master-in-equity.Â  
 
Plaintiffs, less Izetta, (Respondents) filed a motion for partial summary judgment asking the court to find that neither James nor Izetta are general partners of the Partnership.Â  James filed a cross-motion for partial summary judgment asking the court to find that there are no general partners of the Partnership. Â James also filed a motion to amend his answer, counterclaim and cross-claim to conform to proof regarding his cross-motion for partial summary judgment.Â  Izetta did not file a pleading in the case, but submitted an affidavit in opposition to both motions for partial summary judgment.
At the hearing on the motions, Respondentâ€™s offered the affidavit of Kenneth B. Wingate, the attorney who prepared all of the Partnership documents.Â  The affidavit stated James refused to accept a general partnership unit because he did not want the liability associated with being a general partner.Â  Further, the affidavit explained because James and Izetta would not sign a certificate of amendment acknowledging their position as general partner, as required by statute, Pruitt assigned one general partner unit to only Jane and Tom.Â  James claimed he did not refuse to accept a general partnership unit and was never asked to sign any document relating to the assignment of general partnership units.[5]Â Alternatively, James argued there are no general partners because Pruitt failed to follow the terms of the Partnership Agreement when he appointed Jane and Tom as general partners.Â  According to Jamesâ€™ interpretation of the Partnership Agreement, to appoint new or substitute general partners the limited partners of the Partnership had to be notified and consent to such appoint.Â  Thus, James avers because he, as a limited partner, never consented to the appointment of Jane and Tom, after Pruitt transferred his general partnership shares and withdrew as general partner, there was no longer a general partner of the Partnership.
The master granted partial summary judgment on Respondentâ€™s motion finding James is not a general partner but denying partial summary judgment on Respondentâ€™s motion regarding Izetta.[6]Â  The master found James did not meet any of the statutory requirements for recognition as a general partner.Â  The master further denied Jamesâ€™ motion for partial summary judgment, finding he was barred by the doctrine of estoppel and laches because he waited too long to raise his no general partner argument.Â  The master also denied Jamesâ€™ motion to amend his answer, counterclaim and cross-claim.Â  James filed a motion to reconsider, alter, or amend the masterâ€™s order.Â  A hearing was held on January 17, 2006, at which time the master denied Jamesâ€™ motion.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard that governs the circuit court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as matter of law.Â  Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 467-68, 581 S.E.2d 496, 500-501 (Ct. App. 2003);Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 364 S.C. 222, 227, 612 S.E.2d 719, 722 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Nonetheless, a court cannot ignore facts unfavorable to that party and must determine whether a verdict for the party opposing the motion would be reasonably possible under the facts.Â  Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 423, 529 S.E.2d 710, 713 (2000) (citations omitted). 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
James appeals the grant of summary judgment in favor of the Respondentâ€™s, which found James is not a general partner of the Partnership.Â  James claims the June 7, 1999 assignment of partnership interest signed by Pruitt clearly indicates James is a general partner and, thus, there is a genuine issue of material fact as to whether he refused to accept the assignment of a general partnership interest.Â  James avers the master gave more weight to the evidence provided by the Respondentâ€™s rather than reviewing the evidence in a light most favorable to James.Â  We disagree.
In order to form a limited partnership in South Carolina, a certificate of limited partnership must be executed and filed in the office of the Secretary of State.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§33-42-210(a) (2006).Â  The certificate must set forth: (1) the name of the limited partnership; (2) the address of the office and name and address of the agent for service of process; (3) the name and mailing address of each general partner; (4) the latest date upon which the limited partnership is to dissolve; and (5) any other matters the partners determine to include.Â  Id.Â  A limited partnership is a partnership consisting of two or more limited partners and one or more general partners.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§33-42-20(7) (2006.Â  A â€œâ€˜General Partnerâ€™ means a person who has been admitted to a limited partnership as a general partner in accordance with the partnership agreement and named in the certificate of limited partnership as a general partner.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-42-20(5) (2006).Â 
 
The certificate of limited partnership is amended by filing a certificate of amendment in the office of the Secretary of State.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§33-42-220(a) (2006).Â  Within thirty days after the admission or withdrawal of a general partner a certificate of amendment must be filed.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§33-42-220(b) (2006).Â  A certificate of amendment designating a new or substitute general partner must be signed by at least one general partner and by each other general partner designated in the certificate as a new or substitute general partner.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§33-42-240 (2006). 
 
In this case, the original certificate of limited partnership, executed and filed in the office of the Secretary of State on September 21, 1995, indicates Pruitt and Janie as sole general partners.Â  In accordance with the statutory requirements, a certificate of amendment was executed and filed in the office of the Secretary of State after Janieâ€™s death to indicate the withdrawal of Janie as a general partner and the admission of Jane and Tom as general partners.Â  The certificate of amendment was signed by Pruitt, as the â€œone general partner,â€ and Jane and Tom, as the general partners designated in the certificate.
While Pruitt executed an assignment of partnership interests, on July 7, 1999, indicating an attempt to assign one general partner unit to Jane, Tom, Izetta and James, he executed a clarification of assignment of partnership interest on the same day.Â  The clarification indicates that only Jane and Tom accepted the general partner units and that Izetta and James would receive limited partner units instead. Â Also, as provided in Section 5.6 of the Partnership Agreement entitled â€œPartnership Interest,â€[7] the percentage of partnership interests from June 7, 1999 to August 1, 2000 indicate Jane and Tom as general partners and James as a limited partner.Â  
 
Further, Pruitt executed another assignment of partnership interests on August 1, 2000, transferring four general partner units each to Jane and Tom.Â  On August 18, 2000, a certificate of amendment was executed and filed in the office of the Secretary of State indicating Pruittâ€™s withdrawl as a general partner and the intent of the Partnership to continue without dissolving.Â  The certificate is signed by the remaining general partners, Jane and Tom.
 
While James argues he never refused to accept the assignment of a general partnership unit and offers Izettaâ€™s affidavit stating she never refused to accept the assignment of a general partnership unit, the overwhelming evidence and documents indicate that the general partner units were never officially assigned to James.Â  Whatever the reason, Pruitt ultimately decided not to appoint James as a general partner, and the final step of amending the certificate of limited partnership was not taken as to James.Â  Although we are bound to review the record in a light most favorable to James, we cannot ignore facts unfavorable to him.Â  See e.g. Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 423, 529 S.E.2d 710, 713 (2000).Â  Therefore, we find the grant of summary judgment in favor of Respondentâ€™s was proper.
James also appeals the denial of his cross-motion for partial summary judgment and the denial of his motion to amend his answer, counterclaim, and cross-claim.Â  It is well settled that the denial of a motion for summary judgment is not appealable.Â  Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 354 S.C. 161, 168, 580 S.E.2d 440, 444 (2003); see also Joyner v. Greenville Assocs Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 364 S.C. 237, 240, 612 S.E.2d 727, 728 (Ct. App. 2005) (declining to address the denial of appellantâ€™s motion for summary judgment). Â Similarly, it is well settled that an interlocutory order, such as an order denying a motion to amend pleadings, is not immediately appealable unless it involved the merits of the case or affects a substantial right.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§14-3-330 (Supp. 2006); see also Tatnall v. Gardner, 350 S.C. 135, 138, 564 S.E.2d 377, 379 (Ct. App. 2002) (order denying motion to amend pleadings to assert third party claims was not immediately appealable because the order did not determine a substantial matter forming the whole or part of some cause of action).Â  Thus we decline to address Jamesâ€™ arguments that the master erred by failing to grant him partial summary judgment and by failing to grant him leave to amend his answer, counterclaim, and cross-motion.
Based on the foregoing, the grant of partial summary judgment is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The Partnershipâ€™s Certificate of Limited Partnership was filed with the South Carolina Secretary of State on September 21, 1995.Â  
 
[3] Pruitt also assigned 3.25 limited partnership units to his four remaining children. Â 
[4] The partition action was resolved by Order dated December 14, 2004 and is not before this court.Â  
 
[5] Izetta also submitted an affidavit declaring she had never been asked to sign a document accepting a general partnership unit.Â 
 
[6] The master denied the motion as to Izetta because she had not filed a pleading in the action, only a response to the pending motions.Â  Thus, the master found her status, including whether she deliberately chose not to be a general partner, was a matter in which â€œfurther inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law,â€ citing Brockbank v. Best Capital Corp., 341 S.C. 372, 378, 534 S.E.2d 688, 692 (2000). Â 
[7] Section 5.6 reads, â€œEach partnerâ€™s percentage of partnership interest is the percentage reflected in Schedule B. as amended from time to time.â€ Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				James H. Dickey, Individually, and as Personal Representative for the Estate of Ruth S. Dickey, Deceased, Plaintiff,
				Of Whom James H. Dickey, Individually is the Appellant,
				v.
				Clarke Nursing Home, Cooke Associates of Florence, Inc., Carolinas Hospital System, and Does A-Z, Defendants,
				Of Whom Clarke Nursing Home is the Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Florence County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-344
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 29, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				James H. Dickey, of Charlotte, Pro
				Se.
				Robert H. Hood, Molly H. Craig and Deborah H. Sheffield, all of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  James Dickey appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on his wrongful death, negligence, and breach of contract causes of action.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
From May 1, 2001 to May 31, 2002, Dickeyâ€™s diabetic mother resided at Clarke Nursing Home (the Nursing Home). Â In April and May 2002, his mother was repeatedly admitted to Carolinas Hospital System (the Hospital).Â  From May 31, 2002 until she was discharged on June 24, 2002, the Hospital treated Dickeyâ€™s mother for foot sores. Â Prior to her discharge, the Hospital called Dickey and requested his permission to amputate her feet, which he granted. Â Dickeyâ€™s mother died in June 2003.[1]Â  
On June 30, 2005, Dickey, both in his individual capacity and as personal representative (PR) of his motherâ€™s estate, filed a complaint against the Nursing Home, Cooke Associates of Florence, Inc.,[2] the Hospital, and DOES A-Z.[3] Â Dickey alleged: (1) professional and medical negligence; (2) gross professional and medical negligence; (3) wrongful death; and (4) breach of contract.[4] Â 
In his complaint, Dickey maintained the Nursing Home, despite knowing his mother was diabetic, transported her in a wheelchair without foot guards or footwear protection. Â Dickey alleged that because of this practice, she developed ulcers on her feet and heels.Â  These ulcers became infected and resulted in her untimely death. 
 
On August 4, 2005, the Nursing Home filed a motion for summary judgment, claiming Dickey lacked standing to bring any claims on behalf of his mother in his individual capacity and the statute of limitations barred the claims. Â The Nursing Home asserted Dickeyâ€™s mother last resided at its facility on May 31, 2002, but Dickey commenced the suit over three years later on June 30, 2005.Â  

On September 20, 2005, the trial court held a hearing on the Nursing Homeâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  The trial court found the date that the Hospital informed Dickey his mother needed an amputation was the date that a reasonable person would be on notice that a potential claim existed against the Nursing Home. Â Dickey could not recall the exact date the Hospital informed him his mother needed an amputation.Â  Therefore, the trial court set the date beginning the statute of limitations no later than June 24, 2002, the date of her last discharge. Â Accordingly, the statute of limitations expired no later than June 24, 2005, six days before Dickey filed the complaint. 

On September 27, 2005, after the summary judgment hearing, the South Carolina Bar placed Dickey on interim suspension for an unrelated matter.[5] Â On October 31, 2005, Dickey filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration regarding the summary judgment motion. Â In ruling on the motion for reconsideration, the trial court found Dickey was authorized to file the complaint in his individual capacity, but he was not authorized to file it on behalf of the estate due to his suspension. Â See Brown v. Coe, 365 S.C. 137, 142, 616 S.E.2d 705, 708 (2005) (holding because an estate is a separate legal entity from the individual named as PR, a PR who is not a lawyer cannot represent an estate in court). Â Because his license was suspended, his attempt to file the motion on behalf of his motherâ€™s estate was tantamount to the unauthorized practice of law. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-5-310 (Supp. 2005).Â  Therefore, the trial court considered the motion only as to Dickey in his individual capacity and denied the motion. Â In his individual capacity, Dickey appealed the trial courtâ€™s decision. 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the disposition of cases not requiring the services of a fact finder.  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).  When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this Court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002) (internal citation omitted).  Under this rule, summary judgment is proper when no genuine issue as to any material fact exists, and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.  Id.  
 
In determining whether a triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all factual inferences drawn from it must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.  Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 354 S.C. 397, 404, 581 S.E.2d 161, 165 (2003).  If evidentiary facts are not disputed, but the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them are, summary judgment should be denied. Â Baugus v. Wessinger, 303 S.C. 412, 415, 401 S.E.2d 169, 171 (1991).  Summary judgment is not appropriate when further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of law.  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Dickey assigns several points of error to the trial courtâ€™s grant of the Nursing Homeâ€™s motion for summary judgment based on the statute of limitations. Â In response, the Nursing Home contends that any cause of action is barred by the statute of limitations.Â  The Nursing Home further claims that Dickey, in his individual capacity, cannot pursue these causes of action.Â  We agree with the Nursing Home.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 
At the trial level, Dickey asserted claims for wrongful death, negligence, gross negligence, and breach of contract.Â  We address each claim in turn. 
 
I. Wrongful Death
The wrongful death statute provides a remedy for the spouse, child, parent, or heir of an injured party when a person commits a wrongful or negligent act causing the injured partyâ€™s death.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-51-10, 15-51-20 (Supp. 2005).Â  Any recovery directly benefits the individual rather than the decedentâ€™s general estate.Â  Lester v. McFaddon, 415 F.2d 1101, 1103 (4th Cir. 1969).Â  However, any recovery under this cause of action constitutes the individualâ€™s complete remedy.Â  See Banks v. Med. Univ. of S.C., 314 S.C. 376, 380, 444 S.E.2d 519, 521 (1994) (holding if a mother brings a claim in her individual capacity for her decedent child, the wrongful death statute is her exclusive remedy); Green v. S. Ry. Co., 319 F. Supp. 919, 919-20 (D.S.C. 1970) (holding recovery under the wrongful death statute is the exclusive remedy for an individual). Â Therefore, Dickeyâ€™s only vehicle to recover for his motherâ€™s death is under the wrongful death statute.Â 
 
Although the wrongful death statute is the only avenue of recovery for Dickey as an individual, such an action inheres only in the PR, and the statutory beneficiaries cannot proceed in their individual capacity.Â  Lester, 415 F.2d at 1103.Â  Under the statute, â€œthe right of action for wrongful death is purely statutory and . . . may be brought only by the executor or administrator of such deceased person.â€Â  Glenn v. E. I. DuPont De Nemours & Co., 254 S.C. 128, 133, 174 S.E.2d 155, 157 (1970) (citing Lilly v. Charlotte, C. & A. R. Co., 32 S.C. 142, 10 S.E. 932 (1890)); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-51-20 (Supp. 2005) (â€œEvery [wrongful death] action shall be brought by or in the name of the executor or administrator of such person.â€).Â  
 
While a non-lawyer PR may administer the affairs of an estate and maintain an action on the estateâ€™s behalf, a PR must be a lawyer if the PR intends to represent the estate in court.Â  Brown, 365 S.C. at 141, 616 S.E.2d at 708.Â  Because the estate is a separate legal entity, only a lawyer can represent the interests of the estate and its beneficiaries in court.Â  Id. at 142, 616 S.E.2d at 708 (holding â€œthe filing of a notice of appeal on behalf of the estate and preparation of briefs . . . clearly constitutes the practice of lawâ€).Â  
 
Consequently, Dickeyâ€™s appeal on the wrongful death claim in his individual capacity cannot succeed.Â  If an action for wrongful death is instituted by one other than the PR of a decedent, the trial court should dismiss the action.Â  Glenn, 254 S.C. at 134, 174 S.E.2d at 158.Â  Although Dickey could have potentially recovered as an individual under the wrongful death statute if he, as PR, brought the action and a licensed lawyer represented the estate in court, he failed to do so. Â Therefore, the trial court properly dismissed this claim. 
 
II.Â Negligence and Gross Negligence
Dickeyâ€™s claims for negligence and gross negligence arise out of the same alleged malfeasance as that alleged for wrongful death.Â  As explained above, wrongful death is the only remedy for an individual.Â  While as PR he may have had a potential claim for negligence under the survival statute, Dickey has appealed only in his individual capacity.Â  See Banks, 314 S.C. at 381 n.5, 444 S.E.2d at 522 n.5 (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-90 (2005)) (â€œAlthough . . . wrongful death is [decedentâ€™s motherâ€™s] exclusive remedy [in her individual capacity], the battery cause of action may be maintained by [the mother] in her representative capacity for [decedent] under the survival statute.â€). Â Consequently, the trial court did not err when it dismissed these claims.
III. Breach of Contract
Dickey claims the Nursing Home breached its contract with his mother when it refused to notify Dickey of regulatory violations, of substandard performance on the part of the Nursing Homeâ€™s employees and personnel, and of any change in conditions regarding his motherâ€™s health.Â  Dickey further claims the Nursing Home, as his motherâ€™s caregiver, extended both implied and express warranties to his mother by virtue of her residence at the Nursing Home.Â  
 
However, Dickey has appealed only in his individual capacity, and he does not specifically assert that he had a contract with the Nursing Home nor does he provide such a contract.Â  Generally, a third person not in privity of contract with the contracting parties does not have a right to enforce the contract.Â  Wogan v. Kunze, 366 S.C. 583, 604, 623 S.E.2d 107, 118 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  While his mother may have had a contract with the Nursing Home,[6] Dickey in his individual capacity cannot enforce such a contract, and thus, he has no cause of action for breach of contract.Â  
 
On appeal, the Nursing Home primarily argues that this Court should affirm the trial court based on the expiration of the statute of limitations.Â  The Nursing Home further supports its position by arguing that Dickey, in his personal capacity, is not entitled to maintain the current action.Â  See 
Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 419, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000) (â€œ[A] respondent . . . may raise . . . any additional reasons the appellate court should affirm the lower courtâ€™s ruling, regardless of whether those reasons have been presented to or ruled on by the lower court.â€).Â  Because this Court has the discretion to affirm on any ground in the record, we decline to address Dickeyâ€™s arguments regarding the statute of limitations. Â See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (holding an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive); see also Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, decision or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€).
CONCLUSION
The wrongful death statute provides an individualâ€™s only avenue of recovery for wrongful or negligent acts which cause anotherâ€™s death.Â  Further, a duly appointed PR must institute a wrongful death action on behalf of the estate, and a licensed lawyer must represent the estate in court.Â  Since Dickey appealed the trial courtâ€™s decision only in his individual capacity, he cannot maintain this appeal.Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.[7]Â  
STILWELL, SHORT, AND WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Neither the Record on Appeal nor the briefs contain the exact date or cause of death.
[2] Dickey asserts that Cooke Associates of Florence, Inc. is another name for the Nursing Home. 
 
[3] In his complaint, Dickey explained that he did not know the identity of some defendants in this matter, and thus, he gave the unknown defendants the name DOES A-Z.Â  Dickey stated he would make a motion to amend his complaint â€œwhen the true capacity, identity, or names of these [d]efendants has been ascertained.â€Â 
 
[4] Dickey was a licensed South Carolina attorney at the time of the filing and represented himself and the estate.
[5] In re Dickey, 366 S.C. 18, 620 S.E.2d 332 (2005).Â  
 
[6] We note that Dickey did not include a contract between his mother and the Nursing Home in the record on appeal.Â  See Germain v. Nichol, 278 S.C. 508, 509, 299 S.E.2d 335, 335 (1983) (â€œAppellant has the burden of providing this Court with a sufficient record upon which this Court can make its decision.â€).
[7] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Fernandes v. Fernandes
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Linda Kay
          Fernandes, Respondent,
        v.
        Joseph Carlos
          Fernandes, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â FrancesÂ  P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-345
  Heard February 6, 2007 â€“ Filed June 29,
  2007
  Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled September
  13, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
MODIFIED


  
    
      
        Gregory Samuel Forman, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Cynthia Barrier Patterson, of Columbia and David Dusty Rhoades, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Joseph Carlos Fernandes (Husband)
  appeals the family courtâ€™s divorce order, which granted Linda Kay Fernandes
  (Wife) a divorce on the ground of adultery, denied Husband alimony, equitably
  divided the marital property, credited Wife with health insurance costs, ordered
  Husband to pay child support through the court, and ordered Husband to pay Wife
$10,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and modify.

FACTS
Husband
  and Wife purchased a house (marital house) in July 1986.Â  In October 1986,
  Husband and Wife married.Â  Husband and Wife have two children.Â  
Husband worked for the United States Navy
  from October 1981 through April 1994.Â  In April 1994, Husband retired from the
  military for medical reasons, and thereafter, he earned income from military
  retirement/disability payments, from refereeing soccer matches, and from
  miscellaneous yard work.Â  Wife derives her income from teaching at a technical
  college.Â  In 1997, Husband and Wife fully paid off the mortgage on the marital
house.Â  
In August 2001, Husband and Wife
  separated.Â  Wife purchased and moved into a separate residence (Wifeâ€™s house),
and Husband remained in the marital house. Â 
In June 2002, Wife filed an action for
  separate maintenance.Â  In March 2003, Wife filed an amended complaint seeking
  divorce on the ground of adultery.Â  After a hearing, the family court: (1) found
  Wife was entitled to a divorce on the ground of adultery; (2) ordered Husband
  to pay $10,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife; (3) gave Wife sole custody of the
  children; (4) ordered Husband to pay child support in the amount of $286 per
  month through the court, plus the 5% administrative service charge; (5)
  equitably divided the marital property; (6) determined Husbandâ€™s Navy Federal
  Credit Union accounts and Charleston Naval Shipyard Federal Credit Union
  accounts were marital property; (7) ordered the marital home to be sold and the
  proceeds divided equally after Husband received $38,808.85 (because Wife had
  more assets); (8) ordered Husband to pay one-half the fair market rental value
  of the marital house to Wife for the time he remained in the house, beginning
  ninety days after the date of the court order; (9) determined Husband had no
  interest in Wifeâ€™s house; and (10) determined Husband would receive the Toyota
  Rav-4 valued at $9,000.Â  Husband filed a motion to alter or amend the family
  courtâ€™s judgment, which was generally denied.[1]Â 
This appeal follows.Â  
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
â€œWhen reviewing the factual determinations of the family court, an
  appellate court may take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Scott
    v. Scott, 354
  S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).Â  However, â€œthe appellate courtâ€™s broad scope of review does not relieve the
  appellant of the burden of showing that the family court committed error.â€Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 62, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).Â  Also, when evidence is disputed, the appellate court may adhere to the
  findings of the family court, which is in a superior position to judge the
witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Adultery
Husband contends the family court erred in finding he
  committed adultery.Â  Specifically, Husband asserts there was no evidence of his
inclination to commit adultery.Â  We disagree. 
â€œTo obtain a divorce on the ground of adultery, the evidence
  establishing the adultery â€˜must be clear and positive, and the infidelity must
  be established by a clear preponderance of the evidence.â€™â€Â  Nemeth v. Nemeth, 325 S.C. 480, 484, 481 S.E.2d 181, 183 (Ct. App. 1997) (quoting Brown v. Brown, 215 S.C. 502, 512-13, 56 S.E.2d 330, 335 (1949)).Â  â€œAdultery
  may be proved by circumstantial evidence, or by direct evidence, or a
  combination of the two; and circumstantial evidence is just as good as direct
evidence if it is equally convincing.â€Â  Anders v. Anders, 285 S.C. 512, 515, 331 S.E.2d 340, 342 (1985).Â  
The proof of adultery â€œmust
  be sufficiently definite to identify the time and place of the offense, and the
  circumstances under which it was committed.â€Â  Nemeth, 325 S.C. at 484, 481 S.E.2d at 183.Â  â€œCircumstantial evidence showing the opportunity and inclination to
commit adultery is sufficient to establish a prima facie case.â€Â  Id.
At trial, Wife argued Husband had an affair with Maria
  Garcia.Â  In support of her position, Wife presented items she found in June
  2002 in the marital home.Â  Wife submitted various romantic cards allegedly from
  Garcia to Husband.Â  One card states, â€œI miss you.Â  My heart aches for you.Â  My
  stomach is in knots because weâ€™re apart.â€Â  Another reads, â€œThereâ€™s only one
  good thing about us being apart, The â€˜welcome backâ€™ sex is gonna be great!!â€Â 
  The cards are signed either â€œMaria â€˜Bragaâ€™â€ or â€œCeu,â€ Garciaâ€™s middle name.Â 
  Also, Wife introduced a book entitled, â€œ101 Nights of Great Sex,â€ which she
  alleged came from Garcia.Â  In addition, Wife presented three pages from an
instant messaging exchange;[2] the exchange is between â€œCeushinhaâ€ and â€œJCFMSoccer.â€Â  
Wife testified Garciaâ€™s â€œemail nameâ€ is â€œCeushinhaâ€
  and Husbandâ€™s â€œemail nameâ€ is â€œJCFMSoccer.â€Â  The instant message text suggests
  the parties to the exchange have passionate feelings for each other and have
  been intimate.Â  At one point, Ceushina said, â€œTell me I never called you by his
  name when we were making loveâ€ to which JCFM replied, â€œYes, you did,
  subconsciously things happen!â€Â  Further, Wife testified that in June 2002, she
  found blue lingerie that was not hers in the marital home.Â  Finally, Wife
  offered a video and witness testimony that suggest Garcia stayed overnight with
Husband in July 2002.Â  
In contrast, Husband averred he and Garcia are long-time
  friends and have never had romantic feelings for one another.Â  Husband admitted
  he and Garcia spent three nights together at his house in July 2002.Â  However,
  Husband explained he and Garcia slept in different bedrooms throughout Garciaâ€™s
  stay.Â  Moreover, Husband testified Garcia intended to stay only a few hours but
  unexpectedly extended her stay because she became ill.Â  Also, Husband testified
  he had never seen the sex book or romantic cards Garcia allegedly sent to him.Â 
  Similarly, Husband testified he did not recognize the instant message exchange
introduced by Wife.Â  
Husband also provided Garciaâ€™s deposition testimony to
  further refute Wifeâ€™s contention.Â  Garcia testified she and Husband are like
  brother and sister.Â  In addition, Garcia testified she visited Husband in July
  2002 when she was en route to visit her boyfriend.Â  Garcia averred she planned
  to stay only a few hours but stayed longer because she began to feel ill.Â 
  Garcia testified she and Husband stayed in separate bedrooms.Â  Further, Garcia
  testified she did not recall sending any romantic cards or sex books to
  Husband; however, Garcia admitted that the handwriting in two of the cards
looked like hers.Â  
We find the record provides sufficient evidence to
  support the family courtâ€™s finding that Husband committed adultery.Â  First, it
  is undisputed that Husband had the opportunity to commit adultery with Garcia
  in July 2002.Â  Second, the romantic cards, the instant messaging exchange, the
  sex book, and the unclaimed lingerie all suggest Husband was inclined to commit
  adultery with Garcia.Â  We concur with and adhere to the family courtâ€™s findings
  in this instance.Â  Woodall, 322 S.C. at 10, 471 S.E.2d at 157 (holding â€œthe appellate court may adhere to the findings of the trial judge
  who . . . was in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and
  veracityâ€).Â  Therefore, we find the family court did not err in
holding Husband committed adultery. 
II.  Alimony
Husband next asserts that if we hold the family court
  erred in finding Husband committed adultery, we must remand Husbandâ€™s claim for
  alimony.Â  We will not address this issue because of our disposition on the
  first issue.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889
  (1993) (stating this Court does not need to address remaining issues when
resolution of a prior issue is dispositive).Â  
III.  Toyota Rav-4
Husband argues the family court erred in awarding the
  Toyota Rav-4 to Husband and in failing to account for the pendente lite depreciation of the vehicle.Â  We find the family court did not err in awarding
Husband the Rav-4 but did err in its valuation of the vehicle.Â Â  
Husband
  and Wife purchased the Rav-4 in 1999.Â  Wife sought temporary and permanent
  possession of the Rav-4 in both her initial and amended complaints.Â  The family
  court awarded Wife possession of the Rav-4 during the pendency of this action.Â 
  Throughout this case, Wife possessed and used the Rav-4.Â  
Wifeâ€™s
  initial financial declaration, submitted in November 2002, listed the value of
  the Rav-4 at $9,000.Â  Wifeâ€™s amended financial declaration, submitted at trial
  in July 2004, valued the Rav-4 at $4,000.Â  The family court awarded the Rav-4
  to Husband, valuing it at $9,000.Â  
a.  Award of Rav-4 to Husband
Generally, â€œ[t]he apportionment of
  marital property is within the family court judgeâ€™s discretion and will not be
  disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Doe v.
    Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 502, 478 S.E.2d 854, 859 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  In making an equitable distribution of marital property, the
  family court must, among other things: (1) identify the marital property, both
  real and personal, to be divided between the parties; (2) determine the fair
  market value of the identified property; (3) apportion the marital estate
  according to the contributions, both direct and indirect, of each party to the
  acquisition of the property during the marriage, their respective assets and
  incomes, and any special equities they may have in marital assets; and (4)
  provide for an equitable division of the marital estate, including the manner
in which the distribution is to take place. Â Nasser-Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 197, 612 S.E.2d 707, 715 (Ct. App. 2005).
In addition, the family court must consider fifteen criteria
  specified by section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), weighing
  each as it finds appropriate based on the facts of the case.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 297, 372 S.E.2d 107, 112 (Ct. App. 1988). Â â€œThese
  criteria guide the court in exercising its discretion over apportionment of the
  marital propertyâ€ and â€œare nothing more than equities to
  be considered in reaching a fair distribution of marital property.â€Â  Id. at 297-98, 372 S.E.2d at 112.Â  â€œOn review of an equitable apportionment of
  marital property, this [C]ourt looks to the fairness of the overall
  apportionment and if the end result is equitable, it is irrelevant that this
  [C]ourt might have weighed specific factors differently than the trial [C]ourt.â€Â  Doe, 324 S.C. at 502, 478
S.E.2d at 859.Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â 
We find the family court did not commit an abuse of discretion in
  awarding the Rav-4 to Husband. Â The family courtâ€™s order provides that in
  determining the equitable apportionment of the property, it â€œspecifically
  considered all factors as set forth in 1-15 subparts of South Carolina Code of
  Law Section 20-7-472 and . . . gave weight as the court found appropriate to
  all of the factors enumerated in that statute.â€Â  After consideration of the
  facts in this case, we affirm the family courtâ€™s award.Â  Because Husband did
  not want the Rav-4 does not make the family courtâ€™s award an abuse of
  discretion.Â  The family court was well within its authority to award the Rav-4,
a portion of the marital estate, to Husband.
b.  Value of Rav-4
Generally, â€œfor purposes of equitable distribution, the value of
  marital property is the value of the property at the time of the commencement
  of the marital litigation.â€Â  Dixon v. Dixon, 334 S.C. 222, 227,
  512 S.E.2d 539, 541 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œIt is equally true, however, that the
  parties may be entitled to share in any appreciation or depreciation in marital assets occurring after separation
  but before divorce.â€Â  Fields v. Fields, 342 S.C. 182, 186, 536 S.E.2d 684, 686 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In cases when a substantial delay exists between the commencement
  of the action and its ultimate resolution, â€œthe family court has the ability to
  consider the post-filing appreciation or depreciation when valuing and
